426.590.  Failure to deliver property on forthcoming bond — Return of officer — Liability of surety — Execution for balance due.

Text

(1) If the defendant in execution fails to pay or replevy the amount of the execution, and fails to deliver the property specified in the forthcoming bond or other property in its place sufficient to satisfy the execution and all costs and commissions, the officer shall return the execution and bond to the office where it was issued and endorse on the execution the levy, the giving of the bond, the particular property which is not forthcoming and all other facts. The surety on the forthcoming bond shall be liable only for the value of the property specified in the bond which is not forthcoming, with interest thereon from the date of the bond and the accruing costs.

(2) If the property specified in a forthcoming bond is not of value sufficient to satisfy the execution and all costs and commissions, the proper officer may issue another execution and credit it with the value of the property specified in the bond.

History

History.
1672.

Annotations

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Bond of Purchaser of Property Under Execution, Form 151.13.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Returns of Sheriff on Executions, Form 151.24.


426.600.  Liability of officer for failure to return forthcoming bond.

Text

Any officer taking a forthcoming bond who fails to return it to the proper office for twenty (20) days after the failure to comply on the part of the defendant in execution shall, with his sureties, be liable to the plaintiff for the amount of the execution, costs and commission, and for an additional twenty percent (20%) thereon, to be recovered by action or motion against any one (1) or more of them or their representatives.

History

History.
1673.


426.610.  Bonds having the effect of a judgment — General provisions for.

Text

(1) Every bond taken on the sale of property under an order of judgment in chancery or on the sale of property under execution, and every replevin and forthcoming bond, shall be signed by the principal and surety, and attested by the person taking the bond, or by someone in his presence. A bond so taken shall be returned to the proper office, with a report of the acts of the person taking it, and, if taken under an execution, the execution shall be returned with the bond. Every such bond shall have the force and effect of a judgment, and if not paid at maturity an execution may issue, which shall be endorsed that no surety of any kind is to be taken.

(2) The officer taking any bond referred to in subsection (1) of this section, and his sureties, or their representatives, shall be jointly and severally liable to the person injured for any damage he may sustain by the officer taking as surety on the bond a person who was not solvent at the time.

(3) If one (1) of several obligors or obligees, in any bond referred to in subsection (1) of this section, dies before the bond is satisfied, execution may issue on the bond in the name of the surviving obligees, against the obligor or the survivor. If all the obligees in such a bond die, their personal representatives may, if the bond is not satisfied at maturity, sue out execution thereon against the obligors or their personal representatives if they are all dead, or, if only part are dead, against the survivor and the personal representatives of the deceased.

(4) If any bond referred to in subsection (1) of this section is quashed, a new execution may issue on the original judgment at the instance of the plaintiff, in the same manner as if the bond had never been given.

History

History.
1676 to 1680.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Sale Bond.

  2. — Effect.

  3. — Signatures.

  4. — Execution.

  5. — Sureties.

  1. Sale Bond. 

 Bond to replevy execution is within this section. E. I. Du Pont De Nemours & Co. v. Combs, 246 Ky. 802, 56 S.W.2d 523, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 28 (Ky. 1933).

  2. — Effect. 

 When the order confirming the commissioner’s sale is entered, it gives life to the sale bond, which then becomes an accepted obligation binding on the principal and sureties to complete the sale, and is in effect a confessed judgment for the amount of the bond. American Asso. v. Hurst, 59 F. 1, 1893 U.S. App. LEXIS 2325 (6th Cir. Ky. 1893).

 The execution of a bond extinguishes the judgment and any suit brought thereafter must be on the bond which is regarded as having the effect of a judgment. Kentucky River Coal Corp. v. Culton, 276 Ky. 418, 124 S.W.2d 82, 1938 Ky. LEXIS 555 (Ky. 1938).

  3. — Signatures. 

 Replevin bond was not sufficient to authorize execution against surety’s property where, although signed by surety and approved by court clerk, it was not signed by principal, provision of this section requiring signature by principal and surety being mandatory. Ewing v. Union Cent. Bank, 254 Ky. 623, 72 S.W.2d 4, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 118 (Ky. 1934).

 Bond to replevy execution bearing forged signature of surety was void and no legal right could be based on it; it was not merely voidable. Commonwealth use of Eversole v. West, 261 Ky. 204, 87 S.W.2d 385, 1935 Ky. LEXIS 629 (Ky. 1935).

  4. — Execution. 

 Sale bonds on judicial sale of land payable to commissioner were collectible by him, on default, by having execution issued, without court order directing him to do so. Ison v. Commonwealth, 110 Ky. 112, 60 S.W. 1125, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 1588, 1901 Ky. LEXIS 61 (Ky. 1901).

 Execution upon bond given by purchaser of land sold under judgment was properly issued where bond was past due and sale bonds were not paid. Torian v. Caldwell, 167 Ky. 670, 181 S.W. 373, 1916 Ky. LEXIS 478 (Ky. 1916).

  5. — Sureties. 

 Sheriff would be liable if he took bond to replevy execution with sureties who were insolvent when bond was executed. E. I. Du Pont De Nemours & Co. v. Combs, 246 Ky. 802, 56 S.W.2d 523, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 28 (Ky. 1933).

 A married woman was not a solvent surety within the meaning of this section because her property would not be subject to the payment of bonds and, therefore, it was improper to accept her as a surety. Commonwealth use of Zimmer v. Craig, 251 Ky. 218, 64 S.W.2d 898, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 852 (Ky. 1933). (See KRS 404.010.).

  Cited: 

 Pineville Steam Laundry v. Phillips, 254 Ky. 391, 71 S.W.2d 980, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 93 (Ky. 1934).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Cross-References. 

Bond lost or destroyed, proceedings, KRS 422.220.

Surety on bond, limitation on action against, KRS 412.120, 412.130.

Suretyship, joint obligations and contribution, KRS ch. 412.

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Execution on Bond Having Effect of Judgment, Form 151.08.


426.615.  Execution plaintiff may substitute for officer in action for recovery of property taken under execution or rent attachment.

Text

In an action against a sheriff or other officer for the recovery of property taken under an execution or rent attachment the court may, upon the application of the defendant and of the party in whose favor the execution or rent attachment is issued, permit the latter to be substituted as the defendant, security for the costs being given.

History

History.
C.C. 32: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1; 1976, ch. 91, § 42.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  1. Action Against Officer. 

 A creditor may be substituted for the officer who is sued in an action for recovery of property taken under execution, but this does not authorize the exoneration of the officer from liability unless bond has been given in conformity with the provisions of former KRS 426.620. Curry v. Ball, 58 S.W. 534, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 592, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 727 (Ky. 1900).


426.620.   Indemnity bond required before levy of execution. [Repealed.]

Annotations

 Compiler’s Notes. 

 This section (C.C. 641: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1) was repealed by Acts 1976, ch. 91, § 46.


426.625.  Rights of officer if indemnity bond not given. [Repealed.]

Annotations

 Compiler’s Notes. 

 This section (C.C. 642: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1) was repealed by Acts 1976, ch. 91, § 46.


426.630.  Action by claimant or purchaser must be upon indemnity bond. [Repealed.]

Annotations

 Compiler’s Notes. 

 This section (C.C. 643: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1) was repealed by Acts 1976, ch. 91, § 46.


426.635.  Disposition of surplus proceeds of sale. [Repealed.]

Annotations

 Compiler’s Notes. 

 This section (C.C. 644: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1) was repealed by Acts 1976, ch. 91, § 46.


426.640.  Bond required for suspension of sale of personal property.

Text

The sale of personal property upon which an execution is levied shall be suspended at the instance of any person, other than the defendant in the execution, claiming the property, who shall execute, with one (1) or more sureties sufficient for double its value, a bond to the plaintiff in the execution, to the effect that, if it shall be adjudged that the property or any part of it is subject to the execution, he will pay to the plaintiff the value of the property so subject, and ten percent (10%) thereon, not exceeding the amount due on the execution, and ten percent (10%) thereon.

History

History.
C.C. 645: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Claimant’s Bond.

  2. — Discharge in Bankruptcy.

  3. — Satisfaction.

  1. Claimant’s Bond. 

 Sale, under an execution levy on property of a tenant upon which his landlord has a lien for rent, may be suspended by the landlord, or by the surety of the tenant on his bond provided by this section of the statute, but on such bond, when the property levied on will not pay the rent, the plaintiff in the execution is not entitled to any judgment. Smith v. Wells' Adm'x, 67 Ky. 92, 1868 Ky. LEXIS 86 (Ky. 1868) (decided under prior law).

 In an action seeking a sale of personal property upon which an execution has been levied, where the sale has been suspended by the execution of a bond by claimants of the cattle, who were not defendants in the execution, they may show any equitable cause against judgment, in whole or in part, on the bond. Williams v. Smith, 67 Ky. 540, 1868 Ky. LEXIS 187 (Ky. 1868) (decided under prior law).

 A third party who executed a forthcoming bond for property levied on, the bond reciting that it was the property of the execution defendant, could not, afterward, without proof of fraud or mistake, assert ownership and claim to the property be executing a claimant’s bond, and thereby prevent judgment against him on the forthcoming bond. Sparks v. Shropshire, 67 Ky. 550, 1868 Ky. LEXIS 190 (Ky. 1868) (decided under prior law).

 Where judgment was obtained by creditor against principal debtor and his sureties and shortly thereafter execution issued thereon and one of sureties paid debt and took assignment of the judgment and had an execution levied upon property for which claimant executed a bond to the assignor of judgment, the court determined he could not recover from the sureties in claimant’s bond because the bond was not executed to plaintiff in the execution. Lair's Guardian v. Wilson, 76 Ky. 589, 1878 Ky. LEXIS 3 (Ky. 1878).

 Where a levy was made upon a one-half interest in a crop of tobacco owned jointly by the execution debtor and another and claimant of the one-half (1/2) interest executed a claimant’s bond, upon motion for judgment on the bond, the court, in denying judgment, determined that the bond was unauthorized without consideration and therefore invalid. Aaron v. Mendel, 78 Ky. 427, 1880 Ky. LEXIS 35 (Ky. 1880).

 In an action where a distress warrant issued for rent in arrears and which was levied upon certain personal property, the defendants were permitted by the court to execute a bond under this section of the statute, which suspended the sale of the property under the warrant. Scott Bros. v. Flood's Trustee, 124 Ky. 739, 99 S.W. 967, 30 Ky. L. Rptr. 955, 1907 Ky. LEXIS 234 (Ky. 1907).

  2. — Discharge in Bankruptcy. 

 In an action against sureties in an indemnifying bond, where it was shown that an execution was issued upon a judgment and was levied upon a stock of goods and later the execution defendant obtained a discharge in bankruptcy, the court determined that a discharge in bankruptcy did not discharge the levy of execution and did not affect the right of a judgment creditor to recover on claimant’s bond. Bishop v. John H. Hibben Dry Goods Co., 99 S.W. 644, 30 Ky. L. Rptr. 725 (1907).

  3. — Satisfaction. 

 Where an execution has been levied upon a stock of merchandise, the execution of a claimant’s bond does not prevent the sheriff from proceeding against other property of the defendants, nor from allowing them to replevy the debt, but the entire satisfaction of the execution is not entire satisfaction of the bond if the sale was wrongfully suspended by its execution. Southern Bank Ky. v. White & McMahan, 62 Ky. 290, 1864 Ky. LEXIS 64 (Ky. 1864) (decided under prior law).

  Cited: 

 Olney Trust & Banking Co. v. Vickers, 309 Ky. 657, 218 S.W.2d 684, 1949 Ky. LEXIS 789 (Ky. 1949).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Claimant’s Bond to Suspend Sale Under an Execution, Form 151.16.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Notice of a Motion Against Obligors in a Claimant’s Bond, Given to Suspend a Sale Under an Execution, Form 151.20.


426.645.  Property to be appraised for purpose of taking bond.

Text

For the purpose of taking the bond mentioned in KRS 426.640, the officer shall select three (3) disinterested housekeepers, and administer to them an oath to make a fair appraisement of each article of the property; whose appraisement, in writing, shall be recited in the bond.

History

History.
C.C. 646: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  1. Appraisal. 

 Where execution, issued upon a judgment, was levied upon a stock of merchandise as the property of the execution defendants, and a claimant of the property, before sale by the sheriff, executed a claimant’s bond, the sheriff had the authority under this section of the statute to surrender the property to the claimant after having it appraised. Borches v. Bellis, 110 Ky. 620, 62 S.W. 486, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 37, 1901 Ky. LEXIS 115 (Ky. 1901).

  Cited: 

 Milliken v. Harrod, 275 Ky. 597, 122 S.W.2d 148, 1938 Ky. LEXIS 471 (Ky. 1938).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Appraisement of Personal Property Before Taking Claimant’s Bond, Form 151.18.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Claimant’s Bond to Suspend Sale Under an Execution, Form 151.16.


426.650.  Return of indemnity bond and appraisement to court. [Repealed.]

Annotations

 Compiler’s Notes. 

 This section (C.C. 647: Trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953; 1976 (Ex. Sess.), ch. 14, § 435, effective January 2, 1978) was repealed by Acts 1984, ch. 111, § 199, effective July 13, 1984.


426.655.  Trial of motion for judgment on bond — Judgment — Execution.

Text

The party to whom the bond is executed may move the court to which it is returned for a judgment thereon against all or any of the obligors or their representatives, having given to them ten (10) days’ notice of the motion. The court shall direct a jury to be empaneled, and may cause such issues to be tried as it may prescribe, and direct which party shall be considered plaintiff in the issues. If the property, or any part of it, be found subject to the execution, judgment shall be rendered in favor of the plaintiff therein for the value of the property so subject and ten percent (10%) thereon, not exceeding the amount due on the execution and ten percent (10%) thereon. An execution may be issued upon the judgment forthwith, on which the same indorsement shall be made as on the execution in virtue of which the property had been seized.

History

History.
C.C. 648: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Judgment on Bond.

  2. — Notice to Surety.

  3. — Jury.

  4. — Pleadings.

  5. — Burden of Proof.

  6. — Damages.

  1. Judgment on Bond. 

 In a motion for judgment upon a claimant’s bond, where the defendants in the execution replevy it after the execution of the claimant’s bond, the obligors in the bond are liable for the ten per cent damages and the costs resulting from the execution of the bond and, if the replevin bond should be quashed, the plaintiffs in the execution can proceed on the claimant’s bond. Southern Bank Ky. v. White & McMahan, 62 Ky. 290, 1864 Ky. LEXIS 64 (Ky. 1864) (decided under prior law).

 A third party executing a forthcoming bond for property levied on which recites it is the property of the execution defendant cannot, without proof of fraud or mistake, assert ownership and claim to such property by executing a claimant’s bond, and thereby prevent judgment against him on his forthcoming bond. Sparks v. Shropshire, 67 Ky. 550, 1868 Ky. LEXIS 190 (Ky. 1868) (decided under prior law).

 In a motion for judgment upon a bond, it is not required that the plaintiff state in the notice, or show upon the trial, that he sustained any loss by reason of the execution of the bond, or that he could not have collected his debt otherwise that by a sale of the property; if property was subject to his execution, he was entitled to judgment. Combs v. Wallace, 11 Ky. Op. 338, 3 Ky. L. Rptr. 384, 1881 Ky. LEXIS 316 (Ky. Ct. App. Nov. 19, 1881).

 Where a distress issued for rent in arrears, and levied upon personal property of the tenants, and sale was suspended upon the execution by the tenants of a bond and answered, setting up certain defenses, the issues might be determined by the court, upon a motion with proper notice, for judgment upon the bond. Scott Bros. v. Flood's Trustee, 124 Ky. 739, 99 S.W. 967, 30 Ky. L. Rptr. 955, 1907 Ky. LEXIS 234 (Ky. 1907).

  2. — Notice to Surety. 

 Where a surety was not notified of a motion for judgment  by notice on a claimant’s bond in execution proceedings, the judgment against  the surety was erroneous. Butcher v. Corbin Hardware & Furniture Co., 244 Ky. 632, 51 S.W.2d 931, 1932 Ky. LEXIS 486 (Ky. 1932).

  3. — Jury. 

 Even though it was error for the court to refuse to empanel a jury, the error was not prejudicial where, in any case, the evidence indicated that a directed verdict for the appellee would have been given to the jury. Olney Trust & Banking Co. v. Vickers, 309 Ky. 657, 218 S.W.2d 684, 1949 Ky. LEXIS 789 (Ky. 1949).

  4. — Pleadings. 

 It is within the discretion of the court to permit a defendant surety in a claimant’s bond to file an answer to a motion for judgment upon the bond, since such motion may be heard upon written pleadings or without them. Couchman's Adm'r v. Maupin, 78 Ky. 33, 1879 Ky. LEXIS 53 (Ky. 1879).

 In a summary proceeding on a claimant’s bond, the question of whether the pleadings shall be in writing or not is within the discretion of the court. Borches v. Bellis, 110 Ky. 620, 62 S.W. 486, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 37, 1901 Ky. LEXIS 115 (Ky. 1901).

 In a proceeding on a claimant’s bond by motion for judgment against the claimant and her sureties, a plea of payment by the execution defendant should have been heard by the court. Butcher v. Corbin Hardware & Furniture Co., 244 Ky. 632, 51 S.W.2d 931, 1932 Ky. LEXIS 486 (Ky. 1932).

 The rule requiring pleading of questions of fraud or any other contested issues does not apply to proceedings under this section. Southern Coal & Coke Co. v. Bracht, 267 Ky. 123, 101 S.W.2d 667, 1937 Ky. LEXIS 287 (Ky. 1937).

  5. — Burden of Proof. 

 Where a claimant of property secured a release of a levy by the execution of a bond and the one having the execution levied had made motion for judgment against claimant and his sureties, the court had the discretion to decide who should bear the burden of proof, but when the plaintiff had proven the sheriff had found property in defendant’s possession, a prima facie case was made out for plaintiff and the court should have permitted the jury to weigh the evidence. Borches v. Bellis, 110 Ky. 620, 62 S.W. 486, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 37, 1901 Ky. LEXIS 115 (Ky. 1901).

 Where execution issued upon a judgment and levied upon merchandise as the property of the execution defendants, and the claimant of the property, before sale by sheriff, executed a claimant’s bond, and the sheriff surrendered to him the property and returned the bond, the court determined that in a trial of a motion for judgment against the claimants and his sureties on the bond, the burden of proof was on the claimant to show title to the property. Borches v. Bellis, 110 Ky. 620, 62 S.W. 486, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 37, 1901 Ky. LEXIS 115 (Ky. 1901).

  6. — Damages. 

 On motion for a judgment on a bond suspending a sale of property levied on to satisfy an execution, a judgment ordering the payment of damages by reference to the bond, without ascertaining and fixing the amount to be recovered, is erroneous. Smith v. Wells' Adm'x, 67 Ky. 92, 1868 Ky. LEXIS 86 (Ky. 1868) (decided under prior law).

  Cited: 

 Hauns v. Central Kentucky Lunatic Asylum, 103 Ky. 562, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 246, 45 S.W. 890, 1898 Ky. LEXIS 104 (Ky. 1898).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Cross-References. 

Summary proceedings, KRS 418.005 to 418.015.

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Notice of a Motion Against Obligors in a Claimant’s Bond, Given to Suspend a Sale Under an Execution, Form 151.20.


426.660.  Trial of objection to appraisement.

Text

Upon the trial of the motion, either party may object that the property was not fairly appraised; and, thereupon, the jury trying the facts shall hear evidence respecting, and find, the value of the property.

History

History.
C.C. 649: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953.

Annotations

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Appraisement of Personal Property Before Taking Claimant’s Bond, Form 151.18.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Notice of a Motion Against Obligors in a Claimant’s Bond, Given to Suspend a Sale Under an Execution, Form 151.20.


426.665.  Bond not to discharge levy — Motion to discharge.

Text

The giving of the bond mentioned in KRS 426.640 shall not discharge the levy of the execution upon the property claimed. But the officer may leave it, subject to the lien of the levy, with the person in whose possession it was found, pending the proceeding on the bond; and may, in the meantime, proceed with the execution against any other property of the defendant. The obligor in such bond may, however, on ten (10) days’ notice to the plaintiff in the execution, move the court to which the bond is returned to discharge the same and release the levy under the execution. The provisions of KRS 426.655 and 426.660 shall, so far as applicable, govern the proceedings upon such motion.

History

History.
C.C. 650: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Discharge of Levy.

2. Levy on Other Property.

  1. Discharge of Levy. 

 The levy of an execution will not be discharged on motion upon the ground that the property of a corporation performing a function of government was not liable to the levy. Hauns v. Central Kentucky Lunatic Asylum, 103 Ky. 562, 45 S.W. 890, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 246, 1898 Ky. LEXIS 104 (Ky. 1898).

  2. Levy on Other Property. 

 Where the defendants in an execution suspended the sale of the property by executing a claimant’s bond, the execution of the bond did not prevent the sheriff from proceeding against other property of the defendants. Southern Bank Ky. v. White & McMahan, 62 Ky. 290, 1864 Ky. LEXIS 64 (Ky. 1864) (decided under prior law).

  Cited: 

 Olney Trust & Banking Co. v. Vickers, 309 Ky. 657, 218 S.W.2d 684, 1949 Ky. LEXIS 789 (Ky. 1949).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Claimant’s Bond to Suspend Sale Under an Execution, Form 151.16.


426.670.  Provisions governing executions from quarterly or justices’ courts. [Repealed.]

Annotations

 Compiler’s Notes. 

 This section (C.C. 651: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1; 1976, ch. 91, § 43) was repealed by Acts 1976 (Ex. Sess.), ch. 14, § 491, effective January 2, 1978.


426.675.  Certain jury trials of right of property abolished.

Text

Trials by juries summoned by sheriffs or other officers, of the right of property taken by them under execution or rent attachment, are abolished.

History

History.
C.C. 659: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1; 1976, ch. 91, § 44.

Annotations

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Cross-References. 

Rent, proceedings for recovery of, KRS 383.010 to 383.090.


426.680.  Procedure for levy of execution on jointly owned property.

Text

If an officer levy an execution upon personal property held by the execution debtor jointly with another person:

  (1) The officer shall not deprive such person, without his consent in writing, of the possession of the property, except for the purpose of having it inventoried and appraised, which he shall cause to be done pursuant to the provisions of KRS 426.645;

  (2) The officer shall return the inventory and appraisement, with the execution, to the office from which it issued; and shall state in his return the facts connected with the levy, and the claim of the joint owner;

  (3) The execution creditor shall have a lien upon the property levied on, such as is given by law to an execution in the hands of an officer; and upon the aforesaid return, the creditor may enforce said lien by an action in equity;

  (4) If such creditor, at the commencement of his action or afterward, shall file an affidavit that he verily believes the property levied upon will be removed from the county or sold or otherwise disposed of with intent fraudulently to defeat his lien, the court, or the District Court if no Circuit Judge is available, may make an order directing the officer to possess himself of the property so levied upon, unless bond, with approved security, shall be executed to the plaintiff in the execution, binding the obligors in said bond to have the same forthcoming in obedience to any order or judgment of the court in the action; which bond shall be taken by the officer and returned by him to the court in which the action is pending.

History

History.
C.C. 660: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953; 1976 (Ex. Sess.), ch. 14, § 436, effective January 2, 1978.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Determination of Ownership.

2. Right to Possession.

3. Lack of Appraisement.

4. Jointly Owned Property.

  1. Determination of Ownership. 

 In an action brought for the enforcement of an execution lien against one undivided one-half interest in 350 barrels of corn owned in partnership, in which claimant was made a party to the proceedings on her own petition, the ownership of the property is a question of fact and can only be determined by the evidence. Humphrey v. Brown's Adm'rs, 62 S.W. 1131, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 26 (1901).

 Where a husband transferred, without recordation, to his wife an undivided one-half interest in property jointly owned with a third party in satisfaction of a debt he owed to his wife, which was secured by a recorded mortgage on the property, the property was subject to levy of execution by a judgment creditor of the husband. Farmers' State Bank v. Evans, 258 Ky. 660, 80 S.W.2d 830, 1935 Ky. LEXIS 219 (Ky. 1935).

  2. Right to Possession. 

 Where an officer levies the execution on the timber of a joint owner, he cannot sell the property or deprive the owner, without his consent, of the possession; he can only have it appraised and return the execution and appraisement, and then the execution creditor may enforce his lien by action in equity. Dils v. Hatcher, 69 S.W. 1092, 24 Ky. L. Rptr. 826, 1902 Ky. App. LEXIS 5 (Ky. Ct. App. 1902).

  3. Lack of Appraisement. 

 Where an execution against one having a joint interest in a crop of tobacco was placed in the hands of a constable who made a levy and indorsed the same on the execution, the fact that he failed to appraise and inventory the property did not prevent the existence of an execution lien. Richart v. Goodpaster, 116 Ky. 637, 76 S.W. 831, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 889, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 240 (Ky. 1903).

  4. Jointly Owned Property. 

 When a sale of cattle, upon which an execution is levied, has been suspended by persons not defendants in the execution and it is shown the property is partnership property, a settlement of the partnership should be made and only the interest of the partner obligated should be subjected. Williams v. Smith, 67 Ky. 540, 1868 Ky. LEXIS 187 (Ky. 1868) (decided under prior law).


426.685.  Provisions governing sales by court order of indivisible real property.

Text

(1) Before ordering a sale of real property for the payment of debt, the court must be satisfied by the pleadings, by an agreement of the parties, by affidavits filed, or by a report of a commissioner or commissioners, whether or not the property can be divided without materially impairing its value, and may cause it to be divided, with suitable avenues, streets, lanes or alleys, or without any of them.

(2) If it be necessary to sell, for the payment of debt, a parcel of real property which cannot be divided without materially impairing its value, the officer shall sell the whole of it, though it bring more than the sum to be raised, and the court shall make proper orders for the distribution of the proceeds.

History

History.
C.C. 694(1), (2): amend. Acts 1916, ch. 105; trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Sale of Land.

  2. — Pleadings.

  3. — — Allegations.

  4. — Parties.

  5. — Improper Sale of Divisible Land.

  6. — — Owner Not Harmed.

  7. — — Consent of Owner.

  8. — — Indivisible Property.

  1. Sale of Land. 

 This section must be read in connection with KRS 426.006, 426.010, 426.130, 426.190, 426.430, 426.520, 426.560, 426.695, 426.715, and 451.180. Pineville Steam Laundry v. Phillips, 254 Ky. 391, 71 S.W.2d 980, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 93 (Ky. 1934).

  2. — Pleadings. 

 In an action to foreclose a lien, the court may determine from the pleadings whether the property is readily divisible. Burge v. Chestnut, 121 S.W. 989 (Ky. 1909).

 Where the pleadings in an action to enforce liens not only showed that the property was residence property but alleged that it could not be divided without impairing its value, and the allegation was not denied, and none of the parties were infants, the chancellor was justified in adjudging the property indivisible, since the court could determine that question from the pleadings of the case. Salyer v. Union Bank, 149 Ky. 847, 150 S.W. 14, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 731 (Ky. 1912).

 Where the description of the property sought to be subjected to a purchase money lien, as given in the petition, does not show whether or not the property is divisible, the better practice is to state the facts relative to that question in the petition. Baird v. Prewitt, 158 Ky. 793, 166 S.W. 771, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 726 (Ky. 1914).

  3. — — Allegations. 

 An allegation that the land is divisible, or indivisible, is not required to be made by the pleadings, in an action to foreclose a vendor’s lien. If the court is satisfied, from the character of the boundary, or the number of acres in the tract, as described in the pleadings, that a division can be had, it is all that is required. Sears v. Henry, 76 Ky. 413, 1877 Ky. LEXIS 78 (Ky. 1877).

 Where the petition gives such a description of the land sought to be subjected that the court may, from the description given, determine whether or not the land is susceptible of advantageous division, the allegation in that regard need not be made. Cockrill v. Mize, 12 S.W. 1040, 11 Ky. L. Rptr. 637 (1890).

 The petition need not expressly aver whether the property is, or is not, divisible, as this may appear by the description of the property in the pleading. Lucy v. Hopkins, 13 S.W. 518, 11 Ky. L. Rptr. 907 (1890).

 In an action to enforce a lien against property, it is not necessary to allege that the property is indivisible and the court may order sale of part of the tract where it is satisfied from the character of the boundaries or the number of acres that a division may be made; therefore, in the absence of allegation or proof, the court was authorized to find that a 34 1/2-acre tract was divisible. Mays v. Carman, 66 S.W. 1019, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 2216, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 536 (Ky. Ct. App. 1902).

 It is not necessary to allege in the pleadings in an action to enforce a tax lien that the property was divisible or indivisible. Will v. Louisville, 176 Ky. 450, 195 S.W. 822, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 68 (Ky. 1917).

  4. — Parties. 

 In an action to foreclose a lien, the subsequent purchaser of a portion of the land was a necessary party where the land was divisible and he was entitled to have the other portion of the land first subjected to the lien. Miller v. Brown, 203 Ky. 241, 262 S.W. 16, 1924 Ky. LEXIS 886 (Ky. 1924).

  5. — Improper Sale of Divisible Land. 

 Where it was evident that the land could have been divided and there was no evidence upon which to base the conclusion that a division was impracticable, and the debtor had been prejudiced by the order of the court directing a sale of the entire tract, it was the duty of the court, upon exceptions filed to the commissioner’s report, to set aside the sale, although made in strict conformity to the judgment, as the court, notwithstanding the judgment, had complete control over the mere manner of conducting the sale until the report of sale had been confirmed. Vanmeter v. Vanmeter's Assignee, 88 Ky. 448, 11 S.W. 80, 10 Ky. L. Rptr. 906, 1889 Ky. LEXIS 37 (Ky. 1889).

 In an action for the sale of real property, where there is no allegation in the pleadings with reference to the divisibility of the property and no issue made with reference to that question, but the court determines the question as to divisibility, and it appears upon exceptions to the report of sale that the land was divisible without material impairment of its value and was erroneously ordered sold as a whole, and the error has resulted in the land being sold for a grossly inadequate price, it is the duty of the court to set aside the sale and correct the error, although the sale has been made in conformity with the order of sale. Harris v. Louisville Trust Co., 181 Ky. 659, 205 S.W. 772, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 594 (Ky. 1918).

 Where there was no allegation in the petition, and no evidence in any form, that the real estate on which a materialman’s lien had attached could not be divided without materially impairing its value, and by the judgment the chancellor adjudged a sale of only enough of the property to satisfy the debt, amounting to $965, but under that judgment the commissioner sold the entire tract, which brought $3,300, such sale was not authorized. Dallas v. Gardner, 207 Ky. 93, 268 S.W. 847, 1925 Ky. LEXIS 23 (Ky. 1925).

 Where the judgment expressly limited the authority of the commissioner to sell only enough of the mortgaged land to satisfy the debt and there was nothing to show that the land could not be divided without materially affecting its value, but the commissioner sold the entire tract of land which brought several hundred dollars in excess of the amount of the debt, the chancellor erred in overruling the defendant’s exceptions to the report of sale. Rhinehart v. Stacy, 213 Ky. 684, 281 S.W. 809, 1926 Ky. LEXIS 594 (Ky. 1926).

 Where a commissioner was ordered to sell real estate to satisfy a judgment, there was no showing that the real estate was indivisible, and all of the real estate was sold for an amount greater than the total of the judgment, interest, and costs, the sale was irregular. Barnett v. Bank of Commerce, 264 Ky. 179, 94 S.W.2d 334, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 289 (Ky. 1936).

  6. — — Owner Not Harmed. 

 In an action to subject real property to the payment of debt, the court must be satisfied as to whether or not the property can be divided without materially impairing its value, but where it does not affirmatively appear in the record that the court passed upon the question in ordering sale of a large number of platted lots in bulk, it was error, but did not render the judgment void; since the lots did not bring enough to pay plaintiff’s debt, interest, and costs, it may be presumed that the owner lost nothing by the error. Audas v. Highland Land & Bldg. Co., 205 F. 862, 1913 U.S. App. LEXIS 1503 (6th Cir. Ky. 1913).

  7. — — Consent of Owner. 

 Where the order of sale might appropriately have directed a sale of a sufficiency of the defendant’s three (3) lots to satisfy a mortgage debt rather than the whole of the property, as such property was divisible and had an appraised value much greater than the debt, and the property when sold as a whole brought less than one half (1/2) of its appraised value, but the defendant agreed both to the sale of the property as a whole and to its purchase by the plaintiff at less than two thirds (2/3) of its appraised value, the defendant was not in position to complain of the sale after its confirmation. Moore v. Waltman's Adm'x, 288 Ky. 258, 156 S.W.2d 100, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 90 (Ky. 1941).

  8. — — Indivisible Property. 

 Where it is sought to sell land in satisfaction of a junior mortgage lien which has matured, when a senior mortgage lien owned by a different person, which has not matured, exists upon the land, although the land may be divisible, a sale of no part of it could be had free from encumbrance without prejudice to the prior lienhold because it would be impossible to foretell how much of the encumbered lands would be necessary to satisfy the prior lien at its maturity. Fisher v. Evans, 175 Ky. 300, 194 S.W. 361, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 333 (Ky. 1917).

 Where the plaintiff, in an action to enforce a lien on land, alleges that the property cannot be divided without material impairment of its value, and the defendant fails to defend the action or to deny the indivisibility of the property, and the court adjudges that the land is indivisible in the order of sale and directs it sold as a whole, the defendant, after the sale, cannot except to the sale on the ground that the court erred in ordering the land sold as a whole and that it ought to have been divided before the sale. Harris v. Louisville Trust Co., 181 Ky. 659, 205 S.W. 772, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 594 (Ky. 1918).

 In a suit by the creditors of a defunct bank, who had obtained a judgment against the father and other directors of the bank, for a cancellation of a deed between the father and son and to have the land subjected to the payment of the judgment against the father, where the petition contained an averment that the land was indivisible property and the averment was not controverted by the defendants, the court was entirely warranted in adjudging the property sold as indivisible property. Hamilton v. Cunningham, 186 Ky. 570, 217 S.W. 924, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 15 (Ky. 1920).

  Cited: 

 Underwood’s Adm’r v. Cartwright, 47 S.W. 580, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 809 (1898); Foley v. Graham’s Guardian, 110 S.W. 838, 33 Ky. L. Rptr. 627 (1908).

 Opinions of Attorney General. 

 An ordinance authorizing garagemen to sell vehicles delivered to their possession by the employes of the city of Louisville for traffic violations was invalid and void. OAG 61-916.

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Cross-References. 

Summary proceedings, KRS 418.005 to 418.015.

  Northern Kentucky Law Review. 

2010 General Law Issue: Note: We Don’t Live Here Anymore: A Critical Analysis of Government Responses to the Foreclosure Crisis, 37 N. Ky. L. Rev. 121 (2010).

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th ed., Complaint to Enforce Mortgage Lien Due to Default on Payment, Form 301.01.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th ed., Practice Content for Enforcement of Mortgage Liens, § 301.00.


426.690.  Procedure in action to enforce lien where other liens exist against real property.

Text

The plaintiff in an action to enforce a lien on real property shall state in his petition the liens, if any, which are held thereon by others, and make the holders defendants; and no sale of the property shall be ordered by the court prejudicial to the rights of the holders of any of the liens, and when it appears from the petition or otherwise, that several debts are secured by one (1) lien, or by liens of equal rank, and they are all due at the commencement of the action, or become so before judgment, the court shall order the sale for the pro rata satisfaction of all of them, but if, in such case, the debts be owned by different persons and be not all due, the court shall not order a sale of the property until they all mature. If all such liens be held by the same party, the court may order a sale of enough of the property to pay the debts then due, unless it appear that it is not susceptible of advantageous division, or that, for some other reason, the sale would cause a sacrifice thereof, or seriously prejudice the interests of the defendants, but the holder of a prior lien may enforce the same when the debt thereby secured is due, notwithstanding the existence of inferior liens, whether the debts secured thereby are due or not; and the holder of an inferior lien, when the debt thereby secured is due, may enforce the same by a sale of land subject to a prior lien or liens thereon, where the debt or debts secured thereby are not yet due. Provided, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any liens now of record.

History

History.
C.C. 694(3): amend. Acts 1916, ch. 105; trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Application.

2. Enforcement of Liens.

  3. —Tax Liens.

  4. —Prior Lien.

  5. —Inferior Lien.

  6. —Contested Lien.

  7. —Improvement Lien.

  8. —Indivisible Property.

  9. —Unmatured Debts.

  10. —Parties.

  1. Application. 

 This section does not apply to suits to settle estates. Callebs v. Ruble, 172 Ky. 113, 188 S.W. 1096, 1916 Ky. LEXIS 167 (Ky. 1916).

  2. Enforcement of Liens. 

 In an action to foreclose a vendor’s lien securing two notes, both owned by the plaintiff, one of which was not due, instead of ordering a sale of all or part of the land to satisfy a part only of the plaintiff’s debts, reserving a lien and consequent encumbrance on the land in his favor for the residue of the indebtedness, the court should have simply directed a sale of enough of the land to pay the debts and costs then adjudged, leaving the remaining note to its lien on the remaining portion of the land. Emison v. Risque, 72 Ky. 24, 1872 Ky. LEXIS 6 (Ky. 1872) (decided under prior law).

 In an action to enforce a lien for purchase money upon a tract of land, where there are no other liens known to the plaintiff, the better practice is to state that fact in the petition. Baird v. Prewitt, 158 Ky. 793, 166 S.W. 771, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 726 (Ky. 1914).

 Where plaintiff recovered judgment, had its attachment and levy sustained, and then took no action for three (3) years when it brought a new action to determine the rights of the judgment debtor’s transferee and the priority between its lien and a lien executed after the judgment, the court properly dismissed the action, because this question should have been submitted to the court through amendments of the pleadings in the original action. C. I. T. Corp. v. House, 258 Ky. 86, 79 S.W.2d 392, 1935 Ky. LEXIS 116 (Ky. 1935).

  3. —Tax Liens. 

 In an action to enforce a lien for taxes, a claim of a lien for additional taxes for a subsequent year on the same land was properly set up by amended petition. Board of Councilmen v. Herndon's Adm'r, 133 Ky. 583, 118 S.W. 347, 1909 Ky. LEXIS 200 (Ky. 1909).

 Where the original action by city for the recovery of taxes was brought prior to the time when taxes for the current year were collectible by suit, it was proper for the city to file a supplemental petition setting out taxes accruing after the filing of the original petition and asking that its lien be enforced. Thornton's Unknown Heirs v. Dayton, 216 Ky. 543, 288 S.W. 310, 1926 Ky. LEXIS 967 (Ky. 1926).

  4. —Prior Lien. 

 Under this section it was not error to order a sale of a sufficiency of land to pay a matured prior lien claim thereon before the maturity of notes secured by an inferior lien on the land. Durham v. Elliott, 180 Ky. 724, 203 S.W. 539, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 126 (Ky. 1918).

 In an action by the holder of mortgage note and tax bills to collect them and to foreclose lien securing them, it was not erroneous for the trial court to order a sale of the encumbered property before passing on the validity of inferior liens whose owners filed their answers after the case had been submitted to judgment. Cox v. Stamper, 221 Ky. 745, 299 S.W. 723, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 811 (Ky. 1927).

  5. —Inferior Lien. 

 Where a prior mortgage lien and a junior mortgage lien exist upon the same tract of land and are owned by different persons, and the junior lien has matured, a sale of the land or a sufficiency of it, subject to the prior lien, may be adjudged to satisfy the junior lien, although the prior lien has not matured. Fisher v. Evans, 175 Ky. 300, 194 S.W. 361, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 333 (Ky. 1917).

 A valid sale may be made to satisfy a junior lien which is due, although a prior lien thereon is not, if the liens are held by different persons and the sale is subject to the liens. Fisher v. Maxwell Inv. Co., 206 Ky. 24, 266 S.W. 902, 1924 Ky. LEXIS 272 (Ky. 1924).

 Where real estate is sold to enforce a junior lien, the thing that is sold is the debtor’s equity in the realty, subject to the prior lien; the property must be appraised as a whole and the purchaser, in order to cut off the debtor’s right of redemption and obtain a deed, must bid at least two thirds of the value of the debtor’s equity as computed by deducting the amount of the prior lien from the total appraised value. Hardwick v. Fitzpatrick, 279 Ky. 53, 129 S.W.2d 1006, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 232 (Ky. 1939).

 Trial court improperly confirmed a judicial sale without making it subject to a senior mortgage because, while an assignee and its predecessor failed to bring their claim in the foreclosure proceedings initiated by a junior mortgagee and therefore had a default judgment entered against them, the assignee’s presentation of its claim prior to the judicial sale was sufficient to prevent its senior mortgage from being extinguished by the junior mortgagee’s foreclosure action.  Mortg. Elec. Registration Sys. v. MainSource Bank, 425 S.W.3d 892, 2014 Ky. App. LEXIS 32 (Ky. Ct. App. 2014).

  6. —Contested Lien. 

 Where a lien note is contested, a judgment to sell so much of the land as will be necessary to pay the uncontested part of the note is erroneous unless the plaintiff waived his lien as to the uncontested part of the note. Sears v. Henry, 76 Ky. 413, 1877 Ky. LEXIS 78 (Ky. 1877). See Breckinridge v. Peebles' Adm'r, 38 S.W. 871, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 510 (1897).

 Where one party to an action held a mortgage lien on a stock of merchandise and upon three tracts of land for three notes aggregating about $950, of which all except $676.78 was controverted, and another party held a lien on one of the tracts for $150, it was error for the court to order a sale of the land until after the trial of the issue controverting a portion of the lien debt, since it did not appear from the pleadings that enough of the land could be sold at that time to pay the uncontroverted claim without impairing the value of the remainder by causing a sacrifice thereof. Rowlett v. Harris, 121 Ky. 811, 90 S.W. 562, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 780, 1906 Ky. LEXIS 264 (Ky. 1906).

  7. —Improvement Lien. 

 Where an act of the legislature authorized street improvements to be made at the cost of abutting property owners, such costs to be a lien on the abutting property and to be paid in instalments, an action could be brought on overdue instalments without waiting until all fell due. District of Clifton v. Schneider, 106 Ky. 605, 51 S.W. 13, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 212, 1899 Ky. LEXIS 76 (Ky. 1899).

  8. —Indivisible Property. 

 In an action to enforce a vendor’s lien when some of the purchase money notes are not due, if it appears that the land is not susceptible of advantageous division, the court should not order a sale of it, or any part of it, until the maturity of all notes, although all are held by the same person. Leopold v. Furber, 84 Ky. 214, 1 S.W. 404, 8 Ky. L. Rptr. 198, 1886 Ky. LEXIS 57 (Ky. 1886).

 Where land is subject to several mortgages and the first mortgage was due last, the indivisible property should not be sold until the first mortgage matures. Hendrick v. Robert Mitchell Furniture Co., 29 S.W. 750, 16 Ky. L. Rptr. 769 (1895).

 In an action to enforce a vendor’s lien held by one person to secure several debts, it will be presumed that a house and lot in a city or town are not susceptible of advantageous division. Melton v. Brown, 47 S.W. 764, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 882 (1898).

 Where there are two (2) or more liens on property which cannot be divided without materially impairing its value, it is error to sell the property before all the liens mature, and if all the lien debts are due, it is error, in a proceeding to enforce one of the liens, to order a sale of the property subject to the other liens, but in that event the property should be sold as a whole. Salyer v. Union Bank, 149 Ky. 847, 150 S.W. 14, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 731 (Ky. 1912).

 It was error to order a sale of indivisible property before all the notes were due, although they were all held by the same person. Gray v. Grimm, 157 Ky. 603, 163 S.W. 762, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 341 (Ky. 1914).

 In an action to enforce a lien of encumbered real property, it was error for the chancellor to order a sale of the property, which was indivisible, and when some of the lien notes were not due. Roemer v. Mottley, 164 Ky. 313, 175 S.W. 645, 1915 Ky. LEXIS 381 (Ky. 1915).

  9. —Unmatured Debts. 

 The sale of land for the payment of a debt was void where two (2) of the notes executed for the purchase price had not yet matured. Gunn v. Orndorff, 67 S.W. 372, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 2369, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 344 (Ky. Ct. App. 1902).

 A sale of a 50-acre tract to satisfy three (3) of four (4) notes which had matured and were all held by the plaintiff should not be refused merely because of an assertion that the tract is of limited acreage and little value, where there was no evidence that the tract could not be advantageously divided. Haven v. Daugherty's Adm'r, 79 S.W. 191, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 1852 (1904).

 Where a judgment enforcing a vendor’s lien and an inferior lien and ordering the land sold to satisfy the liens specifically recited that the land could not be divided without materially impairing its value, provided that bonds taken for the unpaid purchase price should have the force and effect of a judgment, and that a lien should exist on the property and be retained by the master commissioner as a security for the purchase money bonds, a sale of the land under execution on two of the bonds before the third one was due was premature. Campbell v. Opatich, 240 Ky. 442, 42 S.W.2d 525, 1931 Ky. LEXIS 413 (Ky. 1931).

  10. —Parties. 

 The Commonwealth of Kentucky, as the holder of a lien on land created by the levy of an execution, was entitled to be made a defendant to an action to enforce a prior mortgage lien upon the land and, where it was not made a defendant, it was entitled to have the sale made in the action set aside in order that there might be a resale and the Commonwealth’s claim presented. Commonwealth v. Robinson, 96 Ky. 553, 29 S.W. 306, 16 Ky. L. Rptr. 558, 1895 Ky. LEXIS 102 (Ky. 1895).

 Where a bank had made a loan and the principal had executed a mortgage to his surety to indemnify him and as security for a separate loan from the surety, the bank’s judgment for sale of the principal’s mortgaged land was improper where the representatives of the deceased surety were not made parties to the action. Guill's Adm'rs v. Corinth Deposit Bank, 68 S.W. 870, 24 Ky. L. Rptr. 482, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 466 (Ky. Ct. App. 1902).

 A sale of land to enforce a lien for the purchase price was not proper where the mortgagees of the purchasers were not made parties to the action. Leonard v. Welch, 76 S.W. 338, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 692 (1903).

 It was erroneous to order a sale of real estate without bringing all lienholders before the court. Pearson v. Pearson, 166 Ky. 91, 178 S.W. 1164, 1915 Ky. LEXIS 637 (Ky. 1915).

 The failure to make a lienholder a party to an action to enforce another lien, and to bring him before the court, is a reversible error and the question may be raised by exceptions to the report of the sale. Fisher v. Evans, 175 Ky. 300, 194 S.W. 361, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 333 (Ky. 1917).

 In an action by the holder of an inferior lien, where the holder of the prior lien was not before the court, a judgment ordering sale of the property to satisfy both liens was erroneous. Walden v. Hacker & Marcum, 244 Ky. 527, 51 S.W.2d 667, 1932 Ky. LEXIS 467 (Ky. 1932).

 When it developed, in an action to set aside deeds and ordering land sold, that there were outstanding liens on the property, the court should have required these lienholders to be made parties before ordering a sale in order that their rights might be protected, and the judgment was erroneous to the extent that it ignored their rights. Williams v. Word's Adm'x, 291 Ky. 101, 163 S.W.2d 41, 1942 Ky. LEXIS 176 (Ky. 1942).

 Where the record showed a transfer of a lien to a third party, in the absence of actual knowledge that such transfer was merely a pledge of collateral, foreclosing parties had a right to rely upon the record and to make only the holder of the lien upon the record a party defendant under this section. Jones v. Chipps, 296 Ky. 245, 176 S.W.2d 408, 1943 Ky. LEXIS 140 (Ky. 1943).

 This section does require that, in a suit to enforce a lien against real property, all known claims shall be set out in the petition and the claimants shall be made parties to the action. Midland-Guardian Co. v. McElroy, 563 S.W.2d 752, 1978 Ky. App. LEXIS 490 (Ky. Ct. App. 1978).

 The interest of a pendente lite lienholder in real property does not survive the judicial sale of the property incident to a foreclosure action to which the lienholder was neither a party nor had actual notice of the proceedings. While this section clearly requires the plaintiff in a foreclosure action to name the holders of other liens in its petition, there is no statutory requirement to name those who acquire a lien after the filing of the petition. Cumberland Lumber Co. v. First & Farmers Bank, Inc., 838 S.W.2d 403, 1992 Ky. App. LEXIS 90 (Ky. Ct. App. 1992).

 KRS 426.690 requires only lien holders at the time of the filing of the foreclosure petition to be named as parties; pursuant to KRS 382.440 and case law, the filing of a foreclosure petition alone is insufficient to bind pendente lite lien filers to the judgment. U.S. Bank, NA v. Hasty, 232 S.W.3d 536, 2007 Ky. App. LEXIS 284 (Ky. Ct. App. 2007).

  Cited in: 

 Barry v. Baker, 93 S.W. 1061, 29 Ky. L. Rptr. 573 (1906); Federal Land Bank v. Allender’s Adm’r, 289 Ky. 565, 159 S.W.2d 1, 1942 Ky. LEXIS 572 (Ky. 1942); Kentucky State Bank v. AG Services, Inc., 663 S.W.2d 754, 1984 Ky. App. LEXIS 447 (Ky. Ct. App. 1984); KeyBank N.A. v. Allen, 499 S.W.3d 693, 2016 Ky. App. LEXIS 144 (Ky. Ct. App. 2016).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Practice Context for Enforcement of Mortgage Liens, §  301.00.


426.695.  Sale of indivisible personal property — Payment of excess — Proceeds.

Text

If it be necessary to sell, for payment of debt, one or more parcels of personal property which, in the opinion of the officer making the sale, cannot be divided without materially impairing the value thereof, he shall sell the whole property, though it bring more than the sum to be raised; but he shall have no commission on the excess. The excess shall be paid to the defendant, or the bond therefor shall be payable to him.

History

History.
C.C. 695: trans Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  1. Indivisible Personalty. 

 In an action by a mortgagor for possession of an automobile repossessed by the mortgagee, the court should have adjudged the entire case and ordered the automobile sold to satisfy the mortgagee’s claim. Cartwright v. C. I. T. Corp., 253 Ky. 690, 70 S.W.2d 388, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 729 (Ky. 1934).

 Opinions of Attorney General. 

 An ordinance authorizing garagemen to sell vehicles delivered to their possession by the employes of the city of Louisville for traffic violations was invalid and void. OAG 61-916.


426.700.  Time, place and terms of sale — Notice.

Text

Every sale made under an order of court must be public, either for cash or upon reasonable credits to be fixed by the court; and shall be made after such notice of the time, place and terms of sale as the order may direct; and, unless the order direct otherwise, shall be made at the door of the courthouse of the county in which the property, or the greater part thereof, may be situated; and the notice of sale must state for what sum of money it is to be made.

History

History.
C.C. 696: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1; amend. Acts 1970, ch. 178, § 1.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Application.

2. Judgment.

3. Place.

4. Description of Property.

5. Deposit.

6. Down Payment.

7. Cash Requirement.

8. Credit Terms.

9. Notice of Amount.

10. Errors in Advertising.

11. Inadequate Description.

12. Advertisement.

  13. — Posting of Notices.

  14. — Insufficient Compliance.

  1. Application. 

 A sale of dividend paying securities by a personal representative, after securing authority by a proper ex parte proceeding, is not a judicial sale in any sense, and thus, this section is not applicable to such sales. Barth v. Fidelity & Columbia Trust Co., 188 Ky. 788, 224 S.W. 351, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 353 (Ky. 1920).

 This section applies only to judicial sales and not to sales under execution. Mason v. Letcher Coal & Coke Co., 196 Ky. 629, 245 S.W. 130, 1922 Ky. LEXIS 550 (Ky. 1922).

 The provisions of KRS 426.200 as to sale of land on the first day of a court term do not apply to sales under this section and, therefore, a decree authorizing the master commissioner to select a day for the sale was not erroneous. Fisher v. Shanks, 210 Ky. 338, 275 S.W. 803, 1925 Ky. LEXIS 669 (Ky. 1925).

 Where executor acted under authority given him in the will and not under judgment, sale under this section was not necessary. Methodist Episcopal Church South v. McAdams, 263 Ky. 833, 94 S.W.2d 11, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 260 (Ky. 1936).

  2. Judgment. 

 Where the judgment ordering the sale of real estate directed the commissioner to sell on a credit of six (6) months and to take bond payable to himself but gave no direction as to the time and place of sale except to direct the commissioner to post notices of the time, place and terms of sale, as sheriffs are required to do before selling land under execution, it was sufficient. Barnes v. Jackson's Administrator, 85 Ky. 407, 3 S.W. 601, 9 Ky. L. Rptr. 33, 1887 Ky. LEXIS 59 (Ky. Ct. App. 1887).

 The judgment should be so explicit in regard to property ordered to be sold, as well as to the time, terms, and place of sale, so that the commissioner should not be required to look to any other paper or order for directions. Meyer v. Covington, 103 Ky. 546, 45 S.W. 769, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 239, 1898 Ky. LEXIS 92 (Ky. 1898). See Neff v. Covington Stone & Sand Co., 108 Ky. 457, 55 S.W. 697, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 4 (Ky. Ct. App. 1900).

 Where it does not appear from the record that there was any objection to the judgment designating the manner of the sale, nor that there was any sacrifice of property, it cannot be presumed that the court would disregard the plain provisions of this section as to credit, time and place in the sale of personal property. Hardin v. Bond, 56 S.W. 676, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 117 (1900).

 A judgment ordering a sale on foreclosure should direct upon what time or credit the land should be sold. Quigley v. Beam's Adm'r, 137 Ky. 325, 125 S.W. 727, 1910 Ky. LEXIS 575 (Ky. 1910).

 Judgments ordering real estate to be sold should be specific, and if they are uncertain to such an extent that they cannot be carried out without doubt as to the meaning, they are void. Alexander v. Hendricks, 201 Ky. 677, 258 S.W. 81, 1924 Ky. LEXIS 606 (Ky. 1924).

 Judgment was erroneous which did not describe the property or specify the terms or time of the sale or for what sum of money it was to be made. Piersall v. Piersall, 302 Ky. 486, 194 S.W.2d 627, 1946 Ky. LEXIS 660 (Ky. 1946).

 Had a judgment authorized the sale of land for cash, or on less than six (6) months’ credit, it would have been erroneous and reversible on appeal, unless it was clearly shown the error was not prejudicial. Miller v. Halsey, 327 S.W.2d 943, 1959 Ky. LEXIS 80 (Ky. 1959) (decision prior to 1970 amendment).

  3. Place. 

 Where it did not appear from the deed that the sale was not made at the courthouse door in the county where the land was situated or another place ordered by the court, the deed was not void. Smith v. Commonwealth Land & Lumber Co., 172 Ky. 607, 189 S.W. 912, 1916 Ky. LEXIS 253 (Ky. 1916).

  4. Description of Property. 

 Where the judgment of sale identified the real property to be sold as a “house and lot on Mulberry Street, in Lexington,” the description was insufficient. Faught v. Henry, 76 Ky. 471, 1877 Ky. LEXIS 124 (Ky. 1877).

 Where the land to be sold was described in metes and bounds, both in the petition and in the judgment, and the land was sufficiently identified to enable the commissioner to locate it and there was no showing that the defendant was prejudiced by the failure to give a fuller description, the judgment will not be disturbed for that reason. Posey v. Green, 78 Ky. 162, 1879 Ky. LEXIS 79 (Ky. 1879).

 Where the decree adjudging a sale of real estate to satisfy a lien described the property as “beginning at Pike street, on the east side of York street, in this city, running thence N. 2961/2 feet, more or less,” such description was insufficient. Meyer v. Covington, 103 Ky. 546, 45 S.W. 769, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 239, 1898 Ky. LEXIS 92 (Ky. 1898).

  5. Deposit. 

 Where the judgment of the court directed that a deposit of $200 be made by the purchaser, it constituted a harmless error, since there was no evidence that the interest of the owner was prejudiced by this requirement. Guest v. Foster, 159 Ky. 1, 166 S.W. 620, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 730 (Ky. 1914).

 Where the judgment ordered the sale of property to be made to the highest bidder for cash in hand, and further provided that any purchaser at the judicial sale should be required to make a deposit of $100, such judgment was not authorized by this section, but did not constitute reversible error. The Court of Appeals directed the lower court to correct the judgment. Young v. Fitch, 182 Ky. 29, 206 S.W. 29, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 318 (Ky. 1918), overruled,  Greene v. Stevenson, 295 Ky. 832, 175 S.W.2d 519, 1943 Ky. LEXIS 348 (Ky. 1943).

 Where the judgment ordering the sale of attached property directed that prospective purchasers would be required to deposit $100 with the special commissioner before the beginning of the sale, such judgment was erroneous and the sale should have been set aside on this ground, even though the commissioner making the sale ignored that part of the judgment and did not require a deposit. Kengreen Gas Utilities Corp. v. Crozer, 244 Ky. 440, 51 S.W.2d 262, 1932 Ky. LEXIS 447 (Ky. 1932).

  6. Down Payment. 

 Under this statute the court is without power to require the purchaser to pay one-fifth of the price on the day of sale, and this would be peculiarly prejudicial in the sale of large properties. Wakenva Coal Co. v. Johnson, 234 Ky. 558, 28 S.W.2d 737, 1930 Ky. LEXIS 219 (Ky. 1930).

  7. Cash Requirement. 

 Where property was sold for $10,000 more than the highest appraisal of it by admittedly competent appraisers, the fact that the court order for the sale required it to be for cash was not prejudicial and, therefore, not reversible error. Call v. Call, 367 S.W.2d 274, 1963 Ky. LEXIS 22 (Ky. 1963) (decision prior to 1970 amendment).

  8. Credit Terms. 

 It is reversible error to direct a sale of land on a credit of three (3) months. McKensie v. Sayler, 43 S.W. 450, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 1414 (1897) (decision prior to 1970 amendment).

  9. Notice of Amount. 

 Where the posted notices of sale omitted to fix the sum of money to be made by the sale and the defendant filed exceptions to the report of sale, the sale was invalid. Fink v. Herrick, 90 S.W. 268, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 763 (1906).

 Where the advertisement of the master commissioner in a sale made in a suit to settle the decedent’s estate failed to state the amount of money to be raised by the sale, the purchaser was not in position to have the sale set aside on that ground. Connell v. Harper, 202 Ky. 406, 259 S.W. 1017, 1924 Ky. LEXIS 727 (Ky. 1924).

 In an execution and sale of a leasehold, the officer could look to the previous default judgment to determine the amount of money to be raised by the sale and insert that amount in his advertisements of sale. Roberts v. Brown, 203 Ky. 11, 261 S.W. 614, 1924 Ky. LEXIS 833 (Ky. 1924).

  10. Errors in Advertising. 

 A notice of judicial sale which erroneously advertised the date of sale and made other errors in the advertisement could possibly be set aside by the trial court. Sizemore v. Bennett, 408 S.W.2d 449, 1966 Ky. LEXIS 108 (Ky. 1966).

 Errors in advertising judicial sale of land plus inadequacy of consideration were sufficient to invalidate sale. Sizemore v. Bennett, 408 S.W.2d 449, 1966 Ky. LEXIS 108 (Ky. 1966).

  11. Inadequate Description. 

 Where there was no description of the land, either in the petition or the judgment, from which the commissioner would be enabled to know what land he was directed to sell, the judgment was reversed. Runyon v. Darnall, 73 Ky. 67, 1873 Ky. LEXIS 54 (Ky. Ct. App. 1873) (decided under prior law).

  12. Advertisement. 

  13. — Posting of Notices. 

 Where the judgment directed posting of notices at the door of the courthouse and in the vicinity of the property to be sold, and also a publication in a newspaper, publication in a newspaper alone was not sufficient with the directions of the judgment. Carter v. Howard, 183 Ky. 356, 209 S.W. 51, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 480 (Ky. 1919).

 Unless contained in the order of the court, it is not necessary that notices of judicial sales be posted in addition to the newspaper advertisement, but where the order of sale requires posting, failure to do so is fatal to the sale. Miller v. Title Ins. & Trust Co., 278 Ky. 598, 129 S.W.2d 163, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 480 (Ky. 1939).

  14. — Insufficient Compliance. 

 Judicial sale of land was not sufficiently or properly advertised as required by KRS 426.700 and this section, where judgment directed publication in newspaper, posting on courthouse door and in vicinity of land, and posting was not done as required. Carter v. Howard, 183 Ky. 356, 209 S.W. 51, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 480 (Ky. 1919).

  Cited: 

 Luttrell v. Wells, 97 Ky. 84, 16 Ky. L. Rptr. 812, 30 S.W. 10, 1895 Ky. LEXIS 157 (Ky. 1895); Underwood’s Adm’r v. Cartwright, 47 S.W. 580, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 809 (1898); Scott v. Graves, 153 Ky. 221, 154 S.W. 1084, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 803 (Ky. 1913); Sedley v. Louisville Trust Co., 419 S.W.2d 531, 1967 Ky. LEXIS 151 (Ky. 1967).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th ed., Judgment and Order of Sale, Plaintiff is First Lien Holder, Form 301.07.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th ed., Practice Context for Enforcement of Mortgage Liens, § 301.00.


426.705.  Bond required of purchaser.

Text

(1) The purchaser of property sold under an order of court shall give bond for the price, with good surety, approved by the officer making the sale, payable to him or to the person entitled to receive the money, as the court may direct; or, if the court make no order on the subject, they shall be made payable to the officer.

(2) They shall bear interest from date at the rate the judgment bears.

(3) They shall have the force of judgments; and on executions issued upon them no replevy shall be allowed, and sales shall be for cash.

History

History.
C.C. 697: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  1. Sale Bonds. 

 Under this section a master commissioner may collect the money on a sale bond payable to himself and his sureties will be liable if he fails to pay the parties entitled to the money. Ison v. Commonwealth, 110 Ky. 112, 60 S.W. 1125, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 1588, 1901 Ky. LEXIS 61 (Ky. 1901).

 Where the executions were issued upon the sale bonds, executed by a debtor at a decretal sale and his surety, which had not been paid at maturity, the sale must be for cash. Mason v. Letcher Coal & Coke Co., 196 Ky. 629, 245 S.W. 130, 1922 Ky. LEXIS 550 (Ky. 1922).

  Cited: 

 Pineville Steam Laundry v. Phillips, 254 Ky. 391, 71 S.W.2d 980, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 93 (Ky. 1934); Flag Drilling Co. v. Erco, Inc., 156 S.W.3d 762, 2005 Ky. App. LEXIS 20 (Ky. Ct. App. 2005).

 Opinions of Attorney General. 

 The buyer of the real estate at a judicial sale is required to execute bond even when the buyer is also the first mortgagee. OAG 86-84.

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Bond of Purchaser of Property Sold by Order of Court, Form 151.14.


426.710.  Purchaser of personal property entitled to it.

Text

The purchaser of personal property sold under an order of court shall be entitled to it, upon complying with the terms of sale.

History

History.
C.C. 698: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953.


426.715.  Lien on realty as security for purchase money — Release.

Text

A lien shall exist on real property sold under an order of court, as security for the purchase money; and, upon payment thereof the clerk shall release the lien on the margin of the record of the deed in the office of the county clerk, or at the option of the county clerk, in a marginal entry record kept for the same purpose. Each entry in the marginal entry record shall be linked to its respective referenced instrument in the indexing system for the referenced instrument.

History

History.
C.C. 699: trans. Acts 1952, ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 1953; 1978, ch. 384, § 529, effective June 17, 1978; 1982, ch. 323, § 5, effective July 15, 1982.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  1. Extent of Insurable Interest. 

 Where the property sold at judicial sale was subsequently destroyed by fire, the mortgagee and the mortgagor had insurable interests in the property to the extent of their respective interests in the proceeds secured by the statutory lien. Kentucky Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Conley, 498 S.W.2d 122, 1973 Ky. LEXIS 284 (Ky. 1973).


426.720.  Final judgment to act as lien on realty — Judgment creditor’s notice requirements — Methods of service.

Text

(1) A final judgment for the recovery of money or costs in the courts of record in this Commonwealth, whether state or federal, shall act as a lien upon all real estate in which the judgment debtor has any ownership interest, in any county in which the following first shall be done:

  (a) The judgment creditor or his counsel shall file with the county clerk of any county a notice of judgment lien containing the court of record entering the judgment, the civil action number of the suit in which the judgment was entered, and the amount of the judgment, including principal, interest rate, court costs, and any attorney fees;

  (b) The county clerk shall enter the notice in the lis pendens records in that office, and shall so note the entry upon the original of the notice;

  (c) The judgment creditor or his counsel shall send to the last known address of the judgment debtor or the judgment debtor’s attorney of record, by regular first class mail, postage prepaid, or shall deliver to the debtor personally, a copy of the notice of judgment lien, which notice shall include the text of KRS 427.060 and also the following notice, or language substantially similar:

“Notice to Judgment Debtor. You may be entitled to an exemption under KRS 427.060, reprinted below. If you believe you are entitled to assert an exemption, seek legal advice.”; and

  (d) The judgment creditor or his counsel shall certify on the notice of judgment lien that a copy thereof has been mailed to the judgment debtor in compliance with paragraph (c) of this subsection.

(2) In any action involving real property which is subject to a judgment lien, service may be had upon the judgment creditor by serving the judgment creditor or the judgment creditor’s attorney as shown in the notice of judgment lien.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1988, ch. 318, § 1, effective July 15, 1988; 2013, ch. 58, § 1, effective June 25, 2013.

Annotations

 Legislative Research Commission Notes. 

 

(6/25/2013). Under the authority of KRS 7.136(1), the Reviser of Statutes has modified the internal numbering of this statute from the way it appeared in 2013 Ky. Acts ch. 58, sec. 1. An internal reference was also changed to correspond to the new numbering system, but the words in the text were not changed.

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Foreign Judgment.

2. Bankruptcy.

3. Judgment Liens.

  1. Foreign Judgment. 

 A foreign judgment holder’s filing and service of a lis pendens notice under KRS 382.440 was not sufficient compliance with the requirements of this section so as to create a lien on a date before the recording of a tax lien by the Internal Revenue Service. Redondo Constr. Corp. v. United States, 157 F.3d 1060, 1998 FED App. 0310P, 1998 U.S. App. LEXIS 26082 (6th Cir. Ky. 1998).

  2. Bankruptcy. 

 Debtors were entitled to avoid a judgment lien on their property under 11 USCS § 522(f) because, on two separate occasions, the creditor failed to strictly comply with the notice requirements of KRS 426.720. Because the lien was defective, it did not survive Chapter 7 discharge as an in rem claim. In re Steele, 402 B.R. 775, 2009 Bankr. LEXIS 803 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 2009).

 Although the creditor contended it timely instituted an action to enforce the lien, in fact it filed an action for breach of the Agreement against debtor. The filing of the Notice of Judgment Lien allowed the creditor to assert a judgment lien against debtor's real property pursuant to Ky. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 426.720, but this lien was subject to avoidance under 11 U.S.C.S. § 522(f). In re Morris, 2017 Bankr. LEXIS 3289 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. Sept. 28, 2017).

  3. Judgment Liens. 

 For purposes of interpreting  KRS 413.090(1) “execution” could mean either the act of executing an order or the writ of execution itself, which was the formal document issued by the court authorizing a sheriff to levy upon the property of a judgment debtor, as described in  KRS 426.020. Since the term was not limited to writs of execution, but could include  KRS 425.501(4) setting forth the procedure for obtaining garnishments, enforcement of judgments pursuant to  KRS 426.381(2), judgment liens under  KRS 426.720, and attachments under  KRS 425.526, the judgment creditor was not time-barred under  KRS 413.090(1)’s 15-year limitations period from collecting on a judgment it had against the judgment debtor, as it had pursued some of those enforcement techniques outside of a writ of execution that it had used more than 15 years earlier.  Wade v. Poma Glass & Specialty Windows, Inc., 394 S.W.3d 886, 2012 Ky. LEXIS 199 (Ky. 2012).

 Circuit court properly denied a judgment debtor's motion, corrected a clerical error regarding judgment interest, and granted a judgment and order of sale to enforce an estate's judgment lien against the debtor's real property because the statute clearly contemplated the judicial sale of the real property subject to a judgment lien, upon filing a notice of judgment lien in the county clerk's office, the lien automatically attached to all real property owned by the debtor in the county where filed, and the alleged deficiencies in the judgment lien notice were merely a matter of form, not content. Newman v. Estate of Hobbic, 539 S.W.3d 697, 2018 Ky. App. LEXIS 72 (Ky. Ct. App. 2018).

 Judgment creditor was entitled to summary judgment in a bankruptcy debtor’s adversary proceeding because, even under the strict compliance requirement, the judgment lien was valid and enforceable since it met the statutory requirements, notwithstanding the misidentification of the identity of a judgment creditor, which was trivial and did not rising to the level necessary to affect the perfection of the judgment lien nor notice of the same, and an order was entered in the main bankruptcy case that the named creditor was not a creditor of the debtor, that she was not the judgment creditor, and that she had no standing to file the judgment lien on her own behalf. Pasley v. Biggs (In re Pasley), 2020 Bankr. LEXIS 3335 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. Nov. 30, 2020).

  Cited in: 

 In re Lyvers, 179 B.R. 837, 1995 Bankr. LEXIS 347 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1995); Pearman v. West Point Nat’l Bank, 887 S.W.2d 366, 1994 Ky. App. LEXIS 135 (Ky. Ct. App. 1994).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Bench & Bar. 

Laramore, Final Judgment: The Beginning of the End, Vol. 58, No. 3, Summer 1994, Ky. Bench & Bar 8.

  Northern Kentucky Law Review. 

Brandt, Kentucky Real Estate Law Survey: 1990 Through 1993, 21 N. Ky. L. Rev. 435 (1994).

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th ed., Notice of Judgment Lien on Real Estate, Form 154.03.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th ed., Practice Context for Insolvent Debtors, § 154.00.


 Uniform Enforcement of Foreign Judgments Act

426.950.  Definition. 

426.955.  Filing and status of foreign judgments. 

426.960.  Notice of filing. 

426.965.  Stay. 

426.970.  Filing fee. 

426.975.  Right to bring action unimpaired. 

426.990.  Penalties. 

426.950.  Definition.

Text

In KRS 426.950 to 426.975 “foreign judgment” means any judgment, decree, or order of a court of the United States or of any other court which is entitled to full faith and credit in this Commonwealth.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1990, ch. 317, § 1, effective July 13, 1990.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Purpose.

2. Application.

  1. Purpose. 

 Purpose of Uniform Enforcement of Foreign Judgments Act is to give holders of foreign judgments the same rights and remedies as the holder of a domestic judgment. Sunrise Turquoise v. Chemical Design Co., 899 S.W.2d 856, 1995 Ky. App. LEXIS 71 (Ky. Ct. App. 1995).

  2. Application. 

 Where Florida long-arm jurisdiction statute conferred personal jurisdiction over nonresidents who conducted business and breached contract in the state, judgment of Florida court against Kentucky buyer of goods for breach of contract, was entitled to full faith and credit, where buyer entered into over 50 contracts with Florida seller and had numerous and long established course of conduct with seller and breached terms of contracts. Sunrise Turquoise v. Chemical Design Co., 899 S.W.2d 856, 1995 Ky. App. LEXIS 71 (Ky. Ct. App. 1995).
