 The Uniform Enforcement of Foreign Judgments Act is subject to KRS 413.090; thus, an action by a judgment creditor on a foreign judgment that is still valid in the state in which it was entered is subject to Kentucky’s fifteen-year statute of limitations on foreign judgments. Fairbanks v. Large, 957 S.W.2d 307, 1997 Ky. App. LEXIS 127 (Ky. Ct. App. 1997).

 Texas court lacked in personam jurisdiction to enter a judgment against a husband; the parties’  Texas marriage, alone, was insufficient for the Texas court to establish personal jurisdiction over the husband where the parties established a marital domicile in Kentucky right after the marriage, so the Texas judgment was not entitled to enforcement in Kentucky under the Uniform Enforcement of Foreign Judgments Act, KRS 426.950 et seq. Cox v. Cox, 170 S.W.3d 389, 2005 Ky. LEXIS 231 (Ky. 2005).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Northern Kentucky Law Review. 

Brandt, Kentucky Real Estate Law Survey: 1990 Through 1993, 21 N. Ky. L. Rev. 435 (1994).

  Treatises 

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, 1991 Supp., Custody of Children, §§ 27.14, 28.1, 28.2.

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, 1991 Supp., Maintenance, § 25.28.


426.955.  Filing and status of foreign judgments.

Text

A copy of any foreign judgment authenticated in accordance with the Act of Congress or the statutes of this state may be filed in the office of the clerk of any court of competent jurisdiction of this state. The clerk shall treat the foreign judgment in the same manner as a judgment of any court of this state. A judgment so filed has the same effect and is subject to the same procedures, defenses and proceedings for reopening, vacating, or staying as a judgment of a court of this state and may be enforced or satisfied in like manner.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1990, ch. 317, § 2, effective July 13, 1990.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Application.

2. Foreign Judgments.

  3. — Counterclaim.

  4. — Rights on Appeal.

  1. Application. 

 Where Florida long-arm jurisdiction statute conferred personal jurisdiction over nonresidents who conducted business and breached contract in the state, judgment of Florida court against Kentucky buyer of goods for breach of contract, was entitled to full faith and credit, where buyer entered into over 50 contracts with Florida seller and had numerous and long established course of conduct with seller and breached terms of contracts. Sunrise Turquoise v. Chemical Design Co., 899 S.W.2d 856, 1995 Ky. App. LEXIS 71 (Ky. Ct. App. 1995).

 Upon proper registration, the holder of a foreign judgment has the equivalent of a Kentucky judgment and may proceed accordingly. Redondo Constr. Corp. v. United States, 157 F.3d 1060, 1998 FED App. 0310P, 1998 U.S. App. LEXIS 26082 (6th Cir. Ky. 1998).

  2. Foreign Judgments. 

  3. — Counterclaim. 

 Kentucky buyer of goods could not assert counterclaim against Florida seller, in proceeding brought in Kentucky to enforce foreign default judgment obtained by seller in Florida under Uniform Enforcement of Foreign Judgments Act as foreign judgment was entitled to same weight as judgment of Kentucky court. Sunrise Turquoise v. Chemical Design Co., 899 S.W.2d 856, 1995 Ky. App. LEXIS 71 (Ky. Ct. App. 1995).

  4. — Rights on Appeal. 

 Where Kentucky buyer of goods had notice of Florida action by Florida seller of goods for breach of contract but maintained it did not defend action because it believed Florida court lacked jurisdiction, it could not raise matters before appellate court which should have been presented to Florida court in its argument to set aside default judgment. Sunrise Turquoise v. Chemical Design Co., 899 S.W.2d 856, 1995 Ky. App. LEXIS 71 (Ky. Ct. App. 1995).


426.960.  Notice of filing.

Text

(1) At the time of the filing of the foreign judgment, the judgment creditor or his lawyer shall make and file with the clerk of the court an affidavit setting forth the name and the last known post office address of the judgment debtor, and the judgment creditor.

(2) Promptly upon the filing of the foreign judgment and the affidavit, the clerk shall mail notice of the filing of the foreign judgment to the judgment debtor at the address given and shall make a note of the mailing in the docket. The notice shall include the name and post office address of the judgment creditor and the judgment creditor’s lawyer, if any, in this state. In addition, the judgment creditor may mail a notice of the filing of the judgment to the judgment debtor and may file proof of mailing with the clerk. Lack of mailing notice of filing by the clerk shall not affect the enforcement proceedings if proof of mailing by the judgment creditor has been filed.

(3) No execution or other process for enforcement of a foreign judgment filed hereunder shall issue until twenty (20) days after the date the judgment is filed.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1990, ch. 317, § 3, effective July 13, 1990.


426.965.  Stay.

Text

(1) If the judgment debtor shows the court that an appeal from the foreign judgment is pending or will be taken, or that a stay of execution has been granted, the court shall stay enforcement of the foreign judgment until the appeal is concluded, the time for appeal expires, or the stay of execution expires or is vacated, upon proof that the judgment debtor has furnished the security for the satisfaction of the judgment required by the state in which it was rendered.

(2) If the judgment debtor shows the court any ground upon which enforcement of a judgment of any court of this state would be stayed, including the ground that an appeal from the foreign judgment is pending or will be taken, or that the time for taking such an appeal has not yet expired, the court shall stay enforcement of the foreign judgment for an appropriate period until all available appeals are concluded or the time for taking all appeals has expired, upon requiring the same security for satisfaction of the judgment which is required in this state, subject to KRS 411.187.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1990, ch. 317, § 4, effective July 13, 1990; 2000, ch. 205, § 2, effective March 29, 2000.

Annotations

 Compiler’s Notes. 

 Section 3 of Acts 2000, ch. 205, effective March 29, 2000, read: “The provisions of Sections 1 and 2 of this Act [KRS 411.187 and this section] are hereby expressly declared to be retroactive and may be applied to all civil actions, including those on appeal, presently docketed in the courts of this Commonwealth.”


426.970.  Filing fee.

Text

A person filing a foreign judgment shall pay to the clerk of the court the amount as otherwise provided by law for filing suit in the courts of this state.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1990, ch. 317, § 5, effective July 13, 1990.


426.975.  Right to bring action unimpaired.

Text

The right of a judgment creditor to bring an action to enforce his judgment instead of proceeding under KRS 426.950 to 426.975 remains unimpaired.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1990, ch. 317, § 6, effective July 13, 1990.


426.990.  Penalties.

Text

(1) Any officer who fails to advertise for sale property taken under execution as required by subsection (1) of KRS 426.340 may, on motion of either the plaintiff or the defendant in the execution, be fined by the court from which the execution issued not less than five dollars ($5) nor more than twenty dollars ($20), and costs, for the use of the party making the motion. The officer shall be given at least ten (10) days’ notice, in writing, of the motion. The officer shall be given at least ten (10) days’ notice, in writing, of the motion. The officer shall, in addition to the fine provided, be liable on his bond to the party aggrieved for damages.

(2) Any officer who fails to return a writ as required by subsection (2) of KRS 426.340 may, on motion, be fined by the court from which the writ issued not more than fifty dollars ($50), for the use of the party injured. The officer shall be given at least three (3) days’ notice, in writing, of the motion.

History

History.
1712, 1714.


CHAPTER 427 Exemptions

427.005.  Definitions. 

427.010.  Exempt personal property, health savings funds, and disposable earnings of individual debtors. 

427.020.  Appraisement of defendant’s property — Selection by defendant. 

427.030.  Debtor’s tools exempt. 

427.040.  Professional libraries and vehicle exempt. 

427.045.  Exemptions not applicable to claims for child support. 

427.050.  Out-of-state law applicable when wages earned and payable out of state — Exceptions. 

427.060.  Homestead and burial plot exemptions — Exceptions. 

427.070.  Right of spouse and children to homestead. 

427.080.  Valuation and allotment of homestead exemption. 

427.090.  Payment of money in lieu of homestead exemption. 

427.100.  Waiver of homestead exemption — Continuance after death. 

427.110.  Insurance benefits—Exemptions. 

427.120.  Police and firefighters’ pension fund in cities of the first, second, and third classes — Exempt from process in some cases. [Repealed.] 

427.125.  Police and firefighters’ pension fund in cities of fourth class — Exempt from process in some cases. 

427.126.  Pension fund for county patrolmen in certain counties; exempt from process. [Repealed.] 

427.130.  Salaries of public officials and employees and sums due from governmental agencies are subject to attachment or garnishment — Service of process. 

427.140.  Employee may not be discharged for garnishment for one (1) indebtedness. 

427.150.  Property totally or partially exempt. 

427.160.  Additional general exemption. 

427.170.  Federal bankruptcy code exemptions applicable in Kentucky. 

427.180.  Grain storage receipt or scale ticket as prima facie claim of right to possession. 

427.990.  Penalty. 

427.005.  Definitions.

Text

As used in this chapter:

  (1) The term “earnings” means compensation paid or payable for personal services, whether denominated as wages, salary, commission, bonus, or otherwise, and includes periodic payments pursuant to a pension or retirement program.

  (2) The term “disposable earnings” means that part of the earnings of any individual remaining after the deduction from those earnings of any amounts required by law to be withheld.

  (3) The term “garnishment” means any legal or equitable procedure through which the earnings of any individual are required to be withheld for payment of any debt.

  (4) The terms “household furnishings, jewelry, personal clothing, and ornaments” mean clothing, furniture, appliances, linens, china, crockery, kitchenware, and personal effects of an individual and the individual’s dependents, but do not include:

  (a) Works of art;

  (b) Electronic entertainment equipment (except to the extent of one (1) television and one (1) radio);

  (c) Antiques; and

  (d) Jewelry other than wedding rings.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1970, ch. 217, § 1; 1992, ch. 53, § 1, effective July 14, 1992.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  1. Earnings. 

 Proceeds from a dairy farmer’s sale of milk do not constitute “earnings” within the meaning of this section and therefore are not exempt under KRS 427.010 or partially protected from garnishment. Rice, Seiller, Cantor, Anderson, & Bordy v. Fitzgerald, 824 S.W.2d 435, 1992 Ky. App. LEXIS 25 (Ky. Ct. App. 1992).

 Debtor’s claimed exemption of severance pay received from Debtor’s former employer did not qualify as “earnings” under this section for purposes of exemption pursuant to KRS 427.010(2). In re Johnson, 199 B.R. 155, 1995 Bankr. LEXIS 2081 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1995).

 Husband’s claim pursuant to KRS 427.010(2)(a) that money owed to the husband’s medical practice was largely exempt from the wife’s garnishment action was more properly considered under KRS 427.005(1), which provided the definition of “earnings” that were subject to exemption. The husband did not prove that the money at issue constituted “earnings” because the husband did not show what part of that money was generated through the husband’s personal efforts. Mickler v. Mickler, 245 S.W.3d 809, 2008 Ky. App. LEXIS 23 (Ky. Ct. App. 2008).

  Cited: 

 In re Harville, 60 B.R. 188, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 6320 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986); In re Harville, 63 B.R. 371, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 5671 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

 Opinions of Attorney General. 

 An order for back child support is includible in the definition of “garnishment” under subsection (3) of this section, especially since KRS 427.010(3)(a) implies that back child support orders are to be treated as garnishments without restrictions as to the amount which may permissibly be withheld. OAG 74-506.

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Comments, Is an IRA Exempt Property Under the Kentucky Exemption Statute KRS Section 427.150(1)(b)?, 73 Ky. L.J. 1127 (1984-85).

  Treatises 

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, Status of Wife, § 11.2.


427.010.  Exempt personal property, health savings funds, and disposable earnings of individual debtors.

Text

(1) The following personal property of an individual debtor resident in this state is exempt from execution, attachment, garnishment, distress or fee-bill: All household furnishings, jewelry, personal clothing and ornaments not to exceed three thousand dollars ($3,000) in value; tools, equipment and livestock, including poultry, of a person engaged in farming, not exceeding three thousand dollars ($3,000) in value; one (1) motor vehicle and its necessary accessories, including one (1) spare tire, not exceeding in the aggregate two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500) in value; professionally prescribed health aids for the debtor, or a dependent of the debtor; and funds deposited in a health savings account as described in Section 223 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.

(2) Except as provided in subsection (3) of this section and KRS 427.050, the maximum part of the aggregate disposable earnings of an individual for any workweek which is subjected to garnishment may not exceed the lesser of either:

  (a) Twenty-five percent (25%) of his disposable earnings for that week, or

  (b) The amount by which his disposable earnings for that week exceed thirty (30) times the federal minimum hourly wage prescribed by Section 6(a)(1) of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 in effect at the time the earnings are payable. In the case of earnings for any pay period other than a week, the multiple of the federal minimum hourly wage equivalent to that set forth in paragraph (b) of this subsection as prescribed by regulation by the federal secretary of labor shall apply.

(3) The restrictions of subsection (2) of this section do not apply in the case of:

  (a) Any order of any court for the support of any person.

  (b) Any order of any court of bankruptcy under Chapter 13 of the Bankruptcy Code.

  (c) Any debt due for any state or federal tax.

(4) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no property upon which a debtor has voluntarily granted a lien shall, to the extent of the balance due on the debt secured thereby, be subject to the provisions of this chapter or be exempt from forced sale under process of law.

History

HISTORY:
1697: amend. Acts 1966, ch. 157, § 1; 1970, ch. 217, § 2; 1980, ch. 236, § 1, effective April 9, 1980; 1982, ch. 336, § 1, effective July 15, 1982; 2017 ch. 121, § 1, effective June 29, 2017.

Annotations

 Compiler’s Notes. 

 The Fair Labor Standards Act referred to in subsection (2)(b) of this section is compiled in 29 USCS, § 201 et seq.

 The Bankruptcy Code referred to in subsection (3)(b) of this section is compiled throughout Title 11 of the United States Code.

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Constitutionality.

2. Purpose.

3. Construction.

4. Application.

5. Alimony.

6. Attachment.

  7. —Rights of Defendant.

8. Bankruptcy.

9. Crops.

10. Damages.

11. Requirements for Claiming.

12. Setoffs and Counterclaims.

13. Fines.

14. Person with Family.

15. Property.

  16. —Ownership.

  17. —Partnership.

  18. —Personal.

  19. —Purchase.

  20. — —From Proceeds of Sale of Property.

  21. —Sale.

  22. —Transfer.

23. Provisions.

24. Salary or Wages.

25. Tobacco.

26. Motor Vehicle.

27. Consensual Liens.

  28. —Unfair Trade Practices.

  29. —Availability of Relief via Motion Practice.

  30. —Court May Waive Filing Fee.

31. Pensions.

  32. —Subject to Security Interest.

  33. —Purchases With.

34. Proceeds from Sale of Product.

35. Right to Exemption.

36. Animals.

37. Debtors.

  38. —Family.

39. Executions.

  40. —Bonds.

  41. —Injunction.

  42. —Replevin.

43. Liens.

  44. —Contracts.

45. Military Pay.

46. Proceeds of Sale.

  47. —Substitution.

  48. —When Exempt.

49. Residence.

50. Right of Action.

  51. —Descent.

52. Sale of Exempt Property.

  53. —Injunction.

  54. —Waiver of Rights.

55. Surrender.

56. Tobacco.

57. Waiver.

  1. Constitutionality. 

 Subsection (4) of this section is not unconstitutional under the Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution. In re Roehrig, 36 B.R. 505, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 5246 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983).

 Debtor’s claim that the retroactive applicability of subsection (4) of this section was a taking of property without due process of law was without merit, where under the applicable state law the household goods in question were not exempt at the time the lien was created on May 16, 1979, nor were they exempt pursuant to the state’s statutory exemption scheme on May 3, 1983, when the debtor’s petition in bankruptcy was filed. In re Roehrig, 36 B.R. 505, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 5246 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983).

 Subsection (4) of this section, which denies to debtors bankruptcy exemptions in property subject to consensual liens, clearly lies beyond any of the 29 enumerated types of “special legislation” specifically prohibited by Ky. Const., § 59 and is therefore “general legislation” well within the province of the Legislature to enact. In re Bennett, 36 B.R. 893, 1984 Bankr. LEXIS 6282 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1984).

  2. Purpose. 

 The protection of the family, as such, from the misfortune of debt that cannot be met was the prime consideration of the Legislature. Baum v. Turner, 139 Ky. 597, 76 S.W. 129, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 600, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 4 (Ky. 1903).

 Primary object of exemption statutes is preservation of debtor’s exempt property for benefit of his family against any appropriation for payment of his debts not authorized by law to which he does not consent. Grant v. Phoenix-Jellico Coal Co., 155 Ky. 585, 159 S.W. 1161, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 299 (Ky. 1913).

 It is not the purpose of the exemption statutes to provide luxuries to the debtor at the expense of his creditors. Thomson v. Dennis' Ex'x, 282 Ky. 352, 138 S.W.2d 490, 1940 Ky. LEXIS 170 (Ky. 1940).

  3. Construction. 

 Exemption statutes are liberally construed. Grant v. Phoenix-Jellico Coal Co., 155 Ky. 585, 159 S.W. 1161, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 299 (Ky. 1913). See Wallins Nat'l Bank v. Turner, 221 Ky. 562, 299 S.W. 194, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 775 (Ky. 1927).

 Subsections (2) and (3) provide only for limited debtor protection and not for a broader exemption such as that created by KRS 432.180 and similar statutes. This limited protection is the same found to have been provided by the federal Consumer Credit Protection Act, a limitation only on the extent to which an employee’s earnings may be garnisheed at his or her workplace. Brown v. Commonwealth, 40 S.W.3d 873, 1999 Ky. App. LEXIS 126 (Ky. Ct. App. 1999).

  4. Application. 

 Fact that certain money is exempted from payment of debts results from legislative decision and not from law of contracts. First Nat'l Bank v. Cann's Ex'x, 247 Ky. 618, 57 S.W.2d 461, 1932 Ky. LEXIS 879 (Ky. 1932).

 Exemptions not specified in statute cannot be read into it by court. Helton v. Vanderpool, 251 Ky. 312, 64 S.W.2d 883, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 846 (Ky. 1933).

  5. Alimony. 

 Exemptions did not apply against judgments in alimony proceedings. Pearson v. Pearson, 166 Ky. 91, 178 S.W. 1164, 1915 Ky. LEXIS 637 (Ky. 1915).

 Statutory exemptions do not apply to levies on property of husband for alimony default. Boden v. McCoy, 278 S.W.2d 68, 1955 Ky. LEXIS 475 (Ky. 1955).

  6. Attachment. 

 Burden is on defendant in attachment to show attached property is exempt. Daugherty v. Bell Nat'l Bank, 175 Ky. 513, 194 S.W. 545, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 342 (Ky. 1917).

  7. —Rights of Defendant. 

 Exemption rights of defendant are not destroyed by attachment prior to judgment. Pinson v. Murphy, 220 Ky. 464, 295 S.W. 442, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 556 (Ky. 1927).

  8. Bankruptcy. 

 Bankrupt’s automobile was not exempt in bankruptcy proceeding. In re McEuen, 19 F. Supp. 924, 1937 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 1776 (D. Ky. 1937).

 KRS 427.010(2)(a) was a Kentucky garnishment statute, limited to pre-bankruptcy actions by creditors; once debtor filed her bankruptcy petition, KRS 427.010(2) did not protect her post-petition federal tax refund from the trustee’s reach. Thus, debtor could not claim an exemption for her 2003 tax refund under the statute. 2004 Bankr. LEXIS 1350.

 KRS 427.010(2)(a) was virtually identical to the Consumer Credit Protection Act (CCPA), 15 USCS §§ 1671-77, which was meant to prevent bankruptcies, not to function within the bankruptcy process, and there was no reason to believe that the General Assembly intended KRS 427.010(2) to be read differently than the CCPA, upon which it was clearly modeled. Absent a showing of the General Assembly’s intent to allow KRS 427.010(2) to continue in the bankruptcy process, debtor could not utilize the garnishment statute to protect her post-petition federal income tax refund from the trustee’s reach. 2004 Bankr. LEXIS 1350.

 The exemption under KRS 427.010 did not apply to the recovery of an insurance fraud claim worth approximately $5,000 which was not reported during the course of the bankruptcy case, but was only raised after the case was reopened by the trustee. The court found this exemption was claimed in bad faith considering debtor failed to disclose the asset at a time when she knew it existed. In re Keith, 336 B.R. 746, 2006 Bankr. LEXIS 79 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 2006).

  9. Crops. 

 A stipulation, in a lease of agricultural lands, giving the landlord a lien for rent on the crop does not waive the tenant’s right to the statutory exemptions out of such crop for his support. Moss v. Carl, 37 S.W. 580, 18. Ky. L. Rptr. 648 (1896).

  10. Damages. 

 Debtor’s action to recover property levied on as exempt is same in character as action of detinue, and measure of damages is thus that of detinue. Winstead v. Hicks, 135 Ky. 154, 121 S.W. 1018, 1909 Ky. LEXIS 270 (Ky. 1909).

  11. Requirements for Claiming. 

 Where defendant in attachment suit failed to account for his property or its proceeds which was in excess of property attached, he could not claim exemptions for such attached property. Rogers v. Allen, 105 S.W. 96, 32 Ky. L. Rptr. 1 (1907).

 Property is not exempt where owner has no family. Jarboe v. Hayden, 133 Ky. 378, 117 S.W. 961, 1909 Ky. LEXIS 181 (Ky. 1909).

 In order to claim exemptions, debtor must state what provisions and provender he has, if any. Tharp v. Tharp's Trustee, 119 S.W. 814 (Ky. 1909).

 Exemption is absolute, and need not be expressly claimed. Winstead v. Hicks, 135 Ky. 154, 121 S.W. 1018, 1909 Ky. LEXIS 270 (Ky. 1909).

 Where exemptions of the debtor in federal income tax refund and wages were not properly claimed because the debtor failed to specify what property was being claimed exempt, in what amount, and under what statute, bankruptcy trustee’s objection to such exemptions would be sustained. In re Bolden, 20 B.R. 686, 1981 Bankr. LEXIS 2364 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1981).

  12. Setoffs and Counterclaims. 

 Generally, debtor’s right to his exemptions will not be defeated by setoffs or counterclaims. Grant v. Phoenix-Jellico Coal Co., 155 Ky. 585, 159 S.W. 1161, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 299 (Ky. 1913).

  13. Fines. 

 Exemptions to housekeepers cannot be seized under execution in favor of commonwealth for fines. Commonwealth v. Cassady, 159 Ky. 776, 169 S.W. 497, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 887 (Ky. 1914) (Ky. 1914).

  14. Person with Family. 

 “Person with family” included wife who actually supported herself, husband and children, and without whose exertions such husband and children would have had no support. Wilson's Assignee v. Wilson, 101 Ky. 731, 42 S.W. 404, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 925, 1897 Ky. LEXIS 237 (Ky. 1897).

  15. Property. 

 Exemptions can be had only for property specified in statute. Roberts v. Frank Carrithers & Bros., 180 Ky. 315, 202 S.W. 659, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 58 (Ky. 1918).

 This section does not exempt other property in lieu of the items specified. Thacker v. Cook, 236 Ky. 159, 32 S.W.2d 738, 1930 Ky. LEXIS 701 (Ky. 1930).

 Where party furnished money with which debtor bought mules, and debtor then traded such mules for other mules, wagon, and plow, items thus traded were nevertheless exempt in face of attachment by such party. Helton v. Vanderpool, 251 Ky. 312, 64 S.W.2d 883, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 846 (Ky. 1933).

 Debtor had burden of showing rugs were used in his “family rooms” and therefore exempt from attachment. Thomson v. Dennis' Ex'x, 282 Ky. 352, 138 S.W.2d 490, 1940 Ky. LEXIS 170 (Ky. 1940).

  16. —Ownership. 

 Failure of plaintiff to allege that he was owner of property which he claimed should have been exempted from sale under execution against him justified sustaining demurrer of defendants. Taylor v. Bertram, 55 S.W. 553, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 1402, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 507 (Ky. Ct. App. 1900).

  17. —Partnership. 

 Partnership property could not be claimed and held by any member of firm as exempt from execution by firm’s creditors, since title was not in individual partner. Green v. Taylor, 98 Ky. 330, 32 S.W. 945, 17 Ky. L. Rptr. 897, 1895 Ky. LEXIS 52 (Ky. 1895).

 Whenever property of firm partner would be exempt as belonging solely to him before and after its contribution to existing firm, such property as partnership property could be claimed by such partner as exempt from execution by his own individual creditors. Southern Jellico Coal Co. v. Smith, 105 Ky. 769, 49 S.W. 807, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 1594, 1899 Ky. LEXIS 278 (Ky. 1899).

  18. —Personal. 

 Personal property belonging to a debtor exempt from execution may be mortgaged, and it is not necessary that his wife should unite in the mortgage. Smith v. D. Wilson & Co., 11 Ky. Op. 946, 4 Ky. L. Rptr. 719, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 355 (Ky. Ct. App. Feb. 20, 1883) (decided under prior law).

 A mortgagor had no right to any exemption in the mortgaged chattels, though personal property exemptions were not referred to in the mortgage. Woods v. Davis, 153 Ky. 99, 154 S.W. 905, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 785 (Ky. 1913).

  19. —Purchase. 

  20. — —From Proceeds of Sale of Property. 

 Property which is purchased from proceeds of sale of exempt property is not itself exempt, where it would not otherwise by exempt under this section. McLeod's Trustee v. McLeod, 89 S.W. 199, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 284 (1905). See Nicholson's Trustee v. Nicholson, 125 Ky. 629, 101 S.W. 985, 31 Ky. L. Rptr. 217, 1907 Ky. LEXIS 320 (Ky. 1907).

  21. —Sale. 

 A debtor is entitled to sell his exempt property freed from any legal demand of his creditors, and hence the fact that notes sued on were given for the proceeds of a sale of a debtor’s exempt property gives his creditors no right to subject them to their claims. King v. Tompkins' Adm'r, 15 Ky. L. Rptr. 29 (1893).

  22. —Transfer. 

 By a transfer of property specifically exempt, a debtor does not forfeit his right to an exemption in remaining property. Northington v. Boyd, 12 Ky. L. Rptr. 227 (decided under prior law).

  23. Provisions. 

 In collection enforcement action, defendant’s allegation that he had insufficient provisions to sustain his family for one year was insufficient in not showing what provisions were actually on hand. Lawson v. S. T. Barlow Co., 51 S.W. 314, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 308 (1899).

  24. Salary or Wages. 

 “Salary” or “wages” mean consideration paid for services at regular times and are synonymous except that “salary” usually refers to compensation for more dignified services. Roberts v. Frank Carrithers & Bros., 180 Ky. 315, 202 S.W. 659, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 58 (Ky. 1918).

 Debtor’s claimed exemption of severance pay received from debtor’s former employer did not qualify as “earnings” under KRS 427.005 for purposes of exemption pursuant to subsection (2) of this section. In re Johnson, 199 B.R. 155, 1995 Bankr. LEXIS 2081 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1995).

 Debtors objection to a garnishment of money that the debtors kept in a bank account on the grounds that the money was exempt as wages was overruled because the protection for wages afforded under KRS 427.010 was limited to wages that were still in the employer’s control, in the same manner as federal law. In re Adams, 2007 Bankr. LEXIS 523 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. Feb. 5, 2007).

 Husband’s bank account was not exempt from garnishment, under KRS 427.010(2), due to exclusively holding the husband’s salary and wages because (1) the statute did not operate to limit the attachment of all wages, but only placed a limit on the amount of wages which could be subject to a garnishment order, and (2) the statute did not protect or exempt wages in the hands of a debtor. Shafizadeh v. Shafizadeh, 444 S.W.3d 437, 2012 Ky. App. LEXIS 285 (Ky. Ct. App. 2012).

  25. Tobacco. 

 Where portion of debtor’s tobacco was sold under execution and debtor had more than sufficient tobacco remaining for sale to supply breadstuffs for the family and provender deficiency, such portion as was sold was not exempt. Turner-Looker Co. v. Garvey, 43 S.W. 202, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 1205 (1897).

 “Income earned by labor” does not include tobacco crop, and such crop is not exempt unless in lieu of insufficient provender on hand. People's Bank of Springfield v. Cocanaugher, 183 Ky. 73, 208 S.W. 322, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 439 (Ky. 1919).

  26. Motor Vehicle. 

 A bus with a seating capacity of 60 passengers is a motor vehicle entitled to the exemption pursuant to this section, because the Legislature did not intend the term “motor vehicle” to be synonymous only with automobile. In re Johnson, 14 B.R. 14, 1981 Bankr. LEXIS 2957 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1981).

  27. Consensual Liens. 

 Consensual liens may not be avoided under 11 USCS § 522(f) where the state has “opted out” of the federal exemptions and where the state exemption statute determines that property subject to a consensual lien is not exempt to the extent of the balance due thereon. In re Casey, 55 B.R. 468, 1985 Bankr. LEXIS 5016 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1985).

 Because Kentucky has chosen to “opt out” for the federal exemptions set forth in 11 USCS, § 522(d), a creditor is entitled to retain its voluntary non-possessory, nonpurchase-money lien on the debtors’ property under this section. In re Estep, 96 B.R. 87, 1988 Bankr. LEXIS 2229 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 1988).

 Whereas consensual liens such as those typically granted by individuals to consumer finance companies are voluntary, the debtor is not entitled, under Kentucky law, to exempt property subject to such liens. In re Raymond, 103 B.R. 846, 1989 Bankr. LEXIS 1485 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1989).

  28. —Unfair Trade Practices. 

 Nonpossessory, nonpurchase money liens on household goods, while not avoidable under the provisions of subsection (4) of this section, have been declared to constitute unfair trade practices by the Federal Trade Commission and, accordingly, since such practices are unlawful, any liens resulting from such unlawful acts are likewise unlawful; being unlawful, the liens are avoidable by the debtor, where it can be shown that the liened goods fell within the Federal Trade Commission definition of household goods. In re Raymond, 103 B.R. 846, 1989 Bankr. LEXIS 1485 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1989).

  29. —Availability of Relief via Motion Practice. 

 Actions to avoid nonpossessory, nonpurchase money liens in personal property are most economically disposed of by motion practice rather than by adversary proceeding; accordingly such avoidance actions are to be heard by motion where the parties to the dispute consent to such adjudication, however, in instances where the parties will not consent, the debtor must file an adversary proceeding. In re Raymond, 103 B.R. 846, 1989 Bankr. LEXIS 1485 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1989).

  30. —Court May Waive Filing Fee. 

 Where the parties to an action to avoid a nonpossessory, nonpurchase money lien in personal property do not consent to resolving the issues by motion, upon timely motion the court may exercise its broad equitable powers and waive the fee charged by the clerk of the Bankruptcy Court for the filing of an adversary proceeding. In re Raymond, 103 B.R. 846, 1989 Bankr. LEXIS 1485 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1989).

  31. Pensions. 

 Though pension money is exempt, the pensioner cannot dispose of it by will to the exclusion of his creditors. Luthey v. Bacon, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 326 (1883) (decided under prior law).

  32. —Subject to Security Interest. 

 Where the income participation section of a partnership agreement plainly recited that payments made thereunder are made only upon a partner’s retirement, death or total disability, whether such payments were characterized as a pension, profit-sharing plan or similar plan or contract was of little consequence as all are exempt to the extent reasonably necessary for the support of the debtor and his dependents; however, where debtor, in consideration for a loan, granted a security interest in those payments, the payments were an exempt asset subject to that security interest. In re Peklenk, 106 B.R. 119, 1989 Bankr. LEXIS 1755 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1989).

  33. —Purchases With. 

 Property purchased by a pensioner with pension money is not exempt. Robion v. Walker, 82 Ky. 60, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 799, 1884 Ky. LEXIS 38 (Ky. 1884), overruled,  Matthews v. Lewis, 617 S.W.2d 43, 1981 Ky. LEXIS 255 (Ky. 1981). See Asher v. Terry, 6 Ky. L. Rptr. 745 (1853) (decided under prior law).

 Pension money was no longer exempt after reaching pensioner’s hands, and this applied as well when pensioner received pension check which he gave to third parties with directions to draw cash and pay for land conveyed to pensioner’s wife, so that such land was likewise not exempt. Johnson v. Elkins, 90 Ky. 163, 13 S.W. 448, 11 Ky. L. Rptr. 967, 1890 Ky. LEXIS 60 (Ky. 1890) (decided under prior law).

  34. Proceeds from Sale of Product. 

 Proceeds from a dairy farmer’s sale of milk do not constitute “earnings” within the meaning of KRS 427.005 and therefore are not exempt under this section or partially protected from garnishment. Rice, Seiller, Cantor, Anderson, & Bordy v. Fitzgerald, 824 S.W.2d 435, 1992 Ky. App. LEXIS 25 (Ky. Ct. App. 1992).

  35. Right to Exemption. 

 Right to exemption must be determined by law which was in force when debt was contracted, not when exemption was claimed. Knight v. Whitman, 69 Ky. 51, 1869 Ky. LEXIS 98 (Ky. 1869). See Millay v. White, 86 Ky. 170, 5 S.W. 429, 9 Ky. L. Rptr. 462, 1887 Ky. LEXIS 114 (Ky. 1887) (decided under prior law).

 Husband’s claim pursuant to KRS 427.010(2)(a) that money owed to the husband’s medical practice was largely exempt from the wife’s garnishment action was more properly considered under KRS 427.005(1), which provided the definition of “earnings” that were subject to exemption. The husband did not prove that the money at issue constituted “earnings” because the husband did not show what part of that money was generated through the husband’s personal efforts. Mickler v. Mickler, 245 S.W.3d 809, 2008 Ky. App. LEXIS 23 (Ky. Ct. App. 2008).

  36. Animals. 

 A housekeeper with a wife and children is entitled to two (2) work beasts, and the horse in question, although only 19 months old and never having been worked, being of the species to which the execution applies, and being intended for the use of the family, is exempt from execution. McClanahan v. McGill, 1 Ky. Op. 178, 1866 Ky. LEXIS 255 (Ky. Ct. App. June 14, 1866) (decided under prior law).

 The term “work beast,” as used in the statute exempting such animals from execution, includes a colt which could be rendered fit for service. Winfrey v. Zimmerman, 71 Ky. 587, 1871 Ky. LEXIS 124 (Ky. Ct. App. 1871) (decided under prior law).

 Where debtor had one milk cow, one calf, and two unbred heifers, cow and calf were exempt for particular purpose of debtor’s present needs and could not be seized and sold in lieu of heifers without knowledge or consent of debtor. Stirman v. Smith, 10 S.W. 131, 10 Ky. L. Rptr. 665 (1888) (decided under prior law).

  37. Debtors. 

  38. —Family. 

 Operatives hired by a debtor to cultivate his farm are not, in contemplation of the exemption laws, part of the debtor’s immediate family. McMurray v. Shuck, 69 Ky. 111, 1869 Ky. LEXIS 112 (Ky. 1869) (decided under prior law).

 A debtor who is a widower having two daughters, both of whom are married, and one of whom, with her husband and child, boards with him, cannot be considered as having a family. Carter v. Adams, 4 S.W. 36, 9 Ky. L. Rptr. 91 (Ky. Ct. App. 1887) (decided under prior law).

  39. Executions. 

 Defendant in execution may, after execution has been delivered to the officer, convey by exchange such of his property as is exempt from execution. Paxton v. Freeman, 29 Ky. 234, 1831 Ky. LEXIS 169 (Ky. 1831) (decided under prior law).

  40. —Bonds. 

 The giving of a delivery bond by an execution debtor does not prevent him from afterwards claiming the property seized as exempt. Perry v. Hensley, 53 Ky. 474 (Ky. 1854) (decided under prior law).

  41. —Injunction. 

 Where property seized under execution was the debtor’s only work beasts, which were essential to the making of his crops and were exempt, the statutory remedy by replevin was inadequate, and the debtor was entitled to have the sale of the property enjoined. Hamlett v. Buckner, 6 Ky. L. Rptr. 741 (1885) (decided under prior law).

  42. —Replevin. 

 A defendant in execution, whose property is levied on, cannot prosecute a writ of replevin, although the property may be exempted by law. Reynolds v. Sallee, 41 Ky. 18, 1841 Ky. LEXIS 62 (Ky. 1841). See Saffell v. Wash, 43 Ky. 92, 1843 Ky. LEXIS 102 (Ky. 1843) (decided under prior law).

  43. Liens. 

  44. —Contracts. 

 Where there is a contract for a lien on a specific thing, a provision of the contract waiving the right of the debtor to exemption out of the thing specified is valid. Marquess v. Brandon, 13 Ky. L. Rptr. 686 (1892) (decided under prior law).

  45. Military Pay. 

 The bounty and back pay of a deceased soldier who died in service during the civil war, and which is made payable to the widow and children of such soldier, is not subject to the debts of the deceased soldier. Avery v. Carter, 7 Ky. Op. 200, 1873 Ky. LEXIS 508 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 16, 1873) (decided under prior law).

  46. Proceeds of Sale. 

  47. —Substitution. 

 No part of the proceeds of land can be set apart in lieu of exempted articles not on hand, there being no provision for such setting apart, but the substitution, if made at all, must be made out of personal property or money. Peak v. Weller & Co., 10 Ky. L. Rptr. 153 (1888) (decided under prior law).

  48. —When Exempt. 

 Where the proceeds of the sale of two horses, one owned by the husband and the other by the wife, were invested in property in the name of the wife, such property will be exempt in her hands, both of the horses having been exempt. Musgrave v. Parish, 11 S.W. 464, 10 Ky. L. Rptr. 998 (1889) (decided under prior law).

  49. Residence. 

 A housekeeper, although he has declared his intention of leaving the state and is making preparations therefor, or is in transitu, still retains his rights as a housekeeper secured to him by the exemption laws. Anthony, A. C., & Co. v. Wade, 64 Ky. 110, 1866 Ky. LEXIS 100 (Ky. 1866). See Rasco v. Sheet & Son, 8 Ky. L. Rptr. 703 (1887) (decided under prior law).

  50. Right of Action. 

  51. —Descent. 

 A debtor’s right of action for the recovery of property exempted from execution, or its value, does not, on his death, pass to his personal representatives, but to his widow, for the benefit of herself and the infant children residing with her. Myers's Adm'r v. Forsythe, 73 Ky. 394, 1874 Ky. LEXIS 63 (Ky. 1874) (decided under prior law).

  52. Sale of Exempt Property. 

 Where a creditor sells property of the debtor which is exempt from sale, the creditor may be required to account for the value of the property thus sold. Levell v. Elliott, 7 Ky. Op. 409, 1873 Ky. LEXIS 629 (Ky. Ct. App. Dec. 1, 1873) (decided under prior law).

  53. —Injunction. 

 An officer cannot be enjoined from selling under execution property claimed to be exempt unless the remedy at law is inadequate. Chesapeake, O. & S.W.R. Co. v. Reasor, 6 Ky. L. Rptr. 298 (1884) (decided under prior law).

  54. —Waiver of Rights. 

 The fact that the widow of the debtor was present at the sale under attachment of exempt property, and made no objection, does not operate as waiver of her rights to the exemption. Myers's Adm'r v. Forsythe, 73 Ky. 394, 1874 Ky. LEXIS 63 (Ky. 1874) (decided under prior law).

 One who stands by and permits his property to be sold without asserting any claim of exemption waives any such right of exemption. Covert v. Bethel, 10 Ky. Op. 50, 1878 Ky. LEXIS 131 (Ky. Ct. App. Sept. 28, 1878) (decided under prior law).

 Where a debtor, who owns certain property, part of which is exempt, and who has a right to elect which of several pieces shall be sold, is present at the sale and makes no objection, his right of election is waived and the sheriff may sell whichever piece he may deem proper. Westerfield v. Moreland, 11 Ky. Op. 247, 3 Ky. L. Rptr. 324, 1881 Ky. LEXIS 267 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 1, 1881) (decided under prior law).

 The indiscriminate sale by a debtor of property, some of which is exempt and some not, and a mingling of the proceeds, amount to a waiver. Rasco v. Sheet & Son, 8 Ky. L. Rptr. 703 (1887) (decided under prior law).

  55. Surrender. 

 Where a debtor, in order to protect the surety on a replevin bond, informed the officer that he would surrender certain exempt property, and the officer accepted the offer, the debtor cannot afterwards withdraw the surrender by claiming his exemptions. Ponder v. Webb, 10 Ky. Op. 745, 1 Ky. L. Rptr. 335, 1880 Ky. LEXIS 356 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 13, 1880) (decided under prior law).

  56. Tobacco. 

 Under exemption law relating to breadstuffs and animal food, tobacco was not exempt as article of food. Stone v. Hales & Moss, 7 Ky. Op. 110, 1873 Ky. LEXIS 452 (Ky. Ct. App. Sept. 20, 1873). See Hayden v. Crutchfield's Ex'r, 11 Ky. Op. 214, 3 Ky. L. Rptr. 83, 1881 Ky. LEXIS 243 (Ky. Ct. App. June 25, 1881) (decided under prior law).

  57. Waiver. 

 Agreement to waive benefit of exemption laws was void. Moxley v. Regan, 73 Ky. 156, 1873 Ky. LEXIS 69 (Ky. 1873). See Harrison's Trustee v. Kuntz, 8 Ky. Op. 688, 1876 Ky. LEXIS 201 (Ky. Ct. App. Apr. 26, 1876) (decided under prior law).

  Cited in: 

 In re Hopper, 79 F. Supp. 910, 1948 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2395 (D. Ky. 1948); Bays v. Mahan, 362 S.W.2d 732, 1962 Ky. LEXIS 265 (1962); Holt v. Brown, 336 F. Supp. 2, 1971 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11011 (W.D. Ky. 1971); In re Dubrock, 5 B.R. 353, 1980 Bankr. LEXIS 4748 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1980); In re Coomes, 20 B.R. 290, 1982 Bankr. LEXIS 4481 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1982); In re T L G Computing Services, Inc., 20 B.R. 568, 1982 Bankr. LEXIS 3987 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1982); In re Zaicek, 29 B.R. 31, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 6408 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983); Credithrift of America v. Lawson, 52 B.R. 369, 1985 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16969 (E.D. Ky. 1985); In re Lyvers, 179 B.R. 837, 1995 Bankr. LEXIS 347 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1995); Fraley v. Commercial Credit, 189 B.R. 398, 1995 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17918 (W.D. Ky. 1995); Lichtenstein v. Barbanel, 322 S.W.3d 27, 2010 Ky. LEXIS 121 (Ky. 2010).

 Opinions of Attorney General. 

 The exemption for the employee is automatic and should be deducted by the employer before forwarding the nonexempt net wages to the court. OAG 66-408.

 The 75 percent exemption is to be computed upon the net earnings prior to and without deduction of the court costs, leaving the debtor 75 percent of such net earnings. OAG 66-505.

 A garnishment covers both income earned as of the date of service on the employer and income that is earned between that date and the end of the pay period during which service is made. OAG 66-522.

 A garnishment does not retroactively cover income earned during a previous pay period but not paid until after service. OAG 66-522.

 The exemptions allowed by this section are an exception to subsection (1) of former KRS 92.650. OAG 67-478.

 Although this section must be read in pari materia with KRS 134.430, the exemptions found in subsection (1) of this section take precedence over the amount of property that may be sold under subsection (1) of KRS 134.430, since this section was last amended after KRS 134.430. OAG 72-122.

 A motor vehicle meeting the described requisites of subsection (1) of this section is exempt from the distress procedure of the sheriff as described in KRS 134.430. OAG 72-212.

 If a motor vehicle is valued at more than $1,500, then it is subject to distraint under KRS 134.430 to the extent of the value in excess of $1,500, but the sheriff would have to turn back to the owner any sale proceeds up to the $1,500 exempted amount and any excess over the $1,500 after the payment of the tax claim. OAG 72-212.

 An arrearage of child support or maintenance payments which payments accrued as the result of a court order would come within the exception found in subsection (3)(a) of this section, and an entire amount of any pay for any period could be subjected to the satisfaction of an amount in arrears. OAG 72-682.

 Where an order for back child support does not exhaust the total funds available for garnishment under subsection (2) of this section, inferior garnishments must be honored in the same pay period so long as the total does not exceed the lesser of the figures provided in subsections (a) and (b) of subsection (2) of this section. OAG 74-506.

 A motor vehicle fitting the description of subsection (1) of this section is exempt from KRS 134.430 if the vehicle is valued at not more than $1,500, but, if the vehicle is valued at more than $1,500 then it is subject to distraint to the extent of the value in excess of $1,500, and the sheriff would have to turn back to the owner any sale proceeds up to the $1,500 exempted amount and any excess over the $1,500 after the payment of the tax claim. OAG 78-584.

 Under the provisions of subsection (4) of this section, a prior lien on personal property of the defendant granted voluntarily by defendant is not subject to exemption from execution; however, the sheriff would have a duty to ascertain the existence of prior liens of record in his county and so advise potential purchases at the sale. OAG 84-7.

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Cross-References. 

Baggage and personal property of guests not exempt from seizure or sale under hotel or boardinghouse keeper’s lien, KRS 376.350.

Confederate pension, exempt from attachment or other process, KRS 206.170.

Crops, no exemption allowed on as against lien for money furnished to raise crop and for subsistence, KRS 383.110.

Growing crops, when may be levied on, KRS 426.170.

Personal estate of intestate, exemption allowed widow or children, KRS 391.030.

Public assistance, exempt from levy and execution, KRS 205.220.

Teachers’ retirement funds, exempt from attachment, KRS 161.700.

Unemployment compensation fund, exempt from levy and attachment, KRS 341.470.

Voluntary assignment does not pass exempt property unless included in the deed, KRS 379.020.

Voluntary assignment, proceedings concerning exempt property, KRS 379.080.

Workers’ compensation, exempt from claims of creditors, KRS 342.180.

  Kentucky Bench & Bar. 

Laramore, Final Judgment: The Beginning of the End, Vol. 58, No. 3, Summer 1994, Ky. Bench & Bar 8.

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Debtor Exemptions in Personal Property — Proposals for Modernization, 52 Ky. L.J. 456 (1964).

Lee, An Analysis of Kentucky’s New Exemption Law, 55 Ky. L.J. 618 (1967).

Stengel, Should States Adopt the Uniform Consumer Credit Code?, 60 Ky. L.J. 8 (1971).

Murrell, The Uniform Consumer Credit Code: Changes It Would Make in Kentucky Law, 60 Ky. L.J. 62 (1971).

Bland, Insolvencies in Farming and Agribusinesses, 73 Ky. L.J. 795 (1984-85).

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Affidavit of Exemptions, Form 151.27.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Complaint by Judgment Creditor to Enforce Execution Lien against Real Estate, Form 151.37.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Complaint by Owner of Property Sold Under Execution Against Judgment Creditor and its Surety for Wrongful Execution and Sale, Form 150.36.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Order Allowing Exemptions, Form 150.34.

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, Actions, § 17.1.

  ALR 

What is “necessary” furniture entitled to exemption from seizure for debt. 41 A.L.R.3d 607.


427.020.  Appraisement of defendant’s property — Selection by defendant.

Text

The officer making the levy shall, prior to selling the defendant’s property, ascertain the value of the property by an appraisal made by two (2) discreet, disinterested persons, one (1) appointed by the officer and one (1) appointed by the defendant. The defendant may select which items of his property he chooses to retain so long as the total value of the property retained does not exceed the value of the exemptions set out in this chapter.

History

History.
1698: amend. Acts 1966, ch. 157, § 2.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  1. Appraisal. 

 It was the duty of the officer to have the appraisement made if the property was exempt, whether or not the debtor claimed it as exempt, and if he failed to do this, and sold, he was liable, whatever the value of the property was. Stirman v. Smith, 10 S.W. 131, 10 Ky. L. Rptr. 665 (1888) (decided under prior law).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Cross-References. 

Appraisal of real property sold under execution, KRS 426.200.

Cattle not exempt under livery stable keeper’s or agister’s lien, KRS 376.410.

  Collateral References. 

  ALR 

What is “necessary” furniture entitled to exemption from seizure for debt. 41 A.L.R.3d 607.


427.030.  Debtor’s tools exempt.

Text

The tools, not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300) in value, of any individual debtor necessary in his trade are exempt from levy under execution, attachment, distress for rent or fee-bill. One (1) motor vehicle not exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500) in value and its necessary accessories, including one (1) spare tire, of a mechanic or other skilled artisan primarily engaged in the replacement, repair, or emergency servicing of essential mechanical, electrical or other equipment in general use, is exempt from execution, attachment, garnishment, distress warrant or fee-bill.

History

History.
1699: amend. Acts 1966, ch. 157, § 3; 1980, ch. 236, § 2, effective April 9, 1980.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Construction.

2. Who May Claim Exemption.

  1. Construction. 

 The tools-of-trade provision under this section co-exists with but does not displace the lien avoidance section of 11 USCS § 522(f) and in cases commenced after April 9, 1980, the avoidance of a lien against a tool of trade will only be realized to a maximum of $1,300. In re Dubrock, 5 B.R. 353, 1980 Bankr. LEXIS 4748 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1980).

  2. Who May Claim Exemption. 

 The tool-of-trade exemption for an art camera and processor could only be used by the artist debtor and not by both that debtor and his nonartist wife, with whom he filed bankruptcy since only the debtor who uses the specified equipment in his trade can claim that equipment as a tool of trade. In re Jeffries, 18 B.R. 682, 1982 Bankr. LEXIS 4405 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1982).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Bench & Bar. 

Bland, The Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978: An Overview, Vol. 44, No. 1, January 1980, Ky. Bench & Bar 8.

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Kentucky Law Survey, Graham, Domestic Relations, 73 Ky. L.J. 379 (1984-85).

  Collateral References. 

  ALR 

Exemptions of motor vehicle from seizure for debt. 37 A.L.R.2d 714.

As tool, instrument and implement. 37 A.L.R.2d 714.


427.040.  Professional libraries and vehicle exempt.

Text

The professional library, office equipment, instruments and furnishings of a minister, attorney, physician, surgeon, chiropractor, veterinarian, or dentist, necessary in the practice of such profession, and not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000) in value shall be exempt from execution, attachment, garnishment, distress warrant or fee-bill. In addition to the above exemption one (1) motor vehicle not exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500) in value with necessary accessories, including one (1) spare tire shall be exempted.

History

History.
1700: amend. Acts 1966, ch. 157, § 4; 1980, ch. 236, § 3, effective April 9, 1980.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  Cited: 

 In re Burch, 34 B.R. 294, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 5100 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Bench & Bar. 

Bland, The Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978: An Overview, Vol. 44, No. 1, January 1980, Ky. Bench & Bar 8.

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Kentucky Law Survey, Graham, Domestic Relations, 73 Ky. L.J. 379 (1984-85).

  ALR 

What is “necessary” furniture entitled to exemption from seizure for debt. 41 A.L.R.3d 607.


427.045.  Exemptions not applicable to claims for child support.

Text

The exemptions provided in KRS 342.180 and KRS 427.010 to 427.040 shall not apply for executions, attachments, or garnishments, issued for the collection of maintenance of minor children.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1966, ch. 157, § 5(g); 1980, ch. 188, § 297, effective July 15, 1980; 1994, ch. 330, § 20, effective July 15, 1994.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  1. Foreclosure Proceeds. 

 Pursuant to KRS 427.045, a father was not entitled to half of the proceeds from a forced foreclosure sale, which was initiated to reduce his support arrearage; however, because the father had an appropriate remedy under KRS 387.290(1), (3) for the appointment of a suitable curator, the trial court erred in creating a trust. Reinle v. Commonwealth, 170 S.W.3d 417, 2005 Ky. App. LEXIS 167 (Ky. Ct. App. 2005).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Kentucky Law Survey, Graham, Domestic Relations, 73 Ky. L.J. 379 (1984-85).

  Treatises 

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, Support of Children (On Dissolution), § 27.13.


427.050.  Out-of-state law applicable when wages earned and payable out of state — Exceptions.

Text

(1) The law of the state wherein wages are earned and payable relating to exemptions shall apply to all garnishments served in the State of Kentucky, except that Kentucky law shall exclusively apply:

  (a) Where the defendant was personally served with process in the State of Kentucky; or

  (b) Where the defendant was a bona fide resident of the State of Kentucky when the subject debt arose; or

  (c) Where the defendant was a bona fide resident of the State of Kentucky when the cause of action arose.

(2) Where the law of a state other than Kentucky applies to a particular garnishment, the garnishee may plead such exemption law.

History

History.
1701a: amend. Acts 1970, ch. 217, § 4.

Annotations

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Bench & Bar. 

Bland, The Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978: An Overview, Vol. 44, No. 1, January 1980, Ky. Bench & Bar 8.


427.060.  Homestead and burial plot exemptions — Exceptions.

Text

In addition to any exemption of personal property, an individual debtor’s aggregate interest, not to exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000) in value, in real or personal property that such debtor or a dependent of such debtor uses as a permanent residence in this state, or in a burial plot for such debtor or a dependent of such debtor is exempt from sale under execution, attachment or judgment, except to foreclose a mortgage given by the owner of a homestead or for purchase money due thereon. This exemption shall not apply if the debt or liability existed prior to the purchase of the property or the erection of the improvements thereon.

History

History.
1702: amend. Acts 1980, ch. 236, § 4, effective April 9, 1980.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS

2. Purpose.

3. Construction.

4. Appurtenances.

6. Land.

  7. — Separate Tracts.

  8. — Unimproved.

  9. — Surface.

  10. — Coowners.

  11. — Descent, Devise or Gift.

  12. — Life Estates.

  13. — Limitations on Size.

14. Judgments.

15. Sureties.

16. Nonresidents.

17. Foreign States.

18. Mortgages.

19. Bankruptcy.

20. Divorce.

  21. — Alimony.

22. Family.

  23. — Dependents.

  24. — Loss.

25. Wife.

  26. — Property.

27. Ownership.

28. Bona Fide Housekeepers.

29. Waiver of Rights.

30. Proceeds.

  31. — From Execution Sale.

  32. — Reinvestment.

33. Conveyances.

  34. — Fraudulent.

  35. — Joinder of Spouse.

36. Inheritance.

  37. — Conversion into Homestead.

  38. — Prior Debts.

39. Abandonment.

  40. — Intent.

  41. — Repeated Absences.

  42. — Temporary Absence.

43. Occupancy.

  44. — Permanent Residence.

  45. — By Tenant.

  46. — Rental.

  47. — Intent.

  48. — Adjacent Property.

49. Construction of Home.

  50. — Debts Created.

51. Purchase.

  52. — Time Debt Created.

  53. — Source of Funds Used.

  54. — — Sale of Homestead.

  55. — — Sale of Personalty.

  56. — — Exempt Money.

  57. — — Partial Payment.

58. Intent of Claimant.

59. Realtor’s Lien.

60. Federal Tax Liens.

61. Homestead Laws.

62. Attachment.

63. Construction of Home.

64. Housekeeper with Family.

65. Inheritance.

66. Liens.

67. Ownership.

68. Petitions.

69. Proceeds.

70. Priorities.

71. Purchase Money.

72. Purchase.

  73. — Time Debt Created.

74. Remainders and Reversions.

  1. In General. 

 In determination of homestead exemption, nature or quantum of estate of debtor was immaterial, since homestead right was exemption privilege and not estate in land. Turner v. Browning's Adm'r, 128 Ky. 79, 107 S.W. 318, 32 Ky. L. Rptr. 891, 1908 Ky. LEXIS 34 (Ky. 1908).

 “Homestead” right is not estate in land, but is exemption from execution, and it attaches to any realty that can be seized under execution, whatever nature or quantum of estate. Howard v. Mitchell, 268 Ky. 429, 105 S.W.2d 128, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 775 (Ky. 1936). See Foreman v. Cook, 277 Ky. 812, 127 S.W.2d 856, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 737 (Ky. 1939); First Nat'l Bank v. Oliver, 286 Ky. 286, 150 S.W.2d 894, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 258 (Ky. 1941).

 Homestead is not an estate in land, but a privilege, and homestead exemption is purely statutory. First Nat'l Bank v. Oliver, 286 Ky. 286, 150 S.W.2d 894, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 258 (Ky. 1941).

  2. Purpose. 

 Purpose of this section was to provide homes for persons intended to benefit from creation of homestead right. Brewer v. Brewer, 268 Ky. 625, 105 S.W.2d 582, 1937 Ky. LEXIS 491 (Ky. 1937).

  3. Construction. 

 This section should be liberally construed and enforced so as to guarantee to family, in every case, protection and benefits intended by its enactment. Williams v. Evans' Adm'r, 247 Ky. 105, 56 S.W.2d 710, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 355 (Ky. 1933). See Richardson v. Richardson, 252 Ky. 235, 67 S.W.2d 7, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 762 (Ky. 1934).

 Under this section, a homestead is exempted from execution by levy and sale. Foreman v. Cook, 277 Ky. 812, 127 S.W.2d 856, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 737 (Ky. 1939).

 To satisfy the intention and requirements of this section, “permanent residence” should be construed to mean “domicile.” In re Washington, 17 B.R. 52, 1981 Bankr. LEXIS 2702 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1981).

 The term “homestead,” in the popular sense, signifies the family dwelling house and appurtenant lands used in connection therewith, but in the statutory sense, “homestead” means the land on which the owner’s dwelling house is located. In re McMahon, 60 B.R. 632, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 6120 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

  4. Appurtenances. 

 A shed erected on homestead property under an agreement between the homesteader and the person building it that the latter could remove it at any time did not belong to the homesteader, nor add to the value of her property in such a manner that the homestead, to the extent of the value of such shed, could be subjected to the payment of a debt of the homesteader contracted before the erection of the shed. Weber v. Gardiner, 80 S.W. 481, 26 Ky. L. Rptr. 44 (1904).

 Where homestead was sold and proceeds used to buy lot, storehouse built thereon was “appurtenances” notwithstanding small rental was had from its use. Green & Sons v. Pennington, 123 Ky. 837, 97 S.W. 766, 30 Ky. L. Rptr. 203, 1906 Ky. LEXIS 222 (Ky. 1906).

  5. Improvements. 

 Where old building was torn down and some of material was worked into new building, result was erection of improvement, and exemption did not apply. Butler v. Davis, 23 S.W. 220, 15 Ky. L. Rptr. 273 (1893).

 The painting of a dwelling house occupied as a homestead after the contracting of a debt by the homesteader is not such an improvement as will render the homestead subject to the payment of the debt to the value of the improvement. Weber v. Gardiner, 80 S.W. 481, 26 Ky. L. Rptr. 44 (1904).

 Plaintiff, who agreed to erect improvements on part of defendant’s land in return for receiving such land, had action against defendant for value of such improvement, and for enforcement of lien thereof, notwithstanding fact that such land was defendant’s homestead. Robards v. Robards, 85 S.W. 718, 27 Ky. L. Rptr. 494 (1905).

 Homestead improvements for comfort and convenience did not make such homestead subject to debts incurred prior to such improvements. Cowan McClung & Co. v. Evans, 101 S.W. 964, 31 Ky. L. Rptr. 226 (1907).

 Repair and additions for comfortable enjoyment do not cause loss of homestead exemption unless value is thereby increased to over $1,000. Graham v. Humm, 191 Ky. 28, 229 S.W. 80, 1921 Ky. LEXIS 265 (Ky. 1921).

  6. Land. 

 Debtor was not allowed to claim homestead exemption on lot adjoining his homestead lot. Tohermes v. Beiser, 93 Ky. 415, 20 S.W. 379, 14 Ky. L. Rptr. 440, 1892 Ky. LEXIS 110 (Ky. 1892) (decided under prior law).

  7. — Separate Tracts. 

 The right of homestead is not limited to one tract of land on which is situated the dwelling house, but may extend to an adjoining tract, where the aggregate value of both does not exceed $1,000.  Franks v. Lucas, 77 Ky. 395, 1878 Ky. LEXIS 88 (Ky. 1878) (decided under prior law).

 A portion of the homestead may be separate from that on which the dwelling is situated, if it be necessary to the claimants as part of the homestead, and can be conveniently used for that purpose. Nichols v. Sennet, 12 Ky. Op. 38, 4 Ky. L. Rptr. 889, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 123 (Ky. Ct. App. Apr. 14, 1883). See Watson v. Strunett, 10 Ky. Op. 259, 1879 Ky. LEXIS 157 (Ky. Ct. App. Mar. 8, 1879) (decided under prior law).

 The exempted land need not all be in one parcel provided that it is capable of continuous and necessary use as a part of the homestead by the reasonable exertions of the homestead claimant. Nickols v. Sennett, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 199 (1883) (decided under prior law).

 Where parcels of land, lying apart, have been connected by a private passway, and used together as one farm, a removal from one portion to the other is not a change of homestead so as to render the portion last resided on subject to debts contracted before the removal. Ross v. Sweeny, 15 S.W. 357, 12 Ky. L. Rptr. 861 (1891). See Slaughter v. Karn, 23 S.W. 791, 15 Ky. L. Rptr. 429 (1893) (decided under prior law).

 Where a debtor’s dwelling house and the tract of land on which it stands are worth less than $1,000, he may make up his homestead exemption out of another tract, which is used as a part of the homestead, though the two tracts do not adjoin. Donaldson v. Richart, 60 S.W. 405, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 1268 (1901). See Gaar, Scott & Co. v. Reesor, 91 S.W. 717, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 1308 (1906); Farmer v. Hampton, 154 Ky. 83, 156 S.W. 1041, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 19 (Ky. 1913).

 Moving off homestead tract into better house nearby did not affect homestead right where both places were kept as home and both were valued at less than $1,000. Turner v. Browning's Adm'r, 128 Ky. 79, 107 S.W. 318, 32 Ky. L. Rptr. 891, 1908 Ky. LEXIS 34 (Ky. 1908).

 Where landowner moved to different tract and continued to partly cultivate original tract, he retained homestead in original tract even though he rented part of it. Frazier v. Potter, 150 Ky. 127, 150 S.W. 19, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 847 (Ky. 1912).

 Husband, living with his wife on her property, was not entitled to homestead in distant farm not occupied as homestead and used by him purely as investment or source of income. Forsythe v. Morgantown Deposit Bank, 252 Ky. 680, 68 S.W.2d 14, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 842 (Ky. 1934).

  8. — Unimproved. 

 The exemption granted by this section is limited to land upon which is located the dwelling house of the owner and a defendant was not entitled to an exemption on a 60-acre tract of unimproved land which contained no dwelling. Lunsford v. Witt, 309 S.W.2d 348, 1958 Ky. LEXIS 350 (Ky. 1958).

  9. — Surface. 

 Only right included under “homestead”was use of land surface. Brandenburg v. Petroleum Exploration, 218 Ky. 557, 291 S.W. 757, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 190 (Ky. 1927).

  10. — Coowners. 

 Coowner was entitled to homestead, especially if coowners were husband and wife, and coowning husband has homestead in his undivided interest therein. Hensley v. Lovely, 250 Ky. 832, 64 S.W.2d 157, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 788 (Ky. 1933).

  11. — Descent, Devise or Gift. 

 Denial of right of exemption, to person who purchases land, as to pre-existing debts does not apply where such land was obtained through descent, devise or gift. Deboe v. Brown, 231 Ky. 682, 22 S.W.2d 111, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 350 (Ky. 1929). See O'Neal v. Turney's Ex'x, 222 Ky. 361, 300 S.W. 913, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 939 (Ky. 1927).

  12. — Life Estates. 

 The holder of a life estate in land is entitled to homestead. Adams v. Adams, 10 Ky. Op. 373, 1879 Ky. LEXIS 234 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 24, 1879). See Robinson v. Smithey, 80 Ky. 636, 4 Ky. L. Rptr. 541, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 10 (Ky. 1883); English v. B. Studicker & Co., 11 Ky. Op. 947, 4 Ky. L. Rptr. 721, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 356 (Ky. Ct. App. Feb. 22, 1883) (decided under prior law).

 Homestead exemption, for debtor with life estate, was allowed in tract of land of value of $1,000, and not such quantity of land that debtor’s life estate therein would be worth $1,000. Todd's Ex'r v. First Nat'l Bank, 173 Ky. 60, 190 S.W. 468, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 408 (Ky. 1917). See McDowell v. Grubbs, 116 Ky. 751, 76 S.W. 846, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 1020, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 245 (Ky. 1903).

  13. — Limitations on Size. 

 A debtor may exempt up to $5,000 in a single piece of property which includes the residence, without any fixed limitations on the size of the tract of land upon which that residence is situated; therefore, the debtors were entitled to a homestead exemption in the entire 55-acre farm where their permanent residence was located. In re Gill, 61 B.R. 201, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 6004 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

  14. Judgments. 

 Former judgment that defendant fraudulently conveyed claimed land to his wife barred defendant’s right to homestead interest in such land, where after judgment such land was sold to claimants in execution sale. Buffington v. Mosby, 51 S.W. 192, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 297 (1899).

 Homestead was not exempt from execution under judgment for costs entered under judgment for costs entered against defendants before homestead was purchased. Mullins v. Robinson, 225 Ky. 648, 9 S.W.2d 988, 1928 Ky. LEXIS 836 (Ky. 1928).

 It was not necessary for creditor’s claim to have been secured by a judgment lien in order to come within the exception to the homestead exemption found in this section. In re Bush, 196 B.R. 378, 1995 Bankr. LEXIS 2048 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1995).

  15. Sureties. 

 Homesteads of sureties of sheriff were liable to execution, in favor of state, which was issued on judgment rendered against such sheriff and his sureties for public dues, and thus such homesteads were also liable to claims of cosureties for contribution. Hutson's Adm'rs v. Combs, 110 Ky. 762, 62 S.W. 709, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 231, 1901 Ky. LEXIS 128 (Ky. 1901).

  16. Nonresidents. 

 The right of exemption depends upon the present and actual purpose and intention of the debtor to use and enjoy the property sought to be exempted as a home for himself and family, and does not exist where the residence of the debtor is permanently located elsewhere. Wilson v. Stoner, 5 Ky. Op. 751, 1872 Ky. LEXIS 361 (Ky. Ct. App. Nov. 23, 1872). See Brown Bros. Brown, Bro. & Co. v. Martin & Co., 67 Ky. 47, 1868 Ky. LEXIS 77 (Ky. 1868) (decided under prior law).

 Homestead exemption did not apply to in-state property of nonresident. Lyons v. Adams, 99 S.W. 900, 30 Ky. L. Rptr. 870 (1907).

  17. Foreign States. 

 Homestead exemption applied against debts contracted in different state. Moody v. Barker, 188 Ky. 401, 222 S.W. 89, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 292 (Ky. 1920).

 Although note sued on was executed in different state, defendant was nevertheless entitled to homestead exemption in real estate in this state. Pinson v. Murphy, 220 Ky. 464, 295 S.W. 442, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 556 (Ky. 1927).

 Defendant who admitted allegation that under foreign law he had no homestead right in attached realty was nevertheless allowed to claim exemptions. Pinson v. Murphy, 220 Ky. 464, 295 S.W. 442, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 556 (Ky. 1927).

 Homestead exemption rights were applied under law of forum. Pinson v. Murphy, 220 Ky. 464, 295 S.W. 442, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 556 (Ky. 1927).

  18. Mortgages. 

 Wife was not entitled to homestead exemption as against claim for purchase money, notwithstanding she did not join with husband in purchase money mortgage. Ratliff v. Anderson & Ratliff, 195 Ky. 320, 242 S.W. 35, 1922 Ky. LEXIS 311 (Ky. 1922).

 Failure of wife to join her husband in mortgaging lot to obtain money for building a house does not give her the right to claim homestead exemption as against the debt so incurred. Norvell v. Faulk, 282 Ky. 591, 139 S.W.2d 428, 1940 Ky. LEXIS 217 (Ky. 1940).

  19. Bankruptcy. 

 A bankrupt might not claim his homestead exemption from property recovered by the trustee after a preference or fraudulent transfer. In re Grisanti, 58 F. Supp. 646, 1945 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2587 (D. Ky. 1945).

 Since the Commonwealth has chosen to opt out of the federal list of exemptions entirely, the district court has to look to this section, to determine whether the debtor is entitled to an exemption before 11 USCS § 522(f) can be applied. Commercial Credit Corp. v. Brooks, 71 B.R. 6 (W.D. Ky. 1986), aff'd, In re Brooks, 817 F.2d 104, 1987 U.S. App. LEXIS 5498 (6th Cir. Ky. 1987).

 The Legislature, in enacting this section, was balancing the need to protect the homesteads of debtors in trouble against the need to insure a ready supply of credit to the general population for the acquisition of homesteads; therefore, this section is not at odds with the Bankruptcy Code. Commercial Credit Corp. v. Brooks, 71 B.R. 6 (W.D. Ky. 1986), aff'd, In re Brooks, 817 F.2d 104, 1987 U.S. App. LEXIS 5498 (6th Cir. Ky. 1987).

 Kentucky homestead exemption was available to eligible debtors at the time a petition under the Bankruptcy Code was filed where there was no pending sale of the residence; therefore, debtors were entitled to have their motions to avoid the judicial liens of the respective creditors avoided to the extent that the liens impair these valid homestead exemptions. In re Powell, 173 B.R. 338, 1994 Bankr. LEXIS 1634 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 1994).

 Under Kentucky law the homestead exemption provided for by this section is an absolute exemption available to an individual debtor upon the commencement of a bankruptcy case; motion of debtor pursuant to 11 USCS § 522(f)(1) to avoid judicial liens as liens that impair his homestead exemption was sustained. In re Lynch, 187 B.R. 536, 1995 Bankr. LEXIS 1368 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 1995).

 Where debtors’ Chapter 13 plan contained a provision to avoid a judicial lien, and the debtors never filed a motion to avoid such lien, but in turn, the creditor never made a timely objection to the plan provision as required by E.D. Ky. Bankr. R. 3015-3(a)(1), regardless of the procedural irregularities, the bankruptcy court exercised its discretion and held that the lien could not be avoided because the lien did not impair the debtors’ homestead exemption pursuant to KRS 427.060. In re Litteral, 2004 Bankr. LEXIS 1749 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. Nov. 15, 2004).

  20. Divorce. 

 Husband’s homestead was exempt as against attorney’s fees and costs from subsequently dismissed divorce action by wife. Nunn v. Page, 134 Ky. 698, 121 S.W. 442, 1909 Ky. LEXIS 408 (Ky. 1909).

  21. — Alimony. 

 Husband’s homestead right did not apply as against alimony decree. Pearson v. Pearson, 166 Ky. 91, 178 S.W. 1164, 1915 Ky. LEXIS 637 (Ky. 1915).

  22. Family. 

 Mere aggregation of individuals occupying same home is not alone sufficient to constitute family under this section, and there must be legal family head who is naturally, legally or morally under duty to support others in household. Owens v. Altsheller & Co., 263 Ky. 727, 93 S.W.2d 844, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 245 (Ky. 1936). See Deboe v. Brown, 231 Ky. 682, 22 S.W.2d 111, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 350 (Ky. 1929).

  23. — Dependents. 

 Commonwealth could not subject its debtor’s homestead to payment of expenses of keeping his wife in one of its asylums. Central Kentucky Lunatic Asylum v. Craven, 98 Ky. 105, 32 S.W. 291, 17 Ky. L. Rptr. 667, 1895 Ky. LEXIS 22 (Ky. 1895).

 Debtor’s dependent granddaughter constituted “family.” Collins v. Gibson, 54 S.W. 945, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 1338, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 363 (Ky. Ct. App. 1900). See Ragsdale, Cooper & Co. v. Watkins, 76 S.W. 45, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 506 (1903).

  24. — Loss. 

 Debtor, whose family was lost by death, marriage, or other means, did not thereby lose his homestead. Eastern Kentucky Asylum for Insane v. Cottle, 143 Ky. 719, 137 S.W. 235, 1911 Ky. LEXIS 490 (Ky. 1911). See Eastern State Hospital v. Cottle, 201 Ky. 377, 256 S.W. 1101, 256 S.W. 1102, 1923 Ky. LEXIS 299 (Ky. 1923).

  25. Wife. 

 Wife was entitled to exemption where she occupied her own land with her husband and children. Herring v. Johnston, 72 S.W. 793, 24 Ky. L. Rptr. 1940, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 516 (Ky. Ct. App. 1903).

 Where state gets judgment against land and then buys such land at execution sale, wife of judgment debtor cannot afterwards claim homestead right, since right is now extinguished. Fields' Heirs v. Napier, 80 S.W. 1110, 26 Ky. L. Rptr. 240 (1904).

 Creditors of wife, for debts which she incurred before marriage, could not take land which she inherited and which she and her subsequent husband homesteaded, since such husband was entitled to homestead exemption therein. Holder's Adm'r v. Holder, 120 Ky. 802, 87 S.W. 1100, 27 Ky. L. Rptr. 1171, 1905 Ky. LEXIS 157 (Ky. 1905).

 Vendor’s lien was good as against wife of purchaser of homestead. Matney v. Williams, 89 S.W. 678, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 494 (1905).

 Wife’s pleading for homestead exemption was insufficient in absence of allegations that she was housekeeper or that she and husband occupied property in question. Eversole v. First Nat'l Bank, 118 S.W. 961 (Ky. 1909).

  26. — Property. 

 Abandoned wife could share in homestead by having part of it set aside for her use or by divesting husband of title to part of it in alimony decree. Nunn v. Page, 134 Ky. 698, 121 S.W. 442, 1909 Ky. LEXIS 408 (Ky. 1909).

 Married woman who owned property in her own name could claim homestead exemption, notwithstanding she was not family head. Moody v. Barker, 188 Ky. 401, 222 S.W. 89, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 292 (Ky. 1920).

 Husband had no right to homestead in wife’s land during her life, and he could not unite her homestead hypothetically with his land to give it character it did not of itself possess. Covington Bros. & Co. v. Byrns, 230 Ky. 66, 18 S.W.2d 870, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 13 (Ky. 1929). See Forsythe v. Morgantown Deposit Bank, 252 Ky. 680, 68 S.W.2d 14, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 842 (Ky. 1934).

  27. Ownership. 

 Homestead right required ownership and occupancy of estate. Evansville Coffin Co. v. Sumner, 189 Ky. 839, 226 S.W. 363, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 523 (Ky. 1920). See Foreman v. Cook, 277 Ky. 812, 127 S.W.2d 856, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 737 (Ky. 1939).

  28. Bona Fide Housekeepers. 

 Widower could not qualify as housekeeper where his married daughter lived with him, and her husband, while away often, was not legally or actually separated from her. Louisville Banking Co. v. Anderson, 106 Ky. 744, 44 S.W. 636, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 1839, 1899 Ky. LEXIS 6 (Ky. 1899), modified, Louisville Bkg. Co. v. Anderson, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 373.

 One who, having a wife and infant child and a house which he has occupied as a homestead, induces a daughter, because of the infirmities of himself and wife and their inability to provide for themselves, to move into the house with them and to assume its expense and care is still a housekeeper with a family. Holburn v. Pfanmiller's Adm'r, 114 Ky. 831, 71 S.W. 940, 24 Ky. L. Rptr. 1613, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 47 (Ky. 1903).

 Wife living apart from undivorced husband was bona fide housekeeper, even though he contributed to support of her and her family. Lee & Hughes v. Hughes, 77 S.W. 386, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 1201 (1903).

 Evidence that person had bastard children by woman who lived with him part of time, and that he helped support the woman and children, was not sufficient to show that he was a “bona fide housekeeper.” Castle v. Allen, 294 Ky. 416, 172 S.W.2d 58, 1943 Ky. LEXIS 477 (Ky. 1943).

  29. Waiver of Rights. 

 Vendor’s retention of lien on all crops raised on vendee’s land could not include statutory exemption of food provisions to sustain vendee’s family, and such exemptions were not waived by vendee in purchase money note. Columbia Finance & Trust Co. v. Morgan, 45 S.W. 65, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 1765, 1898 Ky. LEXIS 263 (Ky. Ct. App. 1898).

 Where commission sold debtor’s land and debtor failed to plead entitlement to homestead, fact that commissioner did not provide for exemption could not then be excepted to by debtor. Davidson v. Dishman, 59 S.W. 326, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 940 (1900).

 Homestead exemption was waived by mortgage where language of mortgage instrument evidenced intention to convey entire interest, and no express waiver was required. Carr v. Britton, 267 Ky. 802, 103 S.W.2d 300, 1937 Ky. LEXIS 396 (Ky. 1937).

 In the absence of action by a creditor, there can be no waiver of the right to claim homestead arising out of mere silence. First Nat'l Bank v. Oliver, 286 Ky. 286, 150 S.W.2d 894, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 258 (Ky. 1941).

  30. Proceeds. 

 Proceeds from sale of land could not be claimed as homestead by bankrupt, even though his father had provided for such sale and proceeds as bequest to him. In re Goetz, 28 F. Supp. 689, 1939 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2399 (D. Ky. 1939).

 Proceeds of homestead are exempt. Weber v. Zook, 53 S.W. 1034, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 1027, 1899 Ky. LEXIS 607 (Ky. Ct. App. 1899).

 Homestead was not exempt which was established with proceeds of sale of original homestead, where such proceeds were first used for indefinite time in trading and purchase of personality. Fitch v. Duckwall, 78 S.W. 185, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 1535 (1904).
