 Homestead exemption could be obtained at any time prior to distribution of proceeds from property. Wilson's Adm'r v. Wilson, 288 Ky. 522, 156 S.W.2d 832, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 139 (Ky. 1941). See Pinson v. Murphy, 220 Ky. 464, 295 S.W. 442, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 556 (Ky. 1927).

 Where debtor and realty company entered into a contract giving company the exclusive right to sell debtor’s residence, and when it did not sell the house the debtor signed a contract with the company giving company the exclusive right to sell the residence at auction, the earlier contract was rescinded by the later contract and there was no real estate listing contract between debtor and company when the house was sold, therefore, the surplus proceeds from the sale, including the company’s purported commission, were the property of the debtor and were properly claimed as a homestead exemption under this section. In re Morris, 42 B.R. 305, 1984 Bankr. LEXIS 5013 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1984).

  31. — From Execution Sale. 

 Where defendant’s land, sufficient to pay creditor’s claim, was sold and creditor permitted proceeds of such sale to be appropriated to other uses, creditor could not then satisfy his claim out of defendant’s remaining homestead exemption, even though creditor was vendor of original property to defendant. Ralls v. Prather, 51 S.W. 318, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 322 (1899).

 Debtor could assert his homestead rights to involuntary sale proceeds at any time prior to disposition by final order. First Nat'l Bank v. Duncan, 210 Ky. 777, 276 S.W. 848, 1925 Ky. LEXIS 774 (Ky. 1925). See Marcum v. Edwards, 181 Ky. 683, 205 S.W. 798, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 603 (Ky. 1918).

  32. — Reinvestment. 

 Debtor may reinvest proceeds from sale of one homestead into another if he does so within reasonable time. J. M. Robinson, Norton & Co. v. Burnett, 174 Ky. 766, 192 S.W. 871, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 253 (Ky. 1917). See Smith v. Fourth Street Bank, 174 Ky. 647, 192 S.W. 643, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 219 (Ky. 1917).

  33. Conveyances. 

 A husband and wife have the right, with or without consideration, to convey their homestead without regard to the claims of creditors. Tong v. Eifort, 80 Ky. 152, 3 Ky. L. Rptr. 647, 1882 Ky. LEXIS 30 (Ky. Ct. App. 1882) (decided under prior law).

 One who sold part of his homestead and remained in possession as tenant of purchaser could claim homestead in unsold part upon which he built new residence. Bennett v. Baird, 81 Ky. 554, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 636, 1884 Ky. LEXIS 5 (Ky. Ct. App. 1884) (decided under prior law).

 Debtor may invest his wife or children with title to his homestead, free from claims of his creditor, by will as well as by deed. Schonbachler v. Schonbachler, 57 S.W. 232, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 314, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 675 (Ky. Ct. App. 1900). See Pendergest v. Heekin, 94 Ky. 384, 22 S.W. 605, 15 Ky. L. Rptr. 180, 1893 Ky. LEXIS 67 (Ky. 1893).

 The status of a father’s homestead exemption is not changed by his conveying title to his child, even though the conveyance be without consideration. First Nat'l Bank v. Oliver, 286 Ky. 286, 150 S.W.2d 894, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 258 (Ky. 1941).

  34. — Fraudulent. 

 The fact that conveyance by husband to wife was fraudulent did not defeat the right to homestead in land fraudulently conveyed. In re Roark, 28 F. Supp. 515, 1939 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2633 (D. Ky. 1939).

 Homestead was exempt when paid for before creation of debt, notwithstanding subsequent fraudulent conveyance to debtor’s wife. Helton v. Vanderpool, 251 Ky. 312, 64 S.W.2d 883, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 846 (Ky. 1933). See Smith v. Fourth Street Bank, 174 Ky. 647, 192 S.W. 643, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 219 (Ky. 1917).

 Where husband’s fraudulent conveyance of property to wife was set aside and wife had paid $1,000 for down payment on such property for its previous conveyance to husband, judgment creditor’s right to proceeds thereof was properly subjected to homestead in wife’s favor for $1,000, notwithstanding vendor and mortgage liens outstanding. Lyon v. Lemaster, 270 Ky. 122, 109 S.W.2d 39, 1937 Ky. LEXIS 32 (Ky. 1937).

 Homestead could be conveyed even with intent to cheat and defraud creditors. Daniels v. Coleman, 291 Ky. 789, 165 S.W.2d 804, 1942 Ky. LEXIS 324 (Ky. 1942).

  35. — Joinder of Spouse. 

 Husband, after his abandonment of his wife, had legal right to voluntarily sell and alienate his homestead without joinder of his wife. Brannon v. Bohannon, 265 Ky. 394, 96 S.W.2d 1036, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 494 (Ky. 1936).

  36. Inheritance. 

 Land which was levied upon under execution against debtor on day it descended to such debtor was exempt when he moved onto it with his family a few weeks later. Spratt v. Allen, 106 Ky. 274, 50 S.W. 270, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 1822, 1899 Ky. LEXIS 45 (Ky. 1899).

 Where portion of defendant’s original homestead was inherited, he purchased remainder, then sold everything and applied proceeds to purchase of new homestead, he was entitled to exemption for such new homestead to extent of value of inherited portion of original. McDonald v. Lowry, 50 S.W. 553, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 1939 (1899).

 When wife remarried she retained her homestead right, and when she and her husband rented property adjacent to wife’s inherited land in question, their use of such land continued their homestead exemption therein. Holder's Adm'r v. Holder, 120 Ky. 802, 87 S.W. 1100, 27 Ky. L. Rptr. 1171, 1905 Ky. LEXIS 157 (Ky. 1905).

 Farm was not exempt which was left to husband in wife’s will and on which he lived with no dependents. Jarboe v. Hayden, 133 Ky. 378, 117 S.W. 961, 1909 Ky. LEXIS 181 (Ky. 1909).

 Inherited interest in land could be set apart as homestead if divisible, or sold and proceeds invested in homestead if not divisible. Robinson v. Robinson, 142 Ky. 589, 134 S.W. 1130, 1911 Ky. LEXIS 255 (Ky. 1911).

  37. — Conversion into Homestead. 

 Debtor had reasonable time to convert inherited land into homestead. Roberts v. Adams, 96 S.W. 554, 29 Ky. L. Rptr. 848 (1906). See Cooper v. Cooper, 230 Ky. 696, 20 S.W.2d 734, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 166 (Ky. 1929).

  38. — Prior Debts. 

 Under this section, providing that homesteads shall be subject to claim for purchase money, a debt created for purchasing a homestead may be enforced against the heirs of the decedent claiming the homestead as exempt. Weber v. Weber, 76 S.W. 507, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 908 (1903).

 A husband cannot claim a homestead, in land devised to him by his wife, as against a debt of the testatrix. Dearing v. Moran, 78 S.W. 217, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 1545 (1904).

 Inherited land was exempt as against pre-existing debts. Roberts v. Adams, 96 S.W. 554, 29 Ky. L. Rptr. 848 (1906). See Roark v. Bach, 116 Ky. 457, 76 S.W. 340, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 699, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 210 (Ky. 1903).

 Where, subsequent to contraction of debt, debtor received bequest and with it purchased homestead, exception withholding exemption with respect to preexisting debts did not apply. Moody v. Barker, 188 Ky. 401, 222 S.W. 89, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 292 (Ky. 1920).

  39. Abandonment. 

 One who removes to another state with his family, and engages in business there, though he avows that he intends to return to this state, cannot claim the homestead exemption. Crush & Fleckenstein v. Stewart, 13 Ky. Op. 1130, 7 Ky. L. Rptr. 825, 1886 Ky. LEXIS 234 (Ky. Ct. App. May 27, 1886). See Williams v. Rose, 13 Ky. Op. 168, 6 Ky. L. Rptr. 517, 1885 Ky. LEXIS 103 (Ky. Ct. App. Jan. 13, 1885) (decided under prior law).

 Where debtor sold his land, established permanent residence in another state, then returned to this state and purchased new homestead, such homestead was not exempt from debts incurred before debtor moved to such other state. Coldwell v. Seiver, 85 Ky. 38, 2 S.W. 651 (Ky. 1887) (decided under prior law).

 Where, at the time of an assignment for creditors, a debtor was not occupying property as a homestead, and continued a nonresident for two (2) years before filing a petition claiming it as such, he will have lost his right by abandonment. Marshall v. Applegate, 10 S.W. 805, 10 Ky. L. Rptr. 811 (1889) (decided under prior law).

 Husband’s homestead right was not abandoned when his wife refused to stay with him, since he continued in residence himself. In re Grisanti, 58 F. Supp. 646, 1945 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2587 (D. Ky. 1945).

 There was no abandonment of homestead when debtor was confined to prison. Clolinger v. Callahan, 204 Ky. 33, 263 S.W. 700, 1924 Ky. LEXIS 406 (Ky. 1924).

 Question whether a homestead has been abandoned is to be determined by particular facts. Williams v. Evans' Adm'r, 247 Ky. 105, 56 S.W.2d 710, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 355 (Ky. 1933). See Marcum v. Edwards, 181 Ky. 683, 205 S.W. 798, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 603 (Ky. 1918).

 Exemption claimed under this section can be lost only by abandonment, and afterwards may be under certain circumstances reclaimed. Brewer v. Brewer, 268 Ky. 625, 105 S.W.2d 582, 1937 Ky. LEXIS 491 (Ky. 1937).

 Because a debtor may only claim an exemption in property where he is domiciled and all the factors considered made it clear that the debtors had abandoned the Florida homestead, the debtors could not claim the essentially unlimited homestead exemption in regard to their Florida property and were limited to the Kentucky homestead exemption provided by this section. In re Vaughan, 188 B.R. 234, 1995 Bankr. LEXIS 1488 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 1995).

  40. — Intent. 

 Homestead is not abandoned by mere intent to leave without actual leaving. Lee & Hughes v. Hughes, 77 S.W. 386, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 1201 (1903).

 An actual removal to a location in another place with no intention of returning is an abandonment of a homestead. American Nat'l Bank v. Mathews, 124 S.W. 811, 1910 Ky. LEXIS 665 (Ky. 1910). See Baker v. Estridge, 154 Ky. 659, 157 S.W. 1080, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 112 (Ky. 1913); Cryer v. Conway, 181 Ky. 526, 205 S.W. 562, 1918 Ky. LEXIS 552 (Ky. 1918).

 Whether there was abandonment or not depended upon intent of claimant as shown by evidence. Smith v. Moss, 211 Ky. 226, 277 S.W. 245, 1925 Ky. LEXIS 852 (Ky. 1925).

 In determining whether there has been an abandonment of a homestead, determinative question is whether the homesteader intends to return and occupy his homestead after the termination of his temporary removal therefrom. This intent is gathered not only from his declarations but from the actions and surroundings accompanying such absence. Foreman v. Cook, 277 Ky. 812, 127 S.W.2d 856, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 737 (Ky. 1939).

  41. — Repeated Absences. 

 As long as there was intent to return, absences from property would not constitute abandonment of homestead, even where such absences were repeated. Smith v. Moss, 211 Ky. 226, 277 S.W. 245, 1925 Ky. LEXIS 852 (Ky. 1925).

  42. — Temporary Absence. 

 Temporary move to city to educate children was not homestead abandonment. Herring v. Johnston, 72 S.W. 793, 24 Ky. L. Rptr. 1940, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 516 (Ky. Ct. App. 1903). See Brandenburgh v. Rose, 110 S.W. 376, 33 Ky. L. Rptr. 585 (1908).

 Temporary move to more conveniently conduct business did not cause loss of homestead right. Ragsdale, Cooper & Co. v. Watkins, 76 S.W. 45, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 506 (1903).

 Where property was acquired before debt was created and occupied as homestead before its sale, debtor who moved temporarily and intended to return was entitled to right of homestead in proceeds of such sale. Mason v. Southern Deposit Bank, 229 Ky. 728, 17 S.W.2d 1022, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 838 (Ky. 1929).

 Husband did not abandon his homestead when he temporarily left and then returned after separation from his wife, notwithstanding he lived on adjoining property, rented such homestead, and reserved space for furniture he did not need. Foreman v. Cook, 277 Ky. 812, 127 S.W.2d 856, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 737 (Ky. 1939).

  43. Occupancy. 

 When one owns land but has no residence upon it, but has built a house on his wife’s land and resides there with his family, he cannot claim a homestead on his own land as against his creditors. Magruder v. Sparks, 9 Ky. Op. 643, 1877 Ky. LEXIS 393 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 31, 1877) (decided under prior law).

 One owning a house and lot, but who does not reside in such house, is not entitled to claim an exemption as a homestead. Hayden v. Craycroft, 9 Ky. Op. 697, 1877 Ky. LEXIS 423 (Ky. Ct. App. Nov. 16, 1877) (decided under prior law).

 Actual occupancy prior to creation of debt was not additional condition of homestead exemption. Morehead v. Morehead, 25 S.W. 750, 16 Ky. L. Rptr. 34 (1894). See Crouch v. Meguiar-Harris Co., 42 S.W. 91, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 819 (1897).

 Purchased land was not exempt where not occupied before levy of execution. Marshall v. Mahorney, 111 Ky. 157, 63 S.W. 471, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 527, 1901 Ky. LEXIS 192 (Ky. 1901).

 Inherited property was not exempt where it was not claimed or occupied as homestead before debt was incurred. Park v. Wright, 74 S.W. 712, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 128, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 351 (Ky. Ct. App. 1903).

 Barn lot could be exempted as homestead pending construction of house upon such lot to replace previously sold adjacent house. Kelley v. Ramsey, 176 Ky. 584, 195 S.W. 1111, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 84 (Ky. 1917).

 The homestead right in this state is not an estate in land but is merely a right of occupancy. Charboneau v. Hart, 211 Ky. 204, 277 S.W. 242, 1925 Ky. LEXIS 846 (Ky. 1925).

 Homestead right continues for as long as there is occupancy. Barnes v. Montjoy's Adm'r, 217 Ky. 465, 290 S.W. 349, 1926 Ky. LEXIS 108 (Ky. 1926).

  44. — Permanent Residence. 

 In order to establish a homestead exemption under this section the debtor claimant must “permanently reside” at the particular location or a dependent of the claimant must make it his permanent residence, and to satisfy the intention and requirements of this section the terms “permanent residence” should be construed to mean “domicile.” In re Jordan, 16 B.R. 590, 1981 Bankr. LEXIS 2781 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1981).

 Where the debtor claimant had moved out of his marital home more than a year prior to his filing a petition in bankruptcy, and a final decree of divorce had been entered over six (6) months prior to the filing of the petition, the debtor could not claim a homestead exemption in the marital home either as a permanent residence or on the basis of occupancy of the home by a dependent. In re Jordan, 16 B.R. 590, 1981 Bankr. LEXIS 2781 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1981).

 Both a houseboat and two boat dock slips comprised the debtors’ permanent residence and qualified for the homestead exemption pursuant to this section. In re McMahon, 60 B.R. 632, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 6120 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

  45. — By Tenant. 

 Where defendant purchased homestead, built house on it, then moved into adjacent house of his wife’s sick father temporarily so that she could care for him there, defendant’s placing of tenant in his own house until he could move into it himself constituted occupancy necessary to establish exemption therein. Derickson v. Gilespie, 32 S.W. 1084, 17 Ky. L. Rptr. 892 (1895). See Deweese v. Deweese, 121 Ky. 747, 90 S.W. 256, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 726, 1906 Ky. LEXIS 255 (Ky. 1906).

 In order to effectuate exemption, debtor must bring himself within letter and spirit of provisions, and fact of cultivating farm or having tenants thereon does not alone maintain occupancy required under such provisions. Tyler's Ex'r v. Williamson, 237 Ky. 579, 36 S.W.2d 34, 1931 Ky. LEXIS 661 (Ky. 1931).

 Where the debtor claimant had moved out of his marital home more than a year prior to his filing a petition in bankruptcy, and a final decree of divorce had been entered over six months prior to the filing of the petition, the debtor could not claim a homestead exemption in the marital home either as a permanent residence or on the basis of occupancy of the home by a dependent. In re Jordan, 16 B.R. 590, 1981 Bankr. LEXIS 2781 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1981).

 Both the houseboat and two boat dock slips comprised the debtors’ permanent residence and qualified for the homestead exemption pursuant to this section. In re McMahon, 60 B.R. 632, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 6120 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

  46. — Rental. 

 There was no exemption for house rented out by debtor, since it was not used by him as homestead. Garrison v. Penn, 66 S.W. 14, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 1775 (1902).

  47. — Intent. 

 Defendant was not entitled to claim the property as a homestead where, at the time of giving mortgage, there never had been an actual residence and use of the property as a home, but merely an intention to so occupy it at some future time. Hansford v. Holdam, 77 Ky. 210, 1878 Ky. LEXIS 62 (Ky. 1878) (decided under prior law).

 Intent to occupy is insufficient for exemption; there must be actual occupancy of homestead. Levy v. Rubarts, 34 S.W. 1078, 17 Ky. L. Rptr. 1370 (1896). See Higgins v. Higgins, 117 Ky. 725, 78 S.W. 1124, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 1824, 1904 Ky. LEXIS 241 (Ky. 1904).

 Homestead could not be claimed by debtor where he did not occupy premises at time of levy of attachment unless he was absent temporarily with fixed and constant intent to return and occupy such premises. Williams v. Evans' Adm'r, 247 Ky. 105, 56 S.W.2d 710, 1933 Ky. LEXIS 355 (Ky. 1933). See Tyler's Ex'r v. Williamson, 237 Ky. 579, 36 S.W.2d 34, 1931 Ky. LEXIS 661 (Ky. 1931).

  48. — Adjacent Property. 

 A debtor is entitled to a homestead, though the dwelling occupied by himself and family is located on land of his wife adjoining that claimed as exempt. Oliver v. Hayden, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 422 (1883) (decided under prior law).

  49. Construction of Home. 

 Homestead exemption did not apply to residence which was destroyed by fire prior to execution sale of homestead lot, where spouses moved to wife’s home and did not attempt to rebuild residence or reoccupy lot for more than two (2) years after such fire. Walters v. Jenkins' Adm'r, 279 Ky. 144, 130 S.W.2d 43, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 254 (Ky. 1939).

  50. — Debts Created. 

 Where debt was incurred for purpose of constructing home on lot owned by debtor, such debt was deemed incurred for purchase of home. Norvell v. Faulk, 282 Ky. 591, 139 S.W.2d 428, 1940 Ky. LEXIS 217 (Ky. 1940).

  51. Purchase. 

 Where plaintiff and defendant purchased jointly two tracts of land at different times and immediately divided it, plaintiff having paid more than his share of the purchase price, defendant was entitled to a homestead in his share of the tract first purchased as against the amount due by him on account of the second purchase. Crenshaw v. Crenshaw, 61 S.W. 366, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 1782, 1901 Ky. LEXIS 333 (Ky. Ct. App. 1901).

 Land obtained in settlement of will contest was not purchased. Burrow v. Maxon, 129 Ky. 578, 112 S.W. 661, 1908 Ky. LEXIS 198 (Ky. 1908).

  52. — Time Debt Created. 

 As against a debt created after the debtor had purchased his homestead and paid more than $1,000 of the purchase money, he was entitled to the full benefit of the homestead exemption, though he did not finish paying for the land until after the debt was created. Donaldson v. Richart, 60 S.W. 405, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 1268 (1901).

 Land was not exempt where debt was incurred prior to purchase of such land. Andrews v. Kentucky Citizens' Bldg. & Loan Ass'n's Assignee, 67 S.W. 826, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 2418, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 328 (Ky. Ct. App. 1902). See Feltner v. Colwell, 294 Ky. 581, 172 S.W.2d 219, 1943 Ky. LEXIS 494 (Ky. 1943).

 Homestead was not exempt against debts created before homestead was paid for. Cowan McClung & Co. v. Evans, 101 S.W. 964, 31 Ky. L. Rptr. 226 (1907).

 While homestead was exempt where no payments had been made on purchase price after debts were contracted, any payments made subsequent to contraction of such debts could be proceeded against by creditors. Ratliff v. Anderson & Ratliff, 195 Ky. 320, 242 S.W. 35, 1922 Ky. LEXIS 311 (Ky. 1922).

 Exemption does not apply if debt or liability existed prior to purchase of land or prior to erection of improvements thereon. Runyon v. Runyon's Adm'x, 264 Ky. 823, 95 S.W.2d 802, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 415 (Ky. 1936).

 Fee-simple title is not necessary to right of homestead. Howard v. Mitchell, 268 Ky. 429, 105 S.W.2d 128, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 775 (Ky. 1936).

 Defendant in execution who seeks to establish homestead exemption must, in his pleadings, negative the fact that the debt existed prior to the acquisition of the land. Feltner v. Colwell, 294 Ky. 581, 172 S.W.2d 219, 1943 Ky. LEXIS 494 (Ky. 1943).

 Only prior debts reduced to a judgment lien will be protected from the application of the homestead exemption under this section. Commercial Credit Corp. v. Brooks, 71 B.R. 6 (W.D. Ky. 1986), aff'd, In re Brooks, 817 F.2d 104, 1987 U.S. App. LEXIS 5498 (6th Cir. Ky. 1987).

 Where the property was purchased five years after the debt was reduced to judgment, and sometime prior to the date on which the petition for bankruptcy was filed, a judgment lien was executed on the property, the homestead exemption was not applicable under this section. Commercial Credit Corp. v. Brooks, 71 B.R. 6 (W.D. Ky. 1986), aff'd, In re Brooks, 817 F.2d 104, 1987 U.S. App. LEXIS 5498 (6th Cir. Ky. 1987).

  53. — Source of Funds Used. 

  54. — — Sale of Homestead. 

 Homestead was exempt where obtained with proceeds of sale of prior homestead which had been obtained with proceeds of sale of original homestead. Collins v. Collins, 99 S.W. 653, 30 Ky. L. Rptr. 816 (1907).

 The sale of a rural homestead and use of the proceeds to purchase an urban homestead transferred the homestead exemption to the latter. Farmers' & Traders' Bank v. Childers, 150 Ky. 719, 150 S.W. 840, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 965 (Ky. 1912). See Green & Sons v. Pennington, 123 Ky. 837, 97 S.W. 766, 30 Ky. L. Rptr. 203, 1906 Ky. LEXIS 222 (Ky. 1906).

 Homestead right in a house which the owner abandoned by buying a second house for a home, and moving there was not transferred to the second house, the second house not having been bought with proceeds of the first house. Clay's Committee v. Washington, 183 Ky. 756, 210 S.W. 484, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 562 (Ky. 1919).

  55. — — Sale of Personalty. 

 Homestead purchased with proceeds from sale of exempt personalty was exempt even against prior existing debts. Van Hook v. Robinson, 105 S.W. 129, 31 Ky. L. Rptr. 1347 (1907). See Nicholson's Trustee v. Nicholson, 125 Ky. 629, 101 S.W. 985, 31 Ky. L. Rptr. 217, 1907 Ky. LEXIS 320 (Ky. 1907).

  56. — — Exempt Money. 

 Purchase of land with exempt pension money did not exempt such land from debt incurred prior to such purchase. Curtis v. Helton, 109 Ky. 493, 59 S.W. 745, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 1056, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 228 (Ky. 1900).

 Homestead purchased with exempt money was itself exempt even from debts incurred before such purchase. Wickwire v. Zeller, 68 S.W. 630, 24 Ky. L. Rptr. 421, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 297 (Ky. Ct. App. 1902).

 Homestead was exempt when obtained with wages which were exempt when earned. Aultman & Taylor Machinery Co. v. Smith, 119 S.W. 1178 (Ky. 1909).

 Where house was owned as homestead and was purchased with exempt wages, it was not subject to execution sale pursuant to prior debt. Elliott v. Argenbright, 221 Ky. 763, 299 S.W. 957, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 822 (Ky. 1927).

  57. — — Partial Payment. 

 Where debtor purchased and partially paid for land, then incurred debt, then sold part of land to pay balance of purchase price, remaining land was exempt as having been paid for before debt was incurred. Morrow v. Bailey, 109 Ky. 359, 59 S.W. 2, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 861, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 209 (Ky. 1900).

  58. Intent of Claimant. 

 The existence of a homestead must be decided on the evidence adduced and on the intention and purpose of the claimant. In re McMahon, 60 B.R. 632, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 6120 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

  59. Realtor’s Lien. 

 Debtor would be entitled to nearly the full amount of the allowable homestead exemption but for the lien of realty company; accordingly, such lien is avoidable by the debtor and the avoidance of the lien passes the full interest of the debtor in the property to the estate and the debtor is permitted to claim his homestead exemption from property of the estate. In re Conyers, 129 B.R. 470, 1991 Bankr. LEXIS 1043 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 1991).

  60. Federal Tax Liens. 

 The United States Bankruptcy Code provides that a properly filed tax lien may be collected from exempt property; therefore, a state-created homestead exemption is ineffective against a federal tax lien. Davenport v. United States, 136 B.R. 125, 1991 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15591 (W.D. Ky. 1991).

 A federal tax lien, arising under 26 USCS § 6321 takes precedence over any assertion of a state law homestead exemption. In re Hendrix, 179 B.R. 519, 1994 Bankr. LEXIS 2097 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 1994).

  61. Homestead Laws. 

 A constitutional or statutory provision, granting or increasing a homestead exemption, is not operative as to liabilities existing before its adoption. Kibbey v. Jones, 70 Ky. 243, 1870 Ky. LEXIS 42 (Ky. 1870) (decided under prior law).

 The homestead exemption is not an estate in the land, but only a privilege of occupying the same by a housekeeper with a family as against his creditors. Brame v. Craig, 75 Ky. 404, 1876 Ky. LEXIS 108 (Ky. 1876) (decided under prior law).

 The right to homestead as against a creditor does not depend upon the debtor occupying it at the time the debt is created, but upon the fact that the debt or liability did not exist at the acquisition of the homestead lands or the erection of the improvements thereon. Kinney v. Wheeler, 10 Ky. Op. 40, 1878 Ky. LEXIS 125 (Ky. Ct. App. Sept. 26, 1878) (decided under prior law).

 No construction of the homestead law, unfavorable to the debtor, should be adopted, except to protect creditors and purchasers against fraud. Bennett v. Baird, 81 Ky. 554, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 636, 1884 Ky. LEXIS 5 (Ky. Ct. App. 1884) (decided under prior law).

  62. Attachment. 

 Homestead cannot be taken for debts which are otherwise collectible, and attaching creditor cannot compel prior creditor to proceed against homestead before attaching other real and personal property. Flowers v. Miller, 16 S.W. 705, 13 Ky. L. Rptr. 250, 1891 Ky. LEXIS 184 (Ky. Ct. App. 1891) (decided under prior law).

  63. Construction of Home. 

 The homestead of a debtor cannot be subjected to pay a debt incurred for materials furnished in the erection of the residence unless the creditor has taken the steps required by statute to preserve his materialman’s lien. Steenberger v. Gowdy, 93 Ky. 146, 19 S.W. 186 (Ky. 1892) (decided under prior law).

  64. Housekeeper with Family. 

 A debtor occupying the land as a homestead with his wife or his children, or with his brothers and sisters, father and mother, or those dependent on him, and whom he is under a natural or legal obligation to maintain, is a bona fide housekeeper with a family and entitled to the homestead. Brooks v. Collins, 74 Ky. 622, 11 Bush 622, 1876 Ky. LEXIS 10 (Ky. 1876) decided under prior law).

 That two brothers supported another brother, he being able to support himself, and also supported a nephew whom they had adopted, but whose parents were able to support him, did not entitle them to homestead rights. National Bank of Lancaster v. Slavin's Trustee, 10 Ky. Op. 739, 1 Ky. L. Rptr. 315, 1880 Ky. LEXIS 353 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 12, 1880) (decided under prior law).

 Where debtor was under no natural or legal obligation to support any of the persons living with him, he was not entitled to a homestead as a housekeeper with a family. Carter v. Adams, 4 S.W. 36, 9 Ky. L. Rptr. 91 (Ky. Ct. App. 1887) (decided under prior law).

 A debtor who has children, strangers in blood, residing with him, and whom he is under no natural or legal obligation to support, is not a housekeeper with a family so as to entitle him to the benefit of the homestead law. Bosquett v. Hall, 90 Ky. 566, 13 S.W. 244, 12 Ky. L. Rptr. 433, 1890 Ky. LEXIS 38 (Ky. 1890) (decided under prior law).

 A debtor is entitled to homestead allowed a housekeeper with a family, though his family consisted only of a daughter who supported herself by teaching school, and when not teaching made her home with her father, fully compensating him for her board by the performance of household duties, since it is not necessary that the persons living with the debtor should be dependent on him for support in the ordinary sense of that word. Doolin v. Dugan, 12 Ky. L. Rptr. 749 (1891) (decided under prior law).

 A debtor who resides on premises claimed as the homestead with his widowed daughter and her child, they having a natural and moral claim on him for support, is a housekeeper with a family. Ross v. Sweeny, 15 S.W. 357, 12 Ky. L. Rptr. 861 (1891) (decided under prior law).

  65. Inheritance. 

 Where property derived by an heir through descent is claimed by him as a homestead, improvements erected thereon are liable for his prior debts. Dwelly v. Galbraith, 12 Ky. Op. 40, 4 Ky. L. Rptr. 891, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 125 (Ky. Ct. App. Apr. 14, 1883) (decided under prior law).

 Debtor was not allowed homestead exemption against debts on land which descended to him, and upon which he had never lived, prior to his contraction of such debts. Creager v. Creager, 87 Ky. 449, 9 S.W. 380, 10 Ky. L. Rptr. 424, 1888 Ky. LEXIS 95 (Ky. 1888) (decided under prior law).

  66. Liens. 

 The fact that borrowed money was used by the borrower in discharging a lien on his homestead does not entitle the lender to the benefit of the lien thus discharged, there being no agreement to that effect. White's Adm'r v. Curd, 86 Ky. 191, 5 S.W. 553, 9 Ky. L. Rptr. 505, 1887 Ky. LEXIS 124 (Ky. 1887) (decided under prior law).

 Where one creditor has a lien on the homestead and other lands of the debtor and another creditor has a lien only on the other lands, the first creditor will not be compelled to satisfy his debt out of the homestead in order that the other property may be left for the second creditor. Flowers v. Miller, 16 S.W. 705, 13 Ky. L. Rptr. 250, 1891 Ky. LEXIS 184 (Ky. Ct. App. 1891) (decided under prior law).

  67. Ownership. 

 The debtor claiming a homestead exemption must be the owner of the property, including the dwelling house, not a joint owner nor an owner in common with others, but the owner of a life estate is entitled to the exemption. Allin v. Robinson's Ex'r, 8 Ky. Op. 478, 1875 Ky. LEXIS 182 (Ky. Ct. App. June 28, 1875) (decided under prior law).

 Each of two joint owners of a parcel of land, on which each resides in a separate house, may claim an estate of homestead, even though no partition has been had between them. Meguiar, Helm & Co. v. Burr, 81 Ky. 32, 4 Ky. L. Rptr. 659, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 24 (Ky. Ct. App. 1883) (decided under prior law).

 Debtors’  were not entitled to a homestead exemption under KRS 427.060 because (1) the subject property was not the debtors’  permanent residence; (2) the subject property was not a part of the debtors’  estate as it was previously sold with court approval and without objection by the debtors; and (3) the debtors did not have standing to assert any sort of an exemption in the subject property because their attempts to have the property conveyed to them post-petition without court approval were without effect. In re Wilson, 338 B.R. 315, 2006 Bankr. LEXIS 131 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 2006).

  68. Petitions. 

 Fact that land was acquired and used as homestead before contraction of debt was not required to be stated in homestead petition. Holcomb v. Hood, 12 Ky. L. Rptr. 240 (1886) (decided under prior law).

 Debtors’  motion for a homestead exemption under KRS 427.060 was not properly raised by the debtors as they simply stated on a schedule that employment of exemptions under 11 USCS § 522(d) was to be determined in the bankruptcy plan, but they never moved to amend the schedule to assert the exemption. This was simply not sufficient to put creditors on notice of specific exemptions to be raised in the case. In re Wilson, 338 B.R. 315, 2006 Bankr. LEXIS 131 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 2006).

  69. Proceeds. 

 The proceeds of a homestead, when invested in property subject to execution, are not exempt. Lear v. Totten, 77 Ky. 101, 1878 Ky. LEXIS 42 (Ky. 1878). See Skinner v. Chadwell, 1 S.W. 437, 8 Ky. L. Rptr. 258 (1886) (decided under prior law).

  70. Priorities. 

 In the settlement of an estate under a deed of trust for the payment of debts, where some claims of creditors are older and some younger than the homestead exemption law, there should be a pro rata distribution of all the debtor’s estate except the homestead, among all the creditors, and if this fails to satisfy all the debts, those whose debts are older than such homestead laws are entitled to have a sale of the homestead in satisfaction of the balance due them. Shanklin v. Harshfield, 9 Ky. Op. 469, 1877 Ky. LEXIS 276 (Ky. Ct. App. June 12, 1877) (decided under prior law).

  71. Purchase Money. 

 The fact that a vendor has waived his lien for the purchase money, or has not retained a lien, does not entitle the vendee to a homestead as against an execution for purchase money. Carpenter's Ex'r v. Kearns, 12 Ky. Op. 9, 4 Ky. L. Rptr. 825, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 104 (Ky. Ct. App. Mar. 8, 1883). See Reynolds v. Williams, 4 S.W. 178, 9 Ky. L. Rptr. 112 (Ky. Ct. App. 1887) (decided under prior law).

 A homestead cannot be claimed as against one who pays off for claimant, notes executed by him for the purchase money of the homestead. Harrod v. Johnson, 12 Ky. Op. 268, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 247, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 245 (Ky. Ct. App. Sept. 29, 1883) (decided under prior law).

  72. Purchase. 

 Where one sold his house and lot on time payments and purchased another house and lot and paid for it by transferring a stock of dry goods, but bought it after becoming indebted, the transaction was not an exchange of one exempt piece of property for another so as to cause the exemption in the first to attach to the last, as the sale of the first property operated to destroy the homestead, and exemption did not attach to the dwelling afterward purchased. Faucett v. Hearn, Lee & Pinkard, 10 Ky. Op. 461, 1880 Ky. LEXIS 144 (Ky. Ct. App. Jan. 20, 1880) (decided under prior law).

 A homestead is subject to the payment of money borrowed for its purchase. Moore v. Miller, 10 Ky. Op. 736, 1 Ky. L. Rptr. 322, 1880 Ky. LEXIS 351 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 9, 1880). See Denny v. McAtee's Adm'r, 11 Ky. Op. 194, 3 Ky. L. Rptr. 36, 1881 Ky. LEXIS 227 (Ky. Ct. App. June 4, 1881); Riley v. Filmore, 11 Ky. Op. 745, 4 Ky. L. Rptr. 347, 1882 Ky. LEXIS 293 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 12, 1882); Broomfield v. Broomfield, 13 Ky. Op. 571, 7 Ky. L. Rptr. 221, 1885 Ky. LEXIS 263 (Ky. Ct. App. Sept. 15, 1885) (decided under prior law).

  73. — Time Debt Created. 

 Where the homestead is sold and the proceeds invested on other property of the same nature, such property is invested with the homestead character, and entitled to the same exemptions as the first one. Carter Bros. & Co. v. Liles, 12 Ky. Op. 456, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 690, 1884 Ky. LEXIS 195 (Ky. Ct. App. Feb. 5, 1884). See R. L. White & Co. v. Wilder, 10 Ky. Op. 836, 1880 Ky. LEXIS 421 (Ky. Ct. App. Nov. 4, 1880); Fant v. Talbot, 81 Ky. 23, 4 Ky. L. Rptr. 656, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 22 (Ky. 1883); Sebastian v. Steel, 20 S.W. 269, 14 Ky. L. Rptr. 311 (1892) (decided under prior law).

 A debtor may acquire a right to a homestead after the creation of a debt by moving on the land with his family and residing there as a housekeeper, if the indebtedness was not created prior to the purchase of the land or the erection of the improvement. Hensey v. Hensey's Adm'r, 92 Ky. 164, 17 S.W. 333, 13 Ky. L. Rptr. 426, 1891 Ky. LEXIS 135 (Ky. 1891) (decided under prior law).

  74. Remainders and Reversions. 

 During continuance of homestead, family head’s remainder of reversionary interest is subject to levy and sale, although during life of debtor his land cannot be sold subject to his homestead right. Schmidt v. Oliges, 12 Ky. Op. 753, 6 Ky. L. Rptr. 297, 1884 Ky. LEXIS 330 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 4, 1884). See Wilson v. Oldham, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 254 (1883) (decided under prior law).

  Cited: 

 In re Gibson, 33 F. Supp. 838, 1940 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2940 (D. Ky. 1940); Paslick v. Shay, 148 Ky. 642, 147 S.W. 369, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 504 (Ky. 1912); Mangrum v. Mangrum, 216 Ky. 154, 287 S.W. 532, 1926 Ky. LEXIS 855 (Ky. 1926); Baker v. Robinson, 273 Ky. 410, 116 S.W.2d 958, 1938 Ky. LEXIS 649 (Ky. 1938); Howard v. Howard, 286 Ky. 139, 150 S.W.2d 653, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 237 (Ky. 1941); In re T L G Computing Services, Inc., 20 B.R. 568, 1982 Bankr. LEXIS 3987 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1982); In re Zaicek, 29 B.R. 31, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 6408 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983); In re Kincaid, 55 B.R. 652, 1985 Bankr. LEXIS 4768 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1985).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Bench & Bar. 

Bland, The Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978: An Overview, Vol. 44, No. 1, January 1980, Ky. Bench & Bar 8.

Bankruptcy Practice: A Checklist for the “Casual Practitioner,” Vol. 69, No. 3, May 2005, Ky. Bench & Bar 19.

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Skaggs, Erwin, The Horizontal Property Law of Kentucky, 51 Ky. L.J. 46 (1962).

Vahlsing and Hudson, Inchoate Dower — An Idea Whose Time Is Past, 60 Ky. L.J. 671 (1972).

Kentucky Law Survey, Graham, Domestic Relations, 73 Ky. L.J. 379 (1984-85).

Bland, Insolvencies in Farming and Agribusinesses, 73 Ky. L.J. 795 (1984-85).

Bratt, Family Protection Under Kentucky’s Inheritance Laws: Is the Family Really Protected? 76 Ky. L.J. 387 (1987-88).

Bratt, Kentucky’s Doctrine of Advancements: A Time for Reform, 75 Ky. L.J. 341 (1986-87).

  Northern Kentucky Law Review. 

Schneider, Recommendations for Improving Kentucky’s Inheritance Laws, 22 N. Ky. L. Rev. 317 (1995).

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Notice of Judgment Lien on Real Estate, Form 154.03.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Practice Context for Dower and Curtesy Exemption, § 254.00.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Practice Context for Homestead Exemption, § 155.00.

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, Personal Rights and Privileges Resulting from Marriage, § 12.6.

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, Property Rights, § 14.3.


427.070.  Right of spouse and children to homestead.

Text

(1) The homestead shall be for the use of the widow as long as she occupies it, and the unmarried infant children of the husband are entitled to a joint occupancy with her until the youngest unmarried child arrives at full age. The termination of the widow’s occupancy shall not affect the rights of the children. The land may be sold, subject to the right of the widow and children, if a sale is necessary to pay the debts of the husband.

(2) The homestead of a woman shall, in like manner, be for the use of her surviving husband and her children, situated as above. When the interest of the husband and children ceases, the homestead shall be disposed of in like manner and the proceeds applied on the same terms to her debts, or, if there are no debts, divided among her children.

History

History.
1707, 1708.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. In General.

2. Abandonment.

  3. — Divorce.

  4. — Children’s Rights.

  5. — Infants.

  6. — Remarriage.

  7. — Repossession.

  8. — Sale.

  9. — — In Another State.

  10. — — Purchaser’s Rights.

  11. — Under Duress or Ignorance.

12. Children of Deceased.

  13. — Death.

  14. — Marriage.

  15. — Rights.

16. Dower.

17. Homestead.

  18. — Priority.

  19. — Termination.

  20. — Before Death of Spouse.

  21. — Distribution of Proceeds.

  22. — Conveyance by Deceased.

  23. — In Lieu of Dower.

  24. — Occupancy.

  25. — — Joint Occupancy.

26. Exchange.

27. Owner Still Living.

28. Sale of Decedent’s Property.

29. Bona Fide Housekeeper.

30. Condemnation.

31. Homestead Rights.

  32. — Widow.

  33. — Children.

  34. — Priority.

  35. — Waiver.

36. Sale of Decedent’s Property.

  1. In General. 

 A married woman entitled to a homestead in property owned by her in her own right is not deprived thereof by the death of her husband, but she is entitled thereto for her own use and benefit so long as she continues to occupy it as a homestead, whether she has a family or any person that she is under a legal or moral obligation to support residing with her. American Nat'l Bank v. Mathews, 124 S.W. 811, 1910 Ky. LEXIS 665 (Ky. 1910).

  2. Abandonment. 

 Widower did not lose homestead right by offering land for sale with intent not to return if successful, where land was not sold and he returned and reoccupied it. Gregory v. Oates, 92 Ky. 532, 18 S.W. 231, 13 Ky. L. Rptr. 761, 1892 Ky. LEXIS 12 (Ky. 1892) (decided under prior law).

 Widow’s confinement to insane asylum was not abandonment. National Loan & Bldg. Ass'n v. Maloney, 60 S.W. 12, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 1094 (1900).

 One’s character of homesteader, with the attendant rights of homestead exemption, is not lost by his commitment to an insane asylum and the death of his wife while he is there. Holburn v. Pfanmiller's Adm'r, 114 Ky. 831, 71 S.W. 940, 24 Ky. L. Rptr. 1613, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 47 (Ky. 1903).

 Widow did not abandon homestead by making deed to tenant under agreement that she would sell if she had right to sell. Moore v. Moore, 78 S.W. 141 (Ky. 1904).

 Widow’s right could be lost by abandonment or alienation. Berger v. Berger, 264 Ky. 225, 94 S.W.2d 618, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 301 (Ky. 1936).

 Widow could deed homestead to her son, in consideration for his caring for her for rest of her life, without abandoning her homestead right. Howard v. Mitchell, 268 Ky. 429, 105 S.W.2d 128, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 775 (Ky. 1936).

  3. — Divorce. 

 Absolute divorce extinguishes all right of the wife to homestead in the land of the husband. Skinner v. Walker, 98 Ky. 729, 34 S.W. 233, 17 Ky. L. Rptr. 1286, 1896 Ky. LEXIS 27 (Ky. 1896). See Mize v. Boston, 185 Ky. 275, 215 S.W. 33, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 284 (Ky. 1919).

  4. — Children’s Rights. 

 The widow cannot dispose of or abandon the homestead to the impairment of the children’s rights. Phipps v. Acton, 75 Ky. 375, 1876 Ky. LEXIS 101 (Ky. 1876). See Moss v. Hall, 79 Ky. 40, 1 Ky. L. Rptr. 314, 3 Ky. L. Rptr. 89, 1880 Ky. LEXIS 84 (Ky. Ct. App. 1880); Elmore v. Elmore's Adm'r, 11 Ky. Op. 902, 4 Ky. L. Rptr. 622, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 339 (Ky. Ct. App. Jan. 25, 1883) (decided under prior law).

  5. — Infants. 

 Infants cannot abandon their homestead rights. Baker v. Lane, 118 S.W. 963 (Ky. 1909).

  6. — Remarriage. 

 Widow who remarries and makes permanent move to new home abandons homestead right notwithstanding she retains old home with tenant. Bloch v. Tarrents' Adm'r, 122 Ky. 138, 91 S.W. 275, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 1066, 1906 Ky. LEXIS 31 (Ky. 1906). See Nelson v. Nelson, 96 S.W. 794, 29 Ky. L. Rptr. 885 (1906); Boggess v. Johnston, 158 Ky. 418, 165 S.W. 413, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 631 (Ky. 1914).

  7. — Repossession. 

 Widow who abandoned homestead by conveying it away could not repossess herself of it from her children. Freeman v. Mills, 59 S.W. 3, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 859 (1900).

  8. — Sale. 

 Widow’s sale of homestead was abandonment of it, and her infant children thereafter had sole right to occupancy. Davidson v. Marcum, 89 S.W. 703, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 562, 1905 Ky. LEXIS 259 (Ky. Ct. App. 1905). See Deboe v. Rushing, 51 S.W. 613, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 423 (1899).

 Where widow undertook to convey homestead, she abandoned it, and remainderman was entitled to immediate possession. Tobien v. Gentry, 183 Ky. 80, 208 S.W. 325, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 441 (Ky. 1919).

  9. — — In Another State. 

 Widow abandoned her homestead when she sold it upon achieving legal age in her new state of residence. Love v. McCandless, 157 Ky. 352, 163 S.W. 197, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 282 (Ky. 1914).

  10. — — Purchaser’s Rights. 

 Surviving spouse who sold homestead abandoned it, and since homestead so abandoned goes immediately to such spouse’s children and homestead heirs, purchaser of homestead took no title or right of possession and any possession by him was adverse as to such heirs. Settle v. Simpson, 204 Ky. 470, 264 S.W. 1092, 1924 Ky. LEXIS 506 (Ky. 1924). See Kimberlin v. Isaacs, 62 S.W. 494, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 42 (1901); Shepard v. Browning, 156 Ky. 194, 160 S.W. 950, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 410 (Ky. 1913); Hager v. Vincent, 228 Ky. 589, 15 S.W.2d 426, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 589 (Ky. 1929).

  11. — Under Duress or Ignorance. 

 Where widow’s giving up of possession was under duress and in ignorance of her rights, her occupancy did not cease and those thus in possession held her homestead as agents or tenants. Young v. Young, 109 Ky. 123, 58 S.W. 592, 58 S.W. 593, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 187 (Ky. 1900).

  12. Children of Deceased. 

 Children did not have to be living with deceased father when he died in order to have joint right of homestead with widow. Potter v. Redmon's Guardian, 123 Ky. 400, 96 S.W. 529, 29 Ky. L. Rptr. 840, 1906 Ky. LEXIS 159 (Ky. 1906).

 Children had joint right to occupancy of widow’s homestead. Thompson v. Thompson's Adm'r, 105 S.W. 1185, 32 Ky. L. Rptr. 319 (1907).

 Children of deceased husband had right of occupancy of homestead with remarried wife until they were 21 years old, and right to joint possession of homestead on termination of wife’s occupancy. Taree v. Spriggs, 149 Ky. 20, 147 S.W. 754, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 558 (Ky. 1912).

 Widow’s son’s undivided half interest could not be defeated by failure of widow and her son-in-law to pay taxes and obtain tax title. Carter v. Monarch, 171 Ky. 345, 188 S.W. 379, 1916 Ky. LEXIS 344 (Ky. 1916).

 Where widow’s deceased husband had children by his first wife only, such widow could claim homestead only in land upon which she was living with deceased when he died. Tinsley v. Tinsley, 193 Ky. 324, 235 S.W. 730, 1921 Ky. LEXIS 218 (Ky. 1921).

 Any infant who was child of deceased could share in homestead with deceased’s widow. Wilson's Adm'r v. Wilson, 288 Ky. 522, 156 S.W.2d 832, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 139 (Ky. 1941).

  13. — Death. 

 When widower inherited fee from deceased sons, there was no merger of his homestead or right of occupancy in such fee. Evansville Coffin Co. v. Sumner, 189 Ky. 839, 226 S.W. 363, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 523 (Ky. 1920).

 Where widower acquired half interest in deceased wife’s property upon death of his son and had no other family, such widower had only right of occupancy and no homestead in such half interest. Evansville Coffin Co. v. Sumner, 189 Ky. 839, 226 S.W. 363, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 523 (Ky. 1920).

  14. — Marriage. 

 Daughter who married during her minority was thereby divested of homestead right. Jones v. Crawford, 119 Ky. 554, 84 S.W. 568, 27 Ky. L. Rptr. 191, 1905 Ky. LEXIS 27 (Ky. 1905).

  15. — Rights. 

 Where husband’s will devised entire estate to widow subject to payment of debts, widow’s failure to renounce will’s provisions did not defeat rights of children to homestead. Schnabel v. Schnabel's Ex'x, 108 Ky. 536, 56 S.W. 983, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 234, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 76 (Ky. 1900), limited, Demarest v. Allen, 189 Ky. 32, 224 S.W. 458, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 369 (Ky. 1920).

 Daughter was not entitled to homestead in widow’s life estate, which widow held by virtue of dower not having been assigned to her. Bogie v. Nelson, 153 Ky. 440, 155 S.W. 1142, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 861 (Ky. 1913).

 Children have, during the life of their parents, no right to the homestead which can be asserted against the parents’ acts. Demarest v. Allen, 189 Ky. 32, 224 S.W. 458, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 369 (Ky. 1920).

  16. Dower. 

 If widow elects to take dower in lieu of homestead, the homestead right of the infant children follows and attaches to the dower. In re Gibson, 33 F. Supp. 838, 1940 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2940 (D. Ky. 1940).

 The widow of bankrupt had the right, upon his death, to elect whether to claim the exempt proceeds derived from sale of his homestead or her right to dower in the land, but her election to receive dower precluded her right to claim exemption in the proceeds. In re Gibson, 33 F. Supp. 838, 1940 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2940 (D. Ky. 1940).

 Widower had to elect between deceased wife’s dower and homestead right. Carpenter v. Hazelrigg, 103 Ky. 538, 45 S.W. 666, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 231, 1898 Ky. LEXIS 90 (Ky. 1898).

 Children’s homestead rights could not be defeated by election of widow to take dower. Thompson v. Thompson's Adm'r, 105 S.W. 1185, 32 Ky. L. Rptr. 319 (1907).

 Where widow had made no election between dower or homestead, the court must elect the estate most beneficial to her and her infant children. Wilson's Adm'r v. Wilson, 288 Ky. 522, 156 S.W.2d 832, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 139 (Ky. 1941).

  17. Homestead. 

 Widower does not need family or children to retain benefit of wife’s homestead. Holder's Adm'r v. Holder, 120 Ky. 802, 87 S.W. 1100, 27 Ky. L. Rptr. 1171, 1905 Ky. LEXIS 157 (Ky. 1905).

 The homestead right in this state is not an estate in land but is merely a right of occupancy. Charboneau v. Hart, 211 Ky. 204, 277 S.W. 242, 1925 Ky. LEXIS 846 (Ky. 1925).

 Widow is entitled to homestead only if her deceased husband was entitled to homestead. Runyon v. Runyon's Adm'x, 264 Ky. 823, 95 S.W.2d 802, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 415 (Ky. 1936).

 The rights given by this section are strictly “rights of occupancy” by a surviving spouse after death of other one and which deceased one owned at time of death. Foreman v. Cook, 277 Ky. 812, 127 S.W.2d 856, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 737 (Ky. 1939).

 “Homestead” in its statutory sense means the land, not exceeding the prescribed amount, upon which is located the dwelling house of the owner, and the right to have it exempted from sale under execution, attachment or judgment. Kelly v. Kelly's Ex'r, 299 Ky. 861, 186 S.W.2d 902, 1945 Ky. LEXIS 499 (Ky. 1945).

  18. — Priority. 

 Widow’s homestead right was subordinate to lien for attorney’s fees which arose prior to acquisition of homestead by decedent husband. Brown v. Ingram's Ex'x, 292 Ky. 703, 168 S.W.2d 31, 1943 Ky. LEXIS 742 (Ky. 1943).

  19. — Termination. 

 Widow’s temporary absence did not terminate her homestead right. Demarest v. Allen, 189 Ky. 32, 224 S.W. 458, 1920 Ky. LEXIS 369 (Ky. 1920).

 Widow’s right was not terminated by mere fact of her moving from homestead. Hamer v. McCown, 231 Ky. 522, 21 S.W.2d 833, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 315 (Ky. 1929).

  20. — Before Death of Spouse. 

 Husband could claim homestead in his own land, notwithstanding this section, until death of his wife. Summers v. Sprigg, 35 S.W. 1033, 18 Ky. L. Rptr. 206 (1896).

 This section does not give a husband any right of homestead in the land of his wife during her life. Lear v. Lear, 234 Ky. 369, 28 S.W.2d 32, 1930 Ky. LEXIS 183 (Ky. 1930).

  21. — Distribution of Proceeds. 

 Homestead may be applied for and obtained at any time before the proceeds of the property are distributed. Wilson's Adm'r v. Wilson, 288 Ky. 522, 156 S.W.2d 832, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 139 (Ky. 1941).

  22. — Conveyance by Deceased. 

 Deed by husband conveying homestead to another, though not signed by wife, bars wife from claiming homestead right after husband’s death, and she has only her right of dower in the land. Pugh v. Pugh, 279 Ky. 170, 130 S.W.2d 40, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 253 (Ky. 1939).

  23. — In Lieu of Dower. 

 Homestead in lieu of dower could be claimed by widow only where she and husband were in occupancy when he died. Dehoney v. Bell, 30 S.W. 400, 17 Ky. L. Rptr. 76 (1895).

  24. — Occupancy. 

 Widow had homestead in deceased husband’s land which was contiguous to her own land and which they both occupied. Buckler v. Brown, 101 Ky. 46, 39 S.W. 509, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 85, 1897 Ky. LEXIS 147 (Ky. 1897).

 The fact that the wife was not living with the husband at his death does not deprive her of the right to a homestead in property on which he made his home. Redmond's Adm'x v. Redmond, 112 Ky. 760, 66 S.W. 745, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 2161, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 220 (Ky. 1902).

 Under this section, the widow is entitled to a homestead in land of the husband occupied by him as such, subject to the right of his unmarried infant children to joint occupancy. Atkins v. Baker, 112 Ky. 877, 66 S.W. 1023, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 2224, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 233 (Ky. 1902).

 Widower’s estate is conditional on his occupancy of it. Clay's Guardian v. Wallace, 116 Ky. 599, 76 S.W. 388, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 820, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 221 (Ky. 1903).

 Property never occupied as homestead by deceased husband was not exempt on passage to his widow. Higgins v. Higgins, 117 Ky. 725, 78 S.W. 1124, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 1824, 1904 Ky. LEXIS 241 (Ky. 1904). See Harris v. Howard, 81 S.W. 275, 26 Ky. L. Rptr. 366 (1904).

 A widow’s occupation of a homestead is sufficient if by tenant, and it is not necessary to preserve her homestead right that she herself should live on the land. Overby v. Williams, 170 Ky. 140, 185 S.W. 822, 1916 Ky. LEXIS 29 (Ky. 1916). See Miller v. Keown, 176 Ky. 117, 195 S.W. 430, 1917 Ky. LEXIS 28 (Ky. 1917), overruled,  Lockhard v. Brown, 536 S.W.2d 318, 1976 Ky. LEXIS 72 (Ky. 1976).

  25. — — Joint Occupancy. 

 Widow had right to joint occupancy of homestead with children although she owned other property. Taylor v. Shelton, 227 Ky. 473, 13 S.W.2d 506, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 904 (Ky. 1929).

  26. Exchange. 

 Exchange of homestead by widow’s second husband gave widow interest in new homestead, with remainder interest in children. Rowe v. Blair, 221 Ky. 685, 299 S.W. 571, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 803 (Ky. 1927).

  27. Owner Still Living. 

 Deserted wife constituted “a family,” and thus was entitled to same exemptions as were had by her husband. Baum v. Turner, 139 Ky. 597, 76 S.W. 129, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 600, 1903 Ky. LEXIS 4 (Ky. 1903).

 Where a husband fails to assert his right of homestead, or abandons the estate, his wife may assert the claim for herself. Purdy v. Melton, 164 Ky. 749, 176 S.W. 346, 1915 Ky. LEXIS 461 (Ky. 1915). See Bishop v. Simpson, 224 Ky. 289, 6 S.W.2d 253, 1928 Ky. LEXIS 588 (Ky. 1928).

 Spouse had no estate or vested interest in homestead while owner still lived. Lear v. Lear, 234 Ky. 369, 28 S.W.2d 32, 1930 Ky. LEXIS 183 (Ky. 1930). See Covington Bros. & Co. v. Byrns, 230 Ky. 66, 18 S.W.2d 870, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 13 (Ky. 1929); Forsythe v. Morgantown Deposit Bank, 252 Ky. 680, 68 S.W.2d 14, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 842 (Ky. 1934).

  28. Sale of Decedent’s Property. 

 Where whole property was sold for debts of decedent, $1,000 of proceeds were set aside to be used by widow and children as their homestead right. Warren's Adm'r v. Warren, 126 Ky. 692, 104 S.W. 1199, 104 S.W. 754, 31 Ky. L. Rptr. 1101, 32 Ky. L. Rptr. 82, 1907 Ky. LEXIS 93 (Ky. 1907).

  29. Bona Fide Housekeeper. 

 A surviving husband, whose family consisted of himself and housekeeper, was not a bona fide housekeeper with a family. Ellis v. Davis, 90 Ky. 183, 14 S.W. 74, 11 Ky. L. Rptr. 893, 1890 Ky. LEXIS 84 (Ky. 1890) (decided under prior law).

  30. Condemnation. 

 Where property occupied by a widow and her daughter was exempt as a homestead and a portion of it was condemned by a railroad company, the widow was entitled to the proceeds of the condemnation as exempt from the creditors of her husband. Brooks v. Collins, 74 Ky. 622, 1876 Ky. LEXIS 10 (Ky. 1876) (decided under prior law).

  31. Homestead Rights. 

  32. — Widow. 

 A widow may claim a homestead in real estate owned by her husband against the husband’s heirs, as well as against his creditors. Gasaway v. Woods, 72 Ky. 72, 1872 Ky. LEXIS 15 (Ky. 1872). See Eustache v. Rodaquest, 74 Ky. 42, 1874 Ky. LEXIS 8 (Ky. 1874) (decided under prior law).

 A widow was entitled to a homestead in a farm devised to her for life by her husband, she having a daughter residing with her on the farm. Burns v. Hoffman, 11 Ky. Op. 549, 3 Ky. L. Rptr. 696, 1882 Ky. LEXIS 197 (Ky. Ct. App. Feb. 28, 1882) (decided under prior law).

 Widow was entitled to homestead exemption where only minor child was her son who, with his wife and children, lived with her. Riley v. Smtih, 5 S.W. 869, 9 Ky. L. Rptr. 615 (1887) (decided under prior law).

 The fact that the land was held by the debtor under a title bond did not preclude the widow’s right to a homestead, and it was not necessary to the existence of this right that the husband should have had a deed to the land. Persifull v. Hind, 88 Ky. 296, 11 S.W. 15, 10 Ky. L. Rptr. 880, 1889 Ky. LEXIS 32 (Ky. 1889) (decided under prior law).

  33. — Children. 

 After the death of the father and mother, their infant children were entitled to the homestead occupied by their parents or to $1,000 out of the proceeds thereof. Dillard v. Hunt, 7 Ky. Op. 625, 1874 Ky. LEXIS 251 (Ky. Ct. App. Mar. 27, 1874) (decided under prior law).

 The judgment of sale, the confirmation, deed and distribution of the money did not estop or preclude the infant children of a husband from claiming a homestead in his real estate. Lawrence v. Lawrence's Adm'r, 10 Ky. Op. 353, 1879 Ky. LEXIS 226 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 15, 1879) (decided under prior law).

 Where several children were entitled to a homestead, a creditor could not complain because those arriving at 21 years of age remained on the homestead with a younger child. Lawrence v. Lawrence's Adm'r, 10 Ky. Op. 353, 1879 Ky. LEXIS 226 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 15, 1879) (decided under prior law).

 Infant children were entitled to a homestead in the land of their deceased father against either creditors or adult children, though he left no widow. Higginbotham v. Meadows, 13 Ky. Op. 374, 6 Ky. L. Rptr. 661, 1885 Ky. LEXIS 178 (Ky. Ct. App. Mar. 26, 1885) (decided under prior law).

  34. — Priority. 

 A widow and a remainderman could not at the same time have a homestead in the same land; the widow’s right was paramount. Merrifield v. Merrifield's Assignee, 82 Ky. 526, 6 Ky. L. Rptr. 568, 1885 Ky. LEXIS 13 (Ky. 1885) (decided under prior law).

  35. — Waiver. 

 Where a widow elected to take under the will of her husband, which passed to her all his estate, subject to the payment of his debts, she waived her homestead right. Oschsver v. German Bldg. & Sav. Ass'n, 12 Ky. Op. 217, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 177, 1883 Ky. LEXIS 212 (Ky. Ct. App. June 16, 1883) (decided under prior law).

 Where a widow applied for dower and did not ask homestead, her right to the latter was waived. Burch v. Atchison, 82 Ky. 585, 6 Ky. L. Rptr. 593, 6 Ky. L. Rptr. 636, 1885 Ky. LEXIS 22 (Ky. Ct. App. 1885) (decided under prior law).

  36. Sale of Decedent’s Property. 

 Where a debtor died and his right to the homestead or its occupancy passed to the widow and children, it could be subjected to sale by his creditors, subject to this occupancy. Taylor v. Loller's Ex'rs, 3 S.W. 165, 8 Ky. L. Rptr. 773 (Ky. Ct. App. 1887) (decided under prior law).

  Cited: 

 Louisville Fertilizer Co. v. Lorton, 110 S.W. 870, 33 Ky. L. Rptr. 676 (1908); Jenkins v. McVaw, 145 Ky. 205, 140 S.W. 150, 1911 Ky. LEXIS 806 (Ky. 1911); Paslick v. Shay, 148 Ky. 642, 147 S.W. 369, 1912 Ky. LEXIS 504 (Ky. 1912); Mangrum v. Mangrum, 216 Ky. 154, 287 S.W. 532, 1926 Ky. LEXIS 855 (Ky. 1926); Brewer v. Brewer, 268 Ky. 625, 105 S.W.2d 582, 1937 Ky. LEXIS 491 (Ky. 1937), overruled in part, Perry v. Motorists Mut. Ins. Co., 860 S.W.2d 762, 1993 Ky. LEXIS 91 (Ky. 1993); Howard v. Howard, 286 Ky. 139, 150 S.W.2d 653, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 237 (Ky. 1941); First Nat’l Bank v. Oliver, 286 Ky. 286, 150 S.W.2d 894, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 258 (Ky. 1941); Ferguson v. Board of Drainage Comm’rs, 299 Ky. 538, 186 S.W.2d 16, 1945 Ky. LEXIS 460 (Ky. 1945).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Bratt, Family Protection Under Kentucky’s Inheritance Laws: Is the Family Really Protected? 76 Ky. L.J. 387 (1987-88).

  Treatises 

  Treatises 

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, Personal Rights and Privileges Resulting from Marriage, § 12.6.

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, Property Rights, § 14.3.


427.080.  Valuation and allotment of homestead exemption.

Text

(1) No sale under execution, attachment or judgment of property occupied as a homestead shall be had until the officer executing the writ or judgment has the part thereof selected by the defendant as his homestead exemption, not to exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000) in value, valued under oath and set apart to him by two (2) disinterested housekeepers of the county. These appraisers shall be selected by the court or officer, and if they disagree the officer making the sale shall act as umpire.

(2) The valuation shall be in writing and signed by the person making it and returned to the court. The officer shall refer to and explain the proceedings in his return on the execution, which shall be recorded in full.

History

History.
1703, 1704: amend. Acts 1980, ch. 236, § 5, effective April 9, 1980.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Depreciation.

2. Erroneous Sales.

3. Excessive Allotment.

4. Execution Subsequent to Allotment.

5. Improvements.

6. Increase in Value.

7. Judicial Allotment.

8. Life Estates.

9. Property of Wife.

10. Requirements Not Followed.

11. Rights After Execution.

12. Separate Tracts.

13. Surviving Spouse.

  1. Depreciation. 

 Once debtor accepted homestead, he thereafter could have no reallotment on grounds value of his premises had depreciated. Wilson v. Newberry, 238 Ky. 635, 38 S.W.2d 695, 1931 Ky. LEXIS 306 (Ky. 1931).

  2. Erroneous Sales. 

 Where there was a forced sale of property in which an unasserted right of homestead exemption existed, such sale was merely erroneous and not void. Moore v. Sanders, 297 Ky. 13, 178 S.W.2d 842, 1944 Ky. LEXIS 650 (Ky. 1944).

  3. Excessive Allotment. 

 Where debtor admitted his allotted property was worth over $1,000, allotment was set aside as excessive. Cincinnati Leaf Tobacco Warehouse Co. v. Thompson, 105 Ky. 627, 49 S.W. 446, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 1439, 1899 Ky. LEXIS 249 (Ky. 1899).

 Where homestead was over $1,000 in value, total exemption was improper, and valuation procedure under this section should have been followed. Ball v. Smiddy, 249 S.W.2d 715, 1952 Ky. LEXIS 838 (Ky. 1952).

  4. Execution Subsequent to Allotment. 

 Where debtor’s land was allotted to him on levy by judgment creditor, subsequent execution sale by another such creditor was set aside. Caldwell v. Taylor, 32 S.W. 678, 17 Ky. L. Rptr. 781 (1895).

  5. Improvements. 

 Valuation of homestead did not include improvements made by widower for his own use. Shields v. Parsons, 230 Ky. 143, 18 S.W.2d 961, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 35 (Ky. 1929).

  6. Increase in Value. 

 Where homestead value increased over $1,000 after allotment, exemption was retained and no new valuation was authorized. Gowdy v. Johnson, 104 Ky. 648, 47 S.W. 624, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 997, 1898 Ky. LEXIS 206 (Ky. 1898), overruled in part, Yager's Adm'r v. Bank of Kentucky, 125 Ky. 177, 100 S.W. 848, 30 Ky. L. Rptr. 1287, 1907 Ky. LEXIS 267 (Ky. 1907). See Morton v. Jones, 136 Ky. 797, 125 S.W. 247, 1910 Ky. LEXIS 544 (Ky. 1910).

 Where requirements of this section were not followed in allotment of homestead, natural appreciation over $1,000 was exempt. Wilson v. Newberry, 238 Ky. 635, 38 S.W.2d 695, 1931 Ky. LEXIS 306 (Ky. 1931).

  7. Judicial Allotment. 

 Court had power to correct insufficient allotment without appointment of additional commissioners. Mount v. Fourth Street Bank, 156 Ky. 503, 161 S.W. 220, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 448 (Ky. 1913).

 Homestead allotment was within power of chancery court in suit brought pursuant thereto. James v. Reeves, 185 Ky. 406, 215 S.W. 66, 1919 Ky. LEXIS 311 (Ky. 1919).

  8. Life Estates. 

 Where the homestead embraced land in which the debtor held only a life estate, the fee-simple value was estimated in setting apart the homestead. Franks v. Lucas, 77 Ky. 395, 1878 Ky. LEXIS 88 (Ky. 1878) (decided under prior law).

 Widow’s homestead in life estate was estimated according to value if owned in fee simple, and remainder of her dower estate over $1,000 was subject to execution. Wilson v. Devasher, 204 Ky. 408, 264 S.W. 1057, 1924 Ky. LEXIS 477 (Ky. 1924). See Suter v. Quarles, 58 S.W. 990, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 1080, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 710 (Ky. Ct. App. 1900).

  9. Property of Wife. 

 It was not necessary to allot wife homestead in her own land, since this would defeat any right she might have to homestead in land of her husband. Rickett v. Bolton, 173 Ky. 739, 191 S.W. 471 (Ky. 1917).

  10. Requirements Not Followed. 

 Owner was not deprived of homestead right by failure of sale officer to follow requirements of this section. Greenhill's Adm'rs v. Oppenheimer, 255 Ky. 221, 72 S.W.2d 1037, 1934 Ky. LEXIS 200 (Ky. 1934).

  11. Rights After Execution. 

 Where there is an execution sale of property with right of homestead, such right, where asserted after the sale, must be made by pleading, motion or affidavit negativing the statutory exceptions to the right of homestead. Moore v. Sanders, 297 Ky. 13, 178 S.W.2d 842, 1944 Ky. LEXIS 650 (Ky. 1944).

  12. Separate Tracts. 

 Homestead should be carved out of the different parcels of a farm, throwing it together if practicable. Burns v. Hoffman, 11 Ky. Op. 549, 3 Ky. L. Rptr. 696, 1882 Ky. LEXIS 197 (Ky. Ct. App. Feb. 28, 1882) (decided under prior law).

 Where a debtor’s dwelling house and the tract of land on which it stands are worth less than $1,000, he may make up his homestead exemption out of another tract, which is used as a part of the homestead, though the two tracts do not adjoin. Donaldson v. Richart, 60 S.W. 405, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 1268 (1901). See Gaar, Scott & Co. v. Reesor, 91 S.W. 717, 28 Ky. L. Rptr. 1308 (1906); Farmer v. Hampton, 154 Ky. 83, 156 S.W. 1041, 1913 Ky. LEXIS 19 (Ky. 1913).

  13. Surviving Spouse. 

 In determining allotment to widow, value of her own land is not considered. Buckler v. Brown, 101 Ky. 46, 39 S.W. 509, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 85, 1897 Ky. LEXIS 147 (Ky. 1897).

  Cited: 

 Owens v. Altsheller & Co., 263 Ky. 727, 93 S.W.2d 844, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 245 (Ky. 1936); Gibbs v. Deins, 282 Ky. 625, 139 S.W.2d 430, 1940 Ky. LEXIS 218 (Ky. 1940).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Cross-References. 

Defendant may designate land to be sold, direct order of sale, surrender land not levied on, KRS 426.150, 426 210.

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Bratt, Family Protection Under Kentucky’s Inheritance Laws: Is the Family Really Protected? 76 Ky. L.J. 387 (1987-88).

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Affidavit for Issuance of Execution to Another County, Form 151.17.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Practice Context for Homestead Exemption, § 155.00.


427.090.  Payment of money in lieu of homestead exemption.

Text

If the defendant in the execution, attachment or other action owns property levied on or sought to be subjected to the payment of any debt or liability, which, in the opinion of the appraisers, is of greater value than five thousand dollars ($5,000) and not divisible without great diminution in value, the property shall be sold and five thousand dollars ($5,000) of the money arising from the sale paid to the defendant to enable him to purchase another homestead. The property shall not be sold for less than five thousand dollars ($5,000).

History

History.
1705: amend. Acts 1980, ch. 236, § 6, effective April 9, 1980.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Money in Lieu of Homestead.

  2. — Interests of Infants.

  3. — Disposition by Debtor.

4. Mortgages.

5. Sale of Property.

  6. — Under $1,000.

7. Surviving Spouse.

  1. Money in Lieu of Homestead. 

  2. — Interests of Infants. 

 When homestead is sold and money given in lieu thereof, great care should be used in protection of interests of infants. Thompson v. Thompson's Adm'r, 105 S.W. 1185, 32 Ky. L. Rptr. 319 (1907).

  3. — Disposition by Debtor. 

 Where money is adjudged debtor in lieu of homestead, creditors cannot complain of disposition of such money by debtor. Huntington Bank v. Bowers, 58 S.W. 418, 22 Ky. L. Rptr. 497, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 634 (Ky. 1900).

  4. Mortgages. 

 This section was not applicable to sales under foreclosure of mortgages. McGuire v. Cope, 225 Ky. 521, 9 S.W.2d 528, 1928 Ky. LEXIS 817 (Ky. 1928).

 Where property was indivisible, it was proper for the chancellor, in ordering the sale of a residence used as a home, to direct that $1,000 of the sale price over and above the first mortgage be invested in a homestead for the debtor. Gibbs v. Deins, 282 Ky. 625, 139 S.W.2d 430, 1940 Ky. LEXIS 218 (Ky. 1940).

  5. Sale of Property. 

  6. — Under $1,000. 

 Execution sale of land worth less than $1,000 was invalid notwithstanding consent or not of defendant thereto. Meade v. Wright, 56 S.W. 523, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 1806, 1900 Ky. LEXIS 431 (Ky. Ct. App. 1900).

 Sale of homestead for $761 over objection of surviving husband was erroneous. Anderson's Adm'r v. Creekmore, 216 Ky. 345, 287 S.W. 941, 1926 Ky. LEXIS 928 (Ky. 1926).

  7. Surviving Spouse. 

 When the homestead of a decedent was sold, the widow was not entitled to $1,000 absolutely out of the proceeds, but had merely a life interest therein. Sansberry v. Simms' Adm'x, 79 Ky. 527, 3 Ky. L. Rptr. 303, 1881 Ky. LEXIS 71 (Ky. 1881) (decided under prior law).

  Cited: 

 Taylor v. Shelton, 227 Ky. 473, 13 S.W.2d 506, 1929 Ky. LEXIS 904 (Ky. 1929).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Cross-References. 

Voluntary assignment, homestead may be sold and money paid assignor, KRS 379.080.

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Bratt, Family Protection Under Kentucky’s Inheritance Laws: Is the Family Really Protected? 76 Ky. L.J. 387 (1987-88).

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Practice Context for Homestead Exemption, § 155.00.

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, Property Rights, § 14.4.


427.100.  Waiver of homestead exemption — Continuance after death.

Text

No mortgage, release or waiver of an exemption granted by KRS 427.060 shall be valid unless it is in writing, subscribed by the defendant and his spouse, and acknowledged and recorded in the same manner as conveyances of real estate. The exemption in favor of an execution debtor or one against whom judgment has been rendered shall continue after the debtor’s death for the benefit of his surviving spouse and children, but shall be estimated in allotting dower or curtesy.

History

History.
1706: amend. Acts 1974, ch. 386, § 100.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Acknowledgment.

2. Contracts.

  3. — Exchange.

  4. — Sale.

5. Deeds.

6. Mortgages.

  7. — Joinder by Wife.

  8. — — Involuntary.

  9. — — Under Age of 21.

  10. — Wife’s Name in Body.

  11. — Delayed Recording.

  12. — Express Waivers.

  13. — Incapacity of Spouse.

14. Sales.

  15. — Coercive.

  16. — Joinder by Wife.

  17. Acknowledgment and recording.

  18. Assignments.

  19. Infants.

  20. Sale.

  1. Acknowledgment. 

 Mortgage without valid acknowledgment was invalid and homestead was thus exempt as against equitable lien declared in foreclosure action. Sousley v. Citizens' Bank of Nepton, 168 Ky. 150, 181 S.W. 960, 1916 Ky. LEXIS 516 (Ky. 1916).

  2. Contracts. 

  3. — Exchange. 

 A contract signed by the husband and wife for the exchange of a homestead is enforceable against the wife as well as the husband. James v. Jones, 127 S.W. 795, 1910 Ky. LEXIS 755 (Ky. 1910).

  4. — Sale. 

 This section does not apply to a voluntary sale of the homestead by the husband and wife, and hence a contract for sale is enforceable though not acknowledged. James v. Jones, 127 S.W. 795, 1910 Ky. LEXIS 755 (Ky. 1910).

  5. Deeds. 

 Deed by husband conveying homestead to another, though not signed by wife, effectively bars wife from claiming homestead right after husband’s death, and she has only her right of dower in the land, which she may assert at any time during her lifetime. Pugh v. Pugh, 279 Ky. 170, 130 S.W.2d 40, 1939 Ky. LEXIS 253 (Ky. 1939). See Gullett v. Arnett, 44 S.W. 957, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 1892 (1898); Hanna's Assignees v. Gay, 117 Ky. 695, 78 S.W. 915, 25 Ky. L. Rptr. 1794, 1904 Ky. LEXIS 236 (Ky. 1904).

  6. Mortgages. 

 A bona fide housekeeper with a family residing on his mortgaged land is entitled to homestead exemption in the absence of a valid release or waiver of the homestead right according to the provisions of the statute. Young v. Phillips, 8 Ky. Op. 712, 1876 Ky. LEXIS 215 (Ky. Ct. App. May 13, 1876) (decided under prior law).

 Unless the homestead is expressly reserved, it cannot be claimed in a mortgaged estate before satisfying the mortgage debt. Kaufman v. Haish, 1 Ky. L. Rptr. 55 (1880) (decided under prior law).

 A mortgage executed by the husband alone does not deprive either him or his wife of the homestead exemption in the land mortgaged. Atkinson v. Gowdy's Adm'r, 8 S.W. 698, 10 Ky. L. Rptr. 173, 1888 Ky. LEXIS 173 (Ky. Ct. App. 1888). See Thorn v. Darlington, 69 Ky. 448, 1869 Ky. LEXIS 181 (Ky. 1869); Dixon v. McClure, 10 Ky. Op. 392, 1879 Ky. LEXIS 248 (Ky. Ct. App. Nov. 26, 1879) (decided under prior law).

 Wife who joined in husband’s mortgage of his land waived her right therein where there was express language of such waiver, even without her name appearing in granting clause. Davis v. Jenkins, 93 Ky. 353, 20 S.W. 283, 14 Ky. L. Rptr. 342, 1892 Ky. LEXIS 104 (Ky. 1892) (decided under prior law).

  7. — Joinder by Wife. 

 Failure of the wife to join in a mortgage does not render it an absolute nullity, and other creditors of the mortgagor have no right to question its validity if the mortgagor chooses to waive the exemption. Taylor v. Dismuke, 15 Ky. L. Rptr. 703 (1894).

 Mortgage signed by husband and wife waived wife’s homestead exemption where there was statement therein that “I hereby mortgage  . . . . .  land on which I now reside.” Hays v. Froman, 103 Ky. 350, 45 S.W. 87, 20 Ky. L. Rptr. 53, 1897 Ky. LEXIS 244 (Ky. 1897).

 Mortgage was ineffective as to waiver of homestead where wife’s name appeared in no place therein other than signature. Massillon Engine & Thresher Co. v. Carr, 71 S.W. 859, 24 Ky. L. Rptr. 1534, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 247 (Ky. Ct. App. 1902).

 Where wife joined in mortgage, it was of no consequence that pronouns therein were in singular rather than plural number. Bray v. Ellison, 83 S.W. 96, 26 Ky. L. Rptr. 1039, 1904 Ky. LEXIS 282 (Ky. Ct. App. 1904).

 Wife’s joinder was not required in husband’s mortgage given to pay homestead purchase price or to build house. Ratliff v. Anderson & Ratliff, 195 Ky. 320, 242 S.W. 35, 1922 Ky. LEXIS 311 (Ky. 1922). See Norvell v. Faulk, 282 Ky. 591, 139 S.W.2d 428, 1940 Ky. LEXIS 217 (Ky. 1940).

 Mortgage signed by husband and wife conveying entire estate was sufficient to relinquish homestead right, and specific mention thereof was not required. Arnett v. Salyersville Nat'l Bank, 242 Ky. 216, 46 S.W.2d 124, 1931 Ky. LEXIS 717 (Ky. 1931). See Carr v. Britton, 267 Ky. 802, 103 S.W.2d 300, 1937 Ky. LEXIS 396 (Ky. 1937).

  8. — — Involuntary. 

 Wife who joined in mortgage involuntarily and under husband’s inducement was nevertheless bound thereby, since she understood quite well what she was doing and there was no duress by mortgagee. Tackitt v. Tackitt's Adm'r, 127 S.W. 987, 1910 Ky. LEXIS 718 (Ky. 1910).

  9. — — Under Age of 21. 

 There was no waiver where wife signing mortgage was under the age of 21. Schlenker v. Clark, 226 Ky. 665, 11 S.W.2d 725, 1928 Ky. LEXIS 157 (Ky. 1928).

  10. — Wife’s Name in Body. 

 There was waiver where wife’s name appeared in body of mortgage, and there was acknowledgment certificate showing that she relinquished her dower and that such mortgage was act and deed of wife for named purposes therein. Long v. Branham, 99 S.W. 271, 30 Ky. L. Rptr. 552 (1907).

  11. — Delayed Recording. 

 Delayed recording of mortgage joined in by wife did not invalidate it as to such wife. Pryse v. People's Bldg. Loan & Sav. Ass'n, 41 S.W. 574, 19 Ky. L. Rptr. 752 (1897).

  12. — Express Waivers. 

 Mortgage was valid waiver where it expressly stated that all right to land thereof was waived under exemption laws of state. Head v. Auberry, 38 S.W. 863, 18 Ky. L. Rptr. 898 (1897).

  13. — Incapacity of Spouse. 

 Mortgage void as to mentally incapacitated spouse and was void as to other spouse as well. Ballinger v. Lester, 113 Ky. 96, 67 S.W. 266, 23 Ky. L. Rptr. 2353, 1902 Ky. LEXIS 24 (Ky. 1902). See Stafford v. Tarter, 96 S.W. 1127, 29 Ky. L. Rptr. 1184 (1906).

  14. Sales. 

  15. — Coercive. 

 Sales which are coercive come within purview of this section. Hensley v. Morgan, 193 Ky. 718, 237 S.W. 370, 1922 Ky. LEXIS 52 (Ky. 1922).

  16. — Joinder by Wife. 

 Husband who abandoned wife could sell his own property without wife’s joinder. Brannon v. Bohannon, 265 Ky. 394, 96 S.W.2d 1036, 1936 Ky. LEXIS 494 (Ky. 1936).

  17. Acknowledgment and recording. 

 A release of a homestead, though in writing, is not valid where it is not acknowledged and recorded in the same manner as a conveyance of real estate. Braun v. Fogle, 12 Ky. Op. 432, 5 Ky. L. Rptr. 607, 1884 Ky. LEXIS 185 (Ky. Ct. App. Jan. 24, 1884) (decided under prior law).

  18. Assignments. 

 Where wife did not join in husband’s assignment for benefit of creditors, homestead was waived by neither. Hemphill v. Haas, 88 Ky. 492, 11 S.W. 510, 11 Ky. L. Rptr. 62, 1889 Ky. LEXIS 64 (Ky. 1889) (decided under prior law).

  19. Infants. 

 There can be no waiver of a homestead by a husband and wife except in the mode provided by the statute, and there being no statute by which infants can waive the homestead, they have no such right. Lawrence v. Lawrence's Adm'r, 10 Ky. Op. 353, 1879 Ky. LEXIS 226 (Ky. Ct. App. Oct. 15, 1879) (decided under prior law).

  20. Sale. 

 The owner of a homestead does not waive his right thereto by his failure to claim it at the sale and by his purchase under the sale and his consent to a resale in satisfaction of his sale bond, as he cannot waive or release it except in the mode pointed out by the statute. Crout v. Sauter, 76 Ky. 442, 1877 Ky. LEXIS 85 (Ky. 1877) (decided under prior law).

  Cited: 

 Warfield Natural Gas Co. v. Ward, 286 Ky. 73, 149 S.W.2d 705, 1940 Ky. LEXIS 1 (Ky. 1940).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Vahlsing and Hudson, Inchoate Dower — An Idea Whose Time Is Past, 60 Ky. L.J. 671 (1972).

Bratt, Family Protection Under Kentucky’s Inheritance Laws: Is the Family Really Protected? 76 Ky. L.J. 387 (1987-88).

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Practice Context for Homestead Exemption, § 155.00.

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, Property Rights, § 14.3.


427.110.  Insurance benefits—Exemptions.

Text

(1) Any money or other benefit to be paid or rendered by any assessment or cooperative life or casualty insurance company is exempt from execution or other process to subject such money or other benefit to the payment of any debt or liability of a policyholder.

(2) Any money or other benefit to be paid or rendered by any fraternal benefit society is exempt from attachment, garnishment or other process to subject such money or other benefit to the payment of any debt or liability of a member or beneficiary, or any other person who may have a right thereunder, either before or after payment.

History

History.
671, 681c-21.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Beneficiaries.

2. Cooperative Insurance.

3. Fraud.

4. Homesteads.

5. Personalty.

6. Loan Value or Cash Surrender Value.

7. Fraternal Benefits.

  1. Beneficiaries. 

 Where testator’s children were beneficiaries of his life insurance, proceeds thereof were exempt as against debts of his estate. Thompson v. Latimer, 209 Ky. 491, 273 S.W. 65, 1925 Ky. LEXIS 527 (Ky. 1925).

  2. Cooperative Insurance. 

 Exemption of cooperative insurance fund did not apply after it was invested in real estate, except to extent of homestead and other exemptions allowed otherwise under KRS 427.060. J. S. Merrell Drug Co. v. Dixon, 131 Ky. 212, 115 S.W. 179, 1909 Ky. LEXIS 14 (Ky. 1909).

  3. Fraud.
