 Premiums paid by insured on a policy in a fraternal insurance organization, in fraud of creditors, are not recoverable from his widow, the beneficiary in said policy. Williams v. Harth, 156 Ky. 702, 161 S.W. 1102, 1914 Ky. LEXIS 172 (Ky. 1914).

  4. Homesteads. 

 The proceeds of insurance of the homestead were exempt from execution. Bernheim v. Davitt, 5 S.W. 193, 9 Ky. L. Rptr. 229 (1887) (decided under prior law).

 Insurance money not exceeding $1,000 from exempt property is itself exempt, as is also subsequent homestead purchased or rebuilt with such money. Rulo v. Murphy, 51 S.W. 312, 21 Ky. L. Rptr. 295 (1899).

  5. Personalty. 

 Insurance proceeds from burned exempt furniture were exempt. Wallins Nat'l Bank v. Turner, 221 Ky. 562, 299 S.W. 194, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 775 (Ky. 1927).

 Insurance proceeds from destroyed exempt personalty were exempt as to value of such personalty not replaced as of judgment. Wallins Nat'l Bank v. Turner, 221 Ky. 562, 299 S.W. 194, 1927 Ky. LEXIS 775 (Ky. 1927).

  6. Loan Value or Cash Surrender Value. 

 This section does not restrict “any money or other benefit to be paid  . . . . . ” as exemptible only upon death but rather it denotes an exemption extending to the debtor on any monetary value or benefits accruing by virtue of ownership. Thus, the loan values or the cash surrender values of life insurance policies by virtue of the enactment of the legislature have been deemed exempt under this section since the term “any money  . . . . .  to be paid” is not restricted as to time of election and offers no alternative but to include the cash surrender value within its definition. In re Worthington, 28 B.R. 736, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 6649 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983).

  7. Fraternal Benefits. 

 Where the fraternal charter provided that the funds should be for the relief of the member’s family and should be exempt from seizure under legal process to pay any debt of the deceased member, a certificate, payable to the widow of the member, was for the benefit of the member’s family, and could not be seized, upon the death of the member, by the widow’s creditors. Schillinger v. Boes, 85 Ky. 357, 3 S.W. 427, 9 Ky. L. Rptr. 18, 1887 Ky. LEXIS 52 (Ky. 1887) (decided under prior law).

  Cited: 

 Kash’s Ex’r v. Kash, 260 Ky. 508, 86 S.W.2d 273, 1935 Ky. LEXIS 506 (Ky. 1935); Department of Welfare v. Farmer’s Committee, 290 Ky. 813, 162 S.W.2d 796, 1942 Ky. LEXIS 500 (Ky. 1942); Ball v. Smiddy, 249 S.W.2d 715, 1952 Ky. LEXIS 838 (Ky. 1952).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Cross-References. 

Assessment or cooperative insurance, KRS ch. 299.

Fraternal benefit societies, KRS 304.29-111 to 304.29-590.

Life insurance proceeds, rights of beneficiary as against creditor, KRS 304.14-300.

  Kentucky Bench & Bar. 

Bland, The Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978: An Overview, Vol. 44, No. 1, January 1980, Ky. Bench & Bar 8.

  Treatises 

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, Business Transactions, § 15.11.

  ALR 

Right, with respect to exempt proceeds of life insurance, of one whose funds have been wrongfully used to pay premiums. 24 A.L.R.2d 672.

Retirement or pension proceeds or annuity payments under group insurance as subject to attachment or garnishment. 28 A.L.R.2d 1213.

Endowment policy as life insurance within exemption law. 30 A.L.R.2d 751.

Beneficiary, option to change. 30 A.L.R.2d 756.

Cash surrender option. 30 A.L.R.2d 757.

Exemption of proceeds of national service life insurance from claims of creditors. 54 A.L.R.2d 1335.


427.120.  Police and firefighters’ pension fund in cities of the first, second, and third classes — Exempt from process in some cases. [Repealed.]

History

History.
2872b-4, 2896b-14, 3142b-18, 3351a-18: amend. Acts 1978, ch. 164, § 52, effective June 17, 1978; 1998, ch. 255, § 31, effective July 15, 1998.

Annotations

 Compiler's Notes. 

 This section (2872b-4, 2896b-14, 3142b-18, 3351a-18: amend. Acts 1978, ch. 164, § 52, effective June 17, 1978;   1998, ch. 255, § 31, effective July 15, 1998) was repealed by Acts   2014, ch. 92, § 314, effective January 1, 2015.

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  1. Marital Property. 

 Husband’s pension from police department was not exempt from division as marital property as part of decree of dissolution. Glidewell v. Glidewell, 859 S.W.2d 675, 1993 Ky. App. LEXIS 51 (Ky. Ct. App. 1993).

 Opinions of Attorney General. 

 Based upon the principle that a child support obligation is not to be considered as an ordinary contractual debt, but a moral obligation imposed by the state, and that the policy of KRS Chapter 67A is to provide benefits for the fund’s member as well as his or her dependents, such benefits may be subject to attachment, assignment, or garnishment for purposes of enforcing a child support order. OAG 91-158.

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Cross-References. 

Police and firemen’s pension funds in cities of second and third classes to be used solely for pensions, KRS 95.620.

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Kentucky Law Survey, Graham, Domestic Relations, 73 Ky. L.J. 379 (1984-85).

  Northern Kentucky Law Review. 

Schechter, Survey of Kentucky Family Law Decisions Rendered In 1993, 21 N. Ky. L. Rev. 387 (1994).


427.125.  Police and firefighters’ pension fund in cities of fourth class — Exempt from process in some cases.

Text

No portion of a pension fund created under KRS 95.761 to 95.784 shall, before or after its order for distribution by the board of trustees to the persons entitled thereto, be held, seized, taken, subjected to or detained or levied upon by virtue of any attachments, execution, injunction, writ, interlocutory, or other order, or decree, or any process or proceeding whatever issued out of or by any court of this state for the payment or satisfaction, in whole or in part, of any debt, damage, claim, demand, or judgment against the beneficiary of said fund, except for court or administratively ordered child support, or owed or to-be-owed child support, but said fund shall be held and distributed for the purpose of KRS 95.761 to 95.784, and for no other purpose whatever.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1942, ch. 9, § 23; 1998, ch. 255, § 32, effective July 15, 1998; 2016 ch. 31, § 35, effective July 15, 2016.

Annotations

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Kentucky Law Survey, Graham, Domestic Relations, 73 Ky. L.J. 379 (1984-85).


427.126.  Pension fund for county patrolmen in certain counties; exempt from process. [Repealed.]

Annotations

 Compiler’s Notes. 

 This section (Acts 1944, ch. 132, § 26) was repealed by Acts 1966, ch. 255, § 283.


427.130.  Salaries of public officials and employees and sums due from governmental agencies are subject to attachment or garnishment — Service of process.

Text

(1) Salaries or sums due state, county, city and school board officers and employees shall be subject to attachment or garnishment.

(2) All sums due any person from the Commonwealth of Kentucky, or any agency or department thereof, and all sums due from any county school board, city or county, shall be subject to attachment or garnishment.

(3) Service of attachments or garnishments upon the Commonwealth of Kentucky shall be made by serving the secretary of the finance and administration cabinet, and the state treasurer. No attachment or garnishment served upon the Commonwealth shall be valid unless the process shall specify the name of the employee, or other creditor, and the budget unit and division thereof through which the sum alleged to be due is payable.

History

History.
1701b: amend. Acts 1942, ch. 102, §§ 1, 2; 1948, ch. 188, § 1.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Constitutionality.

2. Application.

3. Assignment of Salaries.

4. Attachment.

5. Public Officers.

6. Poor Farm.

  1. Constitutionality. 

 This section does not contravene Ky. Const., § 133 or  § 235. Batesville Casket Co. v. Fields, 288 Ky. 104, 155 S.W.2d 743, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 63 (Ky. 1941) (decision prior to 1942 amendment).

  2. Application. 

 This section applies to both constitutional and elective officers. Batesville Casket Co. v. Fields, 288 Ky. 104, 155 S.W.2d 743, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 63 (Ky. 1941) (decision prior to 1942 amendment).

  3. Assignment of Salaries. 

 This section does not alter the rule that assignment of the salary of a public officer before it is due is against public policy. Batesville Casket Co. v. Fields, 288 Ky. 104, 155 S.W.2d 743, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 63 (Ky. 1941) (decision prior to 1942 amendment).

  4. Attachment. 

 Salary of a state officer may not be attached until the end of the month. Batesville Casket Co. v. Fields, 288 Ky. 104, 155 S.W.2d 743, 1941 Ky. LEXIS 63 (Ky. 1941) (decision prior to 1942 amendment).

  5. Public Officers. 

 In enactment of this section, legislature did not intend to include “public officers” within its terms, as opposed to “public employees.” Varden v. Ridings, 20 F. Supp. 495, 1937 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 1650 (D. Ky. 1937) (decision prior to 1942 amendment).

  6. Poor Farm. 

 Inmate maintenance funds payable to county poor farm keeper were exempt from garnishment or attachment. Miracle v. Hopkins, 260 Ky. 712, 86 S.W.2d 681, 1935 Ky. LEXIS 545 (Ky. 1935) (decided under prior law).

  Cited: 

 Knox County v. Melton, 268 Ky. 649, 105 S.W.2d 816, 1937 Ky. LEXIS 513 (Ky. 1937); Main Line Engineering Constr. Service, Inc. v. Hutcheson, 428 S.W.2d 775, 1968 Ky. LEXIS 726 (Ky. 1968).

 Opinions of Attorney General. 

 Where a state employee wrongfully used a gasoline credit card, furnished to him by the Commonwealth, to purchase personal gasoline and groceries in the amount of $436.74 and the employee had accrued wages of $407.83 which were unpaid, the Commonwealth could withhold the pay of the employee as an offset against his improper expenditure. OAG 61-834.

 The use of the term “employer” in the 1970 amendment to KRS 425.210 (now repealed) does not affect the requirements of this section relative to the service of attachments or garnishments on the wages of employees of the Commonwealth which, pursuant to the provisions of this section, will continue to be made by serving the commissioner of finance or the state treasurer. OAG 70-246.

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Complaint Against Resident Defendant, Form 150.01.


427.140.  Employee may not be discharged for garnishment for one (1) indebtedness.

Text

No employer may discharge any employee by reason of the fact that his earnings have been subjected to garnishment for any one (1) indebtedness.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1970, ch. 217, § 3.

Annotations

 Opinions of Attorney General. 

 This section, by strong implication, authorizes the discharge or dismissal of a state employee where such employee is subject to garnishment for more than one indebtedness; a statute need not expressly state what is necessarily implied. OAG 78-433.

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Murrell, The Uniform Consumer Credit Code: Changes It Would Make in Kentucky Law, 60 Ky. L.J. 62 (1971).


427.150.  Property totally or partially exempt.

Text

(1) To the extent reasonably necessary for the support of an individual and his dependents in addition to property totally exempt under subsection (2) of this section, that individual shall be entitled to exemption of money or property received and rights to receive money or property for alimony, support, or separate maintenance.

(2) An individual shall be entitled to exemption of the following property:

  (a) An award under a crime victim’s reparation law;

  (b) A payment on account of the wrongful death of an individual of whom the debtor was a dependent, to the extent reasonably necessary for the support of the debtor and any dependent of the debtor;

  (c) A payment, not to exceed seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500), on account of personal bodily injury, not including pain and suffering or compensation for actual pecuniary loss, of the debtor or an individual of whom the debtor is a dependent;

  (d) A payment in compensation of loss of future earnings of the debtor or an individual of whom the debtor is or was a dependent, to the extent reasonably necessary for the support of the debtor and any dependent of the debtor;

  (e) Assets held, payments made and amounts payable under pensions exempt pursuant to KRS 61.690, 161.700, and 427.125; or

  (f) The right or interest of a person in an individual retirement account or annuity, deferred compensation account, tax sheltered annuity, simplified employee pension, pension, profit-sharing, stock bonus, or other retirement plan described in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, or Section 408 or 408A of the Internal Revenue Code, as amended which qualifies for the deferral of income tax until the date benefits are distributed. This exemption shall also apply to the operation of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, for the purpose of applying the provisions of 11 U.S.C. sec. 522(b)(3) in a federal bankruptcy proceeding and only to the extent otherwise allowed by applicable federal law. This exemption shall not apply to any amounts contributed to an individual retirement account or annuity, deferred compensation account, a pension, profit-sharing, stock bonus, or other qualified retirement plan or annuity if the contribution occurs within one hundred twenty (120) days:

  1. Before the debtor files for bankruptcy if this exemption is being applied in a federal bankruptcy proceeding; or

  2. Before the earlier of the entry of the judgment or other ruling against the debtor or the issuance of the levy, attachment, garnishment, or other execution or order against which this exemption is being applied, if this exemption is being applied in other than a federal bankruptcy proceeding. This exemption shall not apply to the right or interest of a person in an individual retirement account or annuity, deferred compensation account, pension, profit-sharing, stock bonus, or other retirement plan to the extent that that right or interest is subject to any of the following:

  a. An order of a court for payment of maintenance;

  b. An order of a court for payment of child support.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1980, ch. 236, § 8, effective April 9, 1980; 1990, ch. 220, § 2, effective July 13, 1990; 1998, ch. 376, § 1, effective July 15, 1998; 2010, ch. 155, § 5, effective July 15, 2010; 2014, ch. 92, § 313, effective January 1, 2015.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Construction.

2. Legislative Intent.

3. Similar Plan or Contract.

4. Individual Retirement Accounts.

5. Reasonably Necessary Test.

  6. — Evidence.

7. Pension and Profit Sharing Plans.

8. Burden of Proof.

9. Personal Injury Action.

10. Spousal Maintenance.

  1. Construction. 

 It was Congress’s intent to foreclose all non-federal regulation of ERISA-qualified plans, except for some very limited, explicitly described exceptions; therefore, no provision of this section may be utilized to circumvent or otherwise diminish the operation of the anti-alienation provisions of ERISA. In re Rushing, 246 B.R. 291, 2000 Bankr. LEXIS 283 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 2000).

  2. Legislative Intent. 

 When the Kentucky Legislature enacted this section, its inclusion of the words, “similar plan or contract” simply evidenced legislative intent not to restrict exempt status to only those arrangements specifically enumerated within the statute, and the provisions of this section are entitled to an expansive reading. In re Peklenk, 106 B.R. 119, 1989 Bankr. LEXIS 1755 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1989).

  3. Similar Plan or Contract. 

 The legislature in enacting this section did not intend to restrict exempt status to only those arrangements expressly set forth therein, since it recognized the existence of other sophisticated benefit systems regardless of their generic term under the all-encompassing phrase “similar plan or contract” in subdivision (1)(b). To be thus included the similar plan or contract must possess the characteristics of those programs expressly stated or be so parallel in nature as to serve the same goals or purposes. In re Worthington, 28 B.R. 736, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 6649 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983).

  4. Individual Retirement Accounts. 

 The sophistication of deferred compensation plans and programs precludes an exhaustive identification of such arrangements, and thus, the phrase “similar plan or contract” in subdivision (1)(b) must by its adoption include those plans closely parallel in nature to the specifics named. It is well recognized that Individual Retirement Account (IRA) accounts do possess these traits in that benefits through contributions of a tax-deferred nature do flow to the debtor and his dependents under a formalized plan conditioned upon certain prospective elections or future events, and mandating that such accounts to be deemed a qualified plan must adhere to rigid requirements monitored by the Internal Revenue Service. In re Worthington, 28 B.R. 736, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 6649 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983).

 An Individual Retirement Account (IRA) is a “similar plan or contract” under subdivision (1)(b) of this section; accordingly, in a bankruptcy action the cash value of the bankrupt debtor’s IRA account was exempt under subdivision (1)(b). In re Worthington, 28 B.R. 736, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 6649 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983).

  5. Reasonably Necessary Test. 

 To determine if the reasonably necessary test has been met, the court must examine all of the facts and circumstances including the debtor’s age, earning capacity, present and future financial needs, ability to insure against future disruptions in earning capacity, and his ability to reestablish a retirement fund. In re Slezak, 63 B.R. 625, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 5556 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986); In re Fisher, 63 B.R. 649, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 5533 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

 The amount claimed exempt, $69,073, was reasonably necessary for the support of the debtor and his dependents upon his retirement, illness or disability, where at age 61, the debtor in all probability did not have but a few more years to practice medicine, and the debtor, a physician was in bankruptcy after over 25 years of practice. In re Fisher, 63 B.R. 649, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 5533 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

  6. — Evidence. 

 Where, in a bankruptcy action, the court did not have sufficient evidence of the number of the debtors’ dependents and the debtor and his family’s current and future income and expenses, the court set the matter for a hearing to allow the debtor to submit additional proof on the issue of what was reasonably necessary for the support of himself and his dependents. In re Slezak, 63 B.R. 625, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 5556 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

  7. Pension and Profit Sharing Plans. 

 The debtor’s interest in his Keogh Plan, Pension and Profit Sharing Plan, and IRA were included under subdivision (1)(b) of this section. In re Fisher, 63 B.R. 649, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 5533 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

 Where the income participation section of a partnership agreement plainly recited that payments made thereunder are made only upon a partner’s retirement, death or total disability, whether such payments were characterized as a pension, profit-sharing plan or similar plan or contract was of little consequence as all are exempt to the extent reasonably necessary for the support of the debtor and his dependents; however, where debtor, in consideration for a loan, granted a security interest in those payments, the payments were an exempt asset subject to that security interest. In re Peklenk, 106 B.R. 119, 1989 Bankr. LEXIS 1755 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1989).

 The debtor was not entitled to relief where he failed to meet his affirmative duty to disclose a certificate of deposit as an asset to the bankruptcy court pursuant to 11 USCS § 521(1), and he was not allowed to claim an exemption as a pension fund under KRS 427.150. Azbill v. Kendrick (In re Azbill), 2008 Bankr. LEXIS 527 (B.A.P. 6th Cir. Mar. 11, 2008).

  8. Burden of Proof. 

 Where an issue as to an exemption is left in doubt by the proof, so that the court would be required to speculate, the party upon whom the burden of proof ultimately rests must lose. In re Blizard, 81 B.R. 431, 1988 Bankr. LEXIS 59 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1988).

  9. Personal Injury Action. 

 The burden was upon bankruptcy trustee to establish by proof that all of the $14,000 settlement with the insurer received by the individual who sustained a 40% permanent partial functional disability and incurred medical bills of over $50,000 as the result of a motorcycle accident was on account of personal injury rather than the various other causes of action making up a personal injury action, and since under the facts in the action, it was impossible for the trustee to sustain that burden, his objection to the exemption of all $14,000 would be overruled. In re Blizard, 81 B.R. 431, 1988 Bankr. LEXIS 59 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1988).

 Debtors were not precluded from claiming an exemption for any part of their personal injury settlement merely because debtor’s whole source of income was government assistance; fact that debtors had no jobs did not mean that settlement of their personal injury claims lacked any future earnings component. In re Gilbert, 213 B.R. 502, 1997 Bankr. LEXIS 1677 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 1997).

 Payments for emotional or mental symptoms experienced by the debtor such as fright, shock, stress, aggravation, embarrassment, humiliation, depression, emotional discomfort, loss of sleep, nervousness, anxiety, and emotional and mental distress will be excluded from the subsection (2)(c) exemption; any payments for physical manifestations, however, will be deemed exempt. In re Barner, 239 B.R. 139, 1999 Bankr. LEXIS 1203 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1999).

 The court rejected the argument that only a debtor’s monetary recovery for permanent injuries falls within the exemption created by subsection (2)(c). In re Barner, 239 B.R. 139, 1999 Bankr. LEXIS 1203 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1999).

 Trustee had the burden of proving that the debtor could not take a claimed exemption for an annuity that the debtor received as part of a settlement for a personal injury lawsuit, and absent proof to the contrary the debtor was entitled to take a deduction of $57,500 for future lost wages, pursuant to KRS 427.150(2)(d). In re Menefee, 2004 Bankr. LEXIS 2525 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. Dec. 8, 2004).

 Where a settlement agreement specifically stated that payments made to debtor (then plaintiff) constituted damages for personal injuries, debtor’s monthly annuity payments were not exempt under KRS 427.150(2) as payments for lost future earnings even though debtor released her claims for lost future earnings as part of the settlement; the parties specifically agreed to treatment of the payments as damages for personal injuries for tax purposes, and the unambiguous language of the agreement prevailed over later credible testimony about the “underlying meanings” of the agreement. Prjchard v. Wheatley, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 65043 (W.D. Ky. Sept. 11, 2006).

 Where the settlement clearly stated that the payments were on account of “personal physical injuries,” and the court could not find that it covered future lost wages when a plain reading of the document gave no such indication, the post-petition annuity payments were exempt up to $7,500 under KRS 427.150(2)(c), but the annuity payments in excess of $7,500 were not exempt under KRS 427.150(2)(d) because they were on account of personal injuries and not future lost wages. In re Prichard, 339 B.R. 635, 2006 Bankr. LEXIS 602 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 2006), aff'd, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 65043 (W.D. Ky. Sept. 11, 2006).

  10. Spousal Maintenance. 

 Husband was not entitled to an evidentiary hearing on his order for a non-wage garnishment of the wife’s spousal maintenance to pay the debt owed by the parties to the husband’s parents; the family court did not need to reach the issue of whether the maintenance was subject to exemption because the proper method to enforce the debt was for the husband or parents to obtain a separate judgment or collect the debt by a separate lawsuit. Fortwengler v. Fortwengler, 2012 Ky. App. LEXIS 295 (Ky. Ct. App. Dec. 21, 2012), review denied, ordered not published, 2013 Ky. LEXIS 671 (Ky. Dec. 11, 2013).

  Cited in: 

 In re T L G Computing Services, Inc., 20 B.R. 568, 1982 Bankr. LEXIS 3987 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1982); MPM Fin. Group, Inc. v. Morton, 289 S.W.3d 193, 2009 Ky. LEXIS 146 (Ky. 2009).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Bench & Bar. 

Gilman, When Are Pension Benefits Protected From the Claims of Creditors?, Volume 55, No. 1, Winter 1991 Ky. Bench & B. 19.

Morris, Estate Planning for Retirement Benefits, Volume 74, No. 6, November 2010, Ky. Bench & Bar 14.   

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Comments, Is an IRA Exempt Property Under the Kentucky Exemption Statute KRS Section 427.150(1)(b)?, 73 Ky. L.J. 1127 (1984-85).

  Treatises 

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, 1991 Supp., Custody of Children, § 27.13.

Petrilli, Kentucky Family Law, 1991 Supp., Maintenance, § 25.28.


427.160.  Additional general exemption.

Text

Solely for the purpose of applying the provisions of 11 U.S.C. sec. 522(b)(3)(A) in a federal bankruptcy proceeding, in addition to other exemptions provided in this chapter and only to the extent otherwise allowed by applicable federal law, every debtor shall have a general exemption not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000) in value to be applied toward any property, real or personal, tangible or intangible in his estate when he or she has filed for bankruptcy under the provisions of The Bankruptcy Code of 1978, 92 Stat. 2549 (1978), Public Law 95-598, as amended.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1980, ch. 236, § 9, effective April 9, 1980; 2010, ch. 155, § 6, effective July 15, 2010.

Annotations

 Compiler’s Notes. 

 The Bankruptcy Code of 1978, referred to in this section, can be found throughout Title 11 of the United States Code.

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Method of Claiming.

2. Corporate Debtors.

3. Garnished Wages.

4. Impairment of Exemption.

  1. Method of Claiming. 

 Where exemptions of the debtor in federal income tax refund and wages were not properly claimed because the debtor failed to specify what property was being claimed exempt, in what amount, and under what statute, bankruptcy trustee’s objection to such exemptions would be sustained. In re Bolden, 20 B.R. 686, 1981 Bankr. LEXIS 2364 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1981).

  2. Corporate Debtors. 

 The absence of the word “individual” in this section is so obvious that it must have been intentional; accordingly, Kentucky corporations are entitled to a general $1,000 exemption in bankruptcy. In re T L G Computing Services, Inc., 20 B.R. 568, 1982 Bankr. LEXIS 3987 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1982), but see In re Nix Heating & Air Conditioning, Inc., 108 B.R. 1012, 1990 Bankr. LEXIS 269 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1990).

 If a corporation is not entitled “to other exemptions,” a fortiori, it cannot be entitled to an “additional exemption,” therefore, the corporate debtor is not entitled to receive an exemption in this section. (Rejecting rationale utilized in In re TLG Computing Servs., Inc., 20 Bankr. 568, 1982 Bankr. LEXIS 3987 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1982)).In re Nix Heating & Air Conditioning, Inc., 108 B.R. 1012, 1990 Bankr. LEXIS 269 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1990).

  3. Garnished Wages. 

 The debtor could claim wages garnished by a creditor as exempt under this section, the “wild card” exemption provision. In re Harville, 60 B.R. 188, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 6320 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

  4. Impairment of Exemption. 

 Where the judicial lien on the debtor’s garnished wages impaired the exemption available to the debtor pursuant to this section, the judicial lien could be avoided. In re Harville, 63 B.R. 371, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 5671 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986).

 Because the debtor could exempt a portion of her tax refund as Earned Income Credit benefits under KRS 205.220(3) and another portion under the general exemption statute of KRS 427.160, and those exemptions were not subject to levy under 11 USCS § 522(c), the Internal Revenue Service was granted relief from the automatic stay to offset only the remaining amount of the refund under 11 USCS § 553. In re Sharp, 286 B.R. 627, 2002 Bankr. LEXIS 954 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 2002).

  Cited: 

 In re Dubrock, 5 B.R. 353, 1980 Bankr. LEXIS 4748 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1980); In re Schweitzer, 17 B.R. 39, 1981 Bankr. LEXIS 3198 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1981); In re Jeffries, 18 B.R. 682, 1982 Bankr. LEXIS 4405 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1982); In re Steele, 26 B.R. 233, 1982 Bankr. LEXIS 3244 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1982); In re Wright, 34 B.R. 643, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 4972 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983); In re Galloway, 134 B.R. 602, 1991 Bankr. LEXIS 1820 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1991); Fraley v. Commercial Credit, 189 B.R. 398, 1995 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17918 (W.D. Ky. 1995).

 Research References and Practice Aids 

  Kentucky Law Journal. 

Bland, Insolvencies in Farming and Agribusinesses, 73 Ky. L.J. 795 (1984-85).


427.170.  Federal bankruptcy code exemptions applicable in Kentucky.

Text

Solely for the purpose of applying the provisions of 11 U.S.C. sec. 522(b)(2) in a federal bankruptcy proceeding and only to the extent otherwise allowed by applicable federal law, an individual debtor domiciled in this state is authorized to exempt from property of said debtor’s bankruptcy estate the property specified under 11 U.S.C. sec. 522(d).

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1980, ch. 236, § 10, effective April 9, 1980; 2005, ch. 141, § 1, effective June 20, 2005; 2010, ch. 155, § 7, effective July 15, 2010.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

1. Application.

2. Application of KRS 427.060.

3. Availability of Relief Via Motion Practice.

4. Homestead Exemption.

  1. Application. 

 The Bankruptcy Court must apply the Kentucky state exemption statute in bankruptcy cases; thus, exemptions pursuant to 11 USCS § 522(d) are not alternatively available to Kentucky debtors. In re Raymond, 103 B.R. 846, 1989 Bankr. LEXIS 1485 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1989).

 Court of appeals erred in affirming an order granting a debtor’s challenge to a garnishment under KRS 427.170 on the ground that exemptions allowed under 11 U.S.C.S. § 522(d), and incorporated by reference into KRS 427.170, were available to any individual debtor domiciled in Kentucky because KRS 427.170, as modified in 2005, authorized only Kentucky residents in bankruptcy cases to avail themselves of the exemptions specified under § 522(d), and such exemptions were not otherwise available to debtors in Kentucky; the Legislature’s incorporation of § 522(d) into KRS 427.170 by reference thereto, created an ambiguity because it is not clear from the statute alone if the General Assembly intended to also assimilate the federal definitions embodied in the federal statute, or if it intended otherwise, and the legislative record strongly suggests that the Legislature simply chose to “opt-in” the federal exemptions in bankruptcy cases, and to defer for future consideration any other change in the exemptions otherwise allowed under state law. MPM Fin. Group, Inc. v. Morton, 289 S.W.3d 193, 2009 Ky. LEXIS 146 (Ky. 2009).

  2. Application of KRS 427.060. 

 Since the Commonwealth has chosen to opt out of the federal list of exemptions entirely, the district court has to look to KRS 427.060 to determine whether the debtor is entitled to an exemption before 11 USCS § 522(f) can be applied. Commercial Credit Corp. v. Brooks, 71 B.R. 6 (W.D. Ky. 1986), aff'd, In re Brooks, 817 F.2d 104, 1987 U.S. App. LEXIS 5498 (6th Cir. Ky. 1987).

  3. Availability of Relief Via Motion Practice. 

 Lien avoidance matters regarding nonpossessory, nonpurchase money liens on personal property may be decided on motion as the requirement of filing an adversary proceeding is a harsh, and likely unintended, result of the legislature’s “opt out” of the federal exemption scheme. In re Raymond, 103 B.R. 846, 1989 Bankr. LEXIS 1485 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1989).

  4. Homestead Exemption. 

 Kentucky homestead exemption was available to eligible debtors at the time a petition under the Bankruptcy Code was filed where there was no pending sale of the residence; therefore, debtors were entitled to have their motions to avoid the judicial liens of the respective creditors avoided to the extent that the liens impair these valid homestead exemptions. In re Powell, 173 B.R. 338, 1994 Bankr. LEXIS 1634 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 1994).

  Cited: 

 In re Dubrock, 5 B.R. 353, 1980 Bankr. LEXIS 4748 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1980); In re T L G Computing Services, Inc., 20 B.R. 568, 1982 Bankr. LEXIS 3987 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1982); In re Wright, 34 B.R. 643, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 4972 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983); In re Hayden, 41 B.R. 21, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 4946 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 1983); In re Lawson, 42 B.R. 206, 1984 Bankr. LEXIS 5191 (Bankr. E.D. Ky. 1984), rev’d, Credithrift of America v. Lawson, 52 B.R. 369, 1985 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16969 (E.D. Ky. 1985); In re Slezak, 63 B.R. 625, 1986 Bankr. LEXIS 5556 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1986); In re Blizard, 81 B.R. 431, 1988 Bankr. LEXIS 59 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1988); In re Cottrell, 82 B.R. 45, 1987 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13133 (W.D. Ky. 1987); In re Peklenk, 106 B.R. 119, 1989 Bankr. LEXIS 1755 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1989); Fraley v. Commercial Credit, 189 B.R. 398, 1995 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17918 (W.D. Ky. 1995).

 Research References and Practice Aids

Bland, The Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978: An Overview, Vol. 44, No. 1, January 1980, Ky. Bench & Bar 8.

Bankruptcy Practice: A Checklist for the “Casual Practitioner,” Vol. 69, No. 3, May 2005, Ky. Bench & Bar 19.

  Treatises 

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Notice of Judgment Lien on Real Estate, Form 154.03.

Caldwell’s Kentucky Form Book, 5th Ed., Practice Context for Homestead Exemption, § 155.00.


427.180.  Grain storage receipt or scale ticket as prima facie claim of right to possession.

Text

A claimant’s production to a bankruptcy court of a grain storage receipt or scale ticket as evidence of ownership of a quantity of grain held by the trustee shall be sufficient to establish a prima facie claim of right to possession in such claimant of the quantity, quality, and type of grain specified in such document. In any case where a claimant has placed the original of such document on deposit with any party as collateral for a loan, an affidavit from such party verifying ownership of such receipt or scale ticket by the claimant shall be sufficient to establish a prima facie claim of right to possession in such claimant.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1982, ch. 101, § 1, effective July 15, 1982.

Annotations

 NOTES TO DECISIONS 

  Cited: 

 In re Wathen’s Elevators, Inc., 32 B.R. 912, 1983 Bankr. LEXIS 5427 (Bankr. W.D. Ky. 1983).


427.990.  Penalty.

Text

Whoever willfully violates KRS 427.140 shall be fined not more than $1,000, or imprisoned not more than one (1) year, or both.

History

History.
Enact. Acts 1970, ch. 217, § 9.
